Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: East Coasters will soon have more choices when they pull in to a Honda dealership. Honda will expand leasing of its Fit EV to several East Coast states this month. The all-electric car had previously been available in California and Oregon after a limited launch last summer. Now it's coming to dealerships in Massachusetts, Connecticut, Maryland, New York, and New Jersey.

The Fit EV is Honda’s only all-electric vehicle. It uses a twenty-kilowatt-hour battery and a 92-kilowatt electric motor, generating 123 horsepower and 189 pound-feet of torque. The miles per gallon equivalent ratings are 132 MPGe in the city, 105 on the highway. Honda says the Fit EV charges in less than fifteen hours when plugged into a standard 120-volt household outlet. The time is cut to less than three hours if you use Honda's special 240-volt power supply.

The Seats and Gearshift Are Environmentally Friendly, Too

The electric motor isn’t the only green part of the Fit EV. The car was the first to feature Honda’s eco-friendly bio fabric seats. The seats are derived from a sugarcane-based material; Honda says it chose sugarcane over other plants (namely corn) to limit impact on demand for food substances. Bio fabric seating is also standard on the 2014 Accord Plug-In.

The Fit EV also adds a B position to the shifter, which enhances the car’s regenerative braking function to maximize the energy recaptured with regenerative braking.  Honda suggests that the B position is most effective when controlling the car’s speed while maintaining following distance behind the car ahead, or while controlling the car’s speed while traveling downhill.

What's the Deal?

Fit EV lessees on the East Coast will get the same deal as their counterparts in California and Oregon: $389 per month for three years. The full MSRP is given as $36,625, although the car is currently only available for lease. When you lease the Fit EV, you can have it in any color you want as long as it's Reflection Blue Pearl, and collision coverage, roadside assistance, and maintenance costs are all included.

In case you're wondering if a Fit EV is right for you (or if you're right for it), check out Honda's EV Readiness Assessment. Of course, Honda is only releasing 1,100 of them, so it's not as though you'll see one on every corner (or be guaranteed to get one even if you want one). But the increased availability does mean that the EV movement continues to gain juice.

pageElements.text: What makes a woman crazy about an automobile? I can only speak for myself. I grew up in the country surrounded by a dairy farm and five brothers. To me, cars were freedom. When I was fourteen years old, as an exchange student in Ecuador, I learned how to drive in a Toyota Land Cruiser high in the Andes Mountains, where they mark driver error with small white crosses. My fifteen-year-old Ecuadorian brother was my instructor. I never wanted to get out of that car again.
Go back to the series introduction and catch up with the full story! Okay, are you back and loving the Notorious Women as much as I am?

The Talking "It" Girl

The transition to talkies at the end of the 1920s was also the end of the devil-may-care Jazz Age. As the Roaring Twenties wound down, so did the careers of so many stars who couldn't make the transition.

Bad little girl Clara Bow, Hollywood's "It" girl, loved fast cars and had enormous influence on the very sort of woman she portrayed on the screen: the working girl. She came from horrendous poverty, was raised in a tenement slum, and convinced her father to pay for a photo shoot to enter a Fame and Fortune contest for a movie role in Beyond the Rainbow, which she won. Her mother, a prostitute, tried to kill her several times and ended up in a mental hospital. At sixteen years old, Clara was raped by her alcoholic father, whom she still tried to care for and even allowed to live with her until his death in the 1950s.

As Mark Patrick of the Revs Institute for Automotive Research in Naples, Florida, said of the photo of Clara with the flashiest car of the day, Harley Earl's 1927 LaSalle, "What kind of nice Twenties girl buys a newly introduced, flashy car like a LaSalle? She was an It girl in an It car. The LaSalle was fast and flashy, just the car for a fast and flashy actress. In vibrant colors, it was the car for wealthy frat boys with low morals, prohibition gangsters and their broads, and silent-screen flapper actresses."

Clara was very talented, if somewhat crude by Hollywood standards. Clara managed to slide in under the few standards Hollywood had, which is, perhaps, the correct choice of words in the case of the girl who, it was rumored, slept with the entire University of Southern California football team and who was sued for alienation of affections by the wife of a doctor. The reports and accusations got worse and Clara was too fragile to handle them. The "dese"s and "dose"s of her heavy Brooklyn accent and her nervous stutter didn't help her case for making it into the talkies. Paramount dropped her in 1931, but she made two films after that before permanently retiring, saying, "I don't wanna be remembered as somebody who couldn't do nothin' but take her clothes off."

She had some semblance of a normal life but was eventually diagnosed with schizophrenia in 1949, endured horrible shock treatments, and died of a heart attack in 1965.  I prefer to remember her by something she said from her sanitarium in 1951: "We had individuality. We did as we pleased. I'd whiz down Sunset Boulevard in my open Kissel with several chow dogs to match my hair. Today, they're more sensible and end up with better health. But we had more fun."

pageElements.text: You are looking at Jean Harlow with her 1932 Packard Deluxe Eight sport phaeton on the left and her 1934 Cadillac V-12 town sedan on the right: expensive, conservative choices (especially the phaeton) and both very safe cars for a woman out to protect her career.

So what went so terribly wrong? Ranked one of the greatest movie stars of all time, Harlean Harlow Carpenter from Kansas City, Missouri, was initially a critical failure but had monstrous charisma on the screen as a bombshell with a body that wouldn't quit.
The movie Gallagher was renamed Platinum Blonde to cash in on the name invented for her hair color by Howard Hughes's publicity director, and many of her fans dyed their hair to try and match hers.

Taken to Hollywood by a crazy, overbearing mother who wasn't above offering herself to casting directors who would give her Baby a chance, Harlean eloped at sixteen and was quickly afterward discovered by Fox executives. She signed on under her mother's maiden name, Jean Harlow. After a few bit parts, Jean's big break came on the failure of the Norwegian silent screen star of Hell's Angels, whose thick accent couldn't cut it when Howard Hughes decided to reshoot it as a talkie. Jean Harlow eventually was able to land roles that showed her gift for comedy and became wildly famous at MGM. Her career was brief, however.

British writer David Bret published a book on the actress's eventful life, Tarnished Angel. It detailed how, in the words of one reviewer, Jean was often "drunk, debauched, and drawn to middle-aged men who let her down in bed and beat her black and blue instead of giving her the love she craved."

Lived Fast, Died Young

By the age of twenty-six, Jean had been married three times. Her second husband was found dead at home under suspicious circumstances. It was officially ruled a suicide, although it was rumored that she might have murdered him. She had an affair with the married but separated boxer Max Baer, and, to prevent a scandal from his outraged wife, the studio arranged her third marriage with a cinematographer friend that was quietly dissolved seven months later. She was now a ripe old twenty-three years old. Jean was in a two-year relationship with William Powell after that, but she died suddenly after she collapsed on a movie set and was sent home to rest.

After a week at home under the care of her Christian Scientist mother, without getting better, Jean was rushed to the hospital by William Powell and Louis B. Mayer, and she died there the next day due to kidney failure.

pageElements.text: Everyone agrees that texting and driving, or even using a handheld mobile phone to talk while driving, is a bad idea. But a new study from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows that, like many things that are bad ideas, it continues to be popular. The CDC report asked drivers from the United States and eight European countries about their phone use while driving, and the numbers weren't exactly encouraging.

In fact, it turns out that in 2011, 69 percent of U.S. drivers admitted to talking on the phone while driving at least once in the previous thirty days, and 31 percent say they have texted or even e-mailed while driving. Why is this such a bad idea? Because the U.S. Department of Transportation says that texting while driving makes you twenty-three times more likely to crash, and crashes in which a driver was using a handheld device are four times more likely to result in injury. In response to what CDC director Tom Frieden calls a potentially "fatal distraction," several states have outlawed texting while driving, with some even going so far as to ban all cell-phone use.

We know that, but has it stopped us from driving distracted? Speaking for myself, I completely avoid texting while driving but will occasionally take a phone call from behind the wheel, even though I know I probably shouldn't.

America vs. Europe

The CDC study also told us that U.S. drivers are more likely to engage with their devices than the drivers in the seven European countries included in the survey. Brits were least likely to talk on the phone, with only 21 percent of surveyed drivers copping to talking on the phone while driving in the preceding thirty days. Spain's drivers were least likely to text and drive, with just fifteen percent of those surveyed saying they had done so in the past month. Portugal tied the U.S.'s high for that data point, with 31 percent of drivers admitting to texting at least once.

If we assume those numbers are accurate (I'm inclined to believe that the number of people who talk on the phone while driving is much closer to 100 percent than 70 percent but don't have data to back me up), we still have a long way to go before the road is free of distracted drivers.

Go Cold Turkey

Unfortunately, there's no surefire way to ensure that your fellow drivers will refrain from using their phones while driving. What you can do, however, is try to limit your own temptation to text and drive. If you're unlikely to turn the phone off when you get behind the wheel (or are dealing with a teenager who doesn't take the risks seriously), think about using one of the several smartphone apps on the market that disable texting when it senses that your phone is in a moving car If a text or call absolutely can't wait, pull over to make it. Your fellow drivers will thank you.

title: Hey, Kid, Your Taxi is Here!
promoTitle: Hey, Kid, Your Taxi is Here!
promoTeaserSmall: Innovative cab service picks up your kids and gets them to ballet class, soccer game, or wherever.
promoTeaser: Innovative cab service picks up your kids and gets them to ballet class, soccer game, or wherever.
metaTitle: Hey, Kid, Your Taxi is Here! - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Hey, Kid, Your Taxi is Here! Read about Kids Kruiser, a taxi service for children. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: There are many days in the recent past when I have felt like a taxi driver. Picture me racking up miles in the driver's seat of my minivan, trying out the "You talkin' to ME?!?" line on a nonplussed four-year-old. Not pretty.

This is a feeling common to the average overscheduled parent. If you have kids, and especially if you have kids and a full-time job, you probably spend a chunk of time worrying about getting them to Point A to Point B, not to mention Points C, D, and E. You do start channeling your inner taxi driver after you've ended each day racing to get your child from preschool before they start charging the $5-per-minute late fee. You haven't lived until you've faced the regular scenario of having to pick up two kids at two different schools, get one to soccer practice on the opposite side of town, take the other one to a music lesson, and then go back to get the soccer player.

So on the day when I first saw the brightly painted Kids Kruiser minivan around town, I knew a light bulb had come on over somebody's head. I tracked down Angela McCommons, president of Kids Kruiser, and the minute I met her I knew I had found a woman with a better idea about transportation for kids.

A Taxi for Kids!

Kids Kruiser is a two-year-old company in Ypsilanti, Michigan, with the mission of providing safe and reliable transportation for children from preschool through high school. McCommons has a three-vehicle fleet, two Chrysler minivans and a Ford Fusion, and she employs four part-time drivers. Between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m., customers can get their kids picked up and dropped off in a wide swath of the Ann Arbor/Ypsilanti area. The service works similar to a taxi but with many kid-friendly touches. McCommons says that what Kids Kruiser is providing is "a familiar experience, the same as what kids are used to." So the vehicles are squeaky clean inside and equipped with board books, booster seats, and even Nook Readers with kid-friendly items installed on them. The Fusion is decorated in a more teen-friendly way, with racing stripes, but the whole fleet is immediately recognizable. "I didn't want kids to have trouble finding it," McCommons says. No worries there!

McCommons, 35, is an engineer by education and training and worked for Chrysler before starting the business. She already has some 100 families registered with the service. Kids Kruiser also has a relationship with the local Education Project for Homeless Youth, so the brightly colored vehicles pick up and drop off children in temporary housing or shelters who might not have reliable ways to get to school or activities.

On a recent afternoon, I rode in the Kids Kruiser minivan while McCommons picked up a little girl from her preschool. This pickup was a regular arrangement with the school, so she just had to pull in to the parking spot at the appointed time, and a teacher brought the girl out in her wheelchair, installed her car seat in the second row of the minivan, and strapped her in. The wheelchair folded to fit neatly in the back of the van, and we were on our way.

Brilliant App

Here's the best part of the Kids Kruiser setup: McCommons, working with a local app developer, created a custom app to allow her to notify parents immediately by text that a Kids Kruiser driver has picked up or dropped off their child. I watched her pull a card with a QR code (one of those square black things) from a file in the driver's compartment and scan it with her iPhone. This automatically sent a text to the girl's mom that she had been picked up. McCommons issues iPhones with the app to every driver so they can do the same. She comments: "We have lots of parents in the medical profession. They are very busy and can't get phone calls, but they can look at a text and know everything's okay."

images.caption: Angela fits passenger's wheelchair in back of the van.
Once she has dropped off or picked up, she sends a confirming text.
Kids Kruiser brand  is everywhere on the vehicle.
Booster seats are provided.
Kids Kruiser app may be the most innovative aspect.
Teens prefer the racing stripe to the rainbow when they get picked up.

pageElements.text: After about ten minutes on the road, we pulled up at the girl's house, and her mother came out the door with a younger child in tow. The text message had let her know exactly when to expect the Kids Kruiser to arrive. Having safely delivered the girl, McCommons again swiped her card on the iPhone. A confirmation text went to the mom. The app also provides the company the data it needs to keep track of all the vehicles and their activities for the day.

A Premium Service at a Premium Price

Kids Kruiser rides don't come cheap. The company charges $17 for the first five miles traveled, which McCommons says includes a $5 pickup fee, and $2 for each additional mile. If the driver is asked to install a customer's own child seat in the vehicle, it's an additional $5 charge. The kids don't pay on the spot, obviously; parents have accounts and are asked to set up and pay for rides in advance.

This could add up to a not inconsiderable amount of money if you planned to have a Kids Kruiser pick up your child regularly. On the other hand, as McCommons points out, "We're not just a taxi ride. We're in charge of your kid during that time." Besides, have you priced gasoline lately? She makes a point of getting together with each family in person before the first ride ever happens, to meet the child or children and make sure the family is comfortable with the service, and her drivers are very carefully screened.

McCommons is willing to take adult passengers, and she does a little side business in driving college students to and from the airport, but as the decorative vans make clear, her main focus is on kids. This is what you call seeing a need and filling it well.

title: The Bike Helmet You Can't See
promoTitle: The Bike Helmet You Can't See
promoTeaserSmall: Two women industrial designers solved the problem of safe biking without a big, cumbersome helmet.
promoTeaser: Two women industrial designers solved the problem of safe biking without a big, cumbersome helmet.
metaTitle: The Bike Helmet You Can't See - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: The Bike Helmet You Can't See
metaDescription: The Bike Helmet You Can't See: Learn about the "invisible bike helmet" invented by two Swedish women. It's a scarf until you crash; then it inflates like a car's airbag. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Anyone who has tried to convince a twelve-year-old child to wear a bike helmet for his or her jaunts about town already knows that bike helmets aren't cool. Sure, they'll save your life, but if the price is a seriously mussed hairdo, are you really going to wear one every time you hop on a bike for a trip around the corner? I think if we're being honest, we've all skipped the helmet once or twice, even though we know we shouldn't.

Anna Haupt and Terese Alstin say they "wouldn't be seen dead" in a plastic-and-foam bike helmet. In 2005, when they both were industrial design students at Lund University in Sweden, they thought there should be an alternative for stylish people who also want to be protected from catastrophic head trauma. So they set about inventing something that seemed impossible: an invisible bike helmet.

The Only Airbag That Can Match Your Outfit

What they came up with almost looks like something out of a sci-fi movie. Dubbed Hovding (the Swedish word for "chieftain"), it's a kind of collar that is worn around the neck like a scarf. It's not exactly invisible (the collar's outer shell will be available in a variety of colors and designs), but close enough. The collar contains an airbag and sensors that detect when the wearer is in a crash, as well as a black box to record data about crashes. When the sensors detect a crash, they trigger a gas inflator that causes the airbag to inflate rapidly to form a cocoon of protection around the wearer's cranium. The whole process takes 0.1 second, meaning that the cyclist's head is protected before it ever hits the ground.

Mohawks Won't Work, But Earbuds Are Fine

Of course, with every innovation there is a downside. Hovding's is that it costs roughly $500 and can only be used once. Once the device has deployed, users will need to buy a new collar, although Hovding gives customers a discount if they send back their spent units and the accompanying crash data, which is used for further research. Punk rockers beware: you can't use Hovding with heavy dreads, a stiff mohawk, or large hoop earrings. Those styles could all impede the airbag's ability to inflate properly, but you can wear Hovding with caps, knit hats, small earrings, and headphones.

Despite the inherent challenges in selling a $500 helmet to people who would just as soon not wear one, Haupt and Alstin are determined to make their product an industry changer. It's not available yet in the United States but has been spreading across Europe, gaining fans, winning design awards, and acing crash tests. Visit their website and check out their video showing the helmet in action, and prepare to be amazed.

Who knows? Maybe five years from now we'll all be wearing airbags around our necks. It may not seem likely, but as Haupt and Alstin say, people who don't think big may call themselves realists, but they're really just "scaredy cats."

images.caption: "Black box" records accident information, airplane style

metaDescription: $ to Buy a Car: Get a Fix on Rates. Read part 2 in our series on financial preparation to buy a car. This segment is on interest rates and financing, and it's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Researching and picking out a new car are exhilarating, but the buying process can be daunting. Cars are expensive, and there's a general feeling that the odds of getting a good deal are stacked against the buyer. Huddy Skiba, sales manager at Hyman Bros. Mazda in Newport News, Virginia, says that when customers walk into a car dealership, they are "terrified that they're going to be ripped off. We're just trying to help."

We want to help, too, so we've put together a few pieces of advice to help unravel the mysteries of shopping for your new car. Doing your homework before you ever walk into a dealership can go a long way toward  making you feel more confident, so this week we'll be talking about what to think about before you finance a car. Follow along, and we'll break down a different part of the process for you each day.
Today, we're focusing on interest rates: what to expect, where to finance, and what to think about before you sign away five years' worth of paychecks.

Interest can add thousands of dollars to the total cost of your car (depending on the interest rate and the size and term of the loan), so it's important to get the best rate you can. Average rates fluctuate over time and also vary depending on the lender supplying them. Dealerships, banks, and credit unions will all finance cars. We recommend checking with a few lenders before you commit to one.

By shopping around for rates before you head to the dealership, you can know what a reasonable annual percentage rate (APR) is and negotiate from there. If a dealer can't give you a rate as low as another establishment, don't be afraid to finance your purchase from outside the manufacturer's financing arm.

Warning: the math involved in understanding APR and discounted price offers can get confusing, which is why you should take all the time you need to get a full explanation and make sure you understand it. Skiba warns against assuming that promotional deals (like the popular zero percent APR) are always the best choice. He says that a special interest rate often takes the place of a rebate. He gives a recent example of a 2012 Mazda 3: "We can sell [this car] with $2,259 off sticker price in lieu of special interest," he says, "but if they want the special rate, it adds $1,400" to the price advertised on the dealership's website. Buyers who take the special interest rate will still pay less than the sticker price, but they'll pay about $1,400 more than a buyer who finances at a normal rate instead of the promotional rate. In this case, customers who opt for zero percent financing would also have to choose a thirty-six-month loan, forgoing the chance to take longer to pay off the car.

For Skiba, it all comes down to numbers. "If you do the math, it might make more sense to do the cheaper price" instead of the zero percent deal. Of course, these particulars will vary from dealer to dealer, but make sure you work out the numbers on all the options you're considering before you sign on the dotted line.
Check back tomorrow for part three of our auto financing series. We'll talk about how to decide how much you can afford to spend on your new wheels.

pageElements.text: Blind spots are an unfortunate but unavoidable part of driving a car, right? Checking your blind spots before switching lanes is one of the very first things they teach new drivers. Being aware of your surroundings when you’re driving never gets less important, but it’s also a little annoying to constantly check over your shoulder to see if some jackass is riding in your blind spot.
New car technology has gone a long way towards making the blind spot check less of a guessing game, with blind spot warning systems growing more prevalent in recent years.

20/20 Hindsight

But even if you’re still driving an older model, there's one way to save your neck from the constant twisting and turning necessitated by safe lane changes. Hammacher Schlemmer is here to save the day with its panoramic No Blind Spot Rear View Mirror. The mirror is more than fifteen inches wide and clips over your car’s existing rearview mirror.

Hammacher Schlemmer says the mirror offers a 180-degree view of the road behind you, while traditional rear- and sideview mirrors together only offer 52 degrees of visibility. In plainer terms? No more turning your head to check the blind spot, and more visibility over all. Peace of mind in mirror form.

Don’t worry if Hammacher Schlemmer’s $59.95 price seems a little hefty. Versions of this product can be found all over the Internet and at auto supply stores for a smaller ransom. Check Amazon.com for a wide selection of the extra-long mirrors, then get back to driving and enjoy your panoramic view of the road behind you.

title: Road Atlas Joins the 21st Century
promoTeaserSmall: Rand McNally atlases you won't shrug at: on iPad and e-book, to supplement (or replace) a nav system.
promoTeaser: Rand McNally atlases you won't shrug at: on iPad and e-book, to supplement (or replace) a nav system.
metaTitle: Road Atlas Joins the 21st Century - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Road Atlas Joins the 21st Century. Read about the 90th-anniversary Rand McNally atlas, now available as an iPad app and an e-book. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Rand McNally has just come out with its 2014 Road Atlas, and that is the best sign of spring I can think of. That's because many of my best road-trip memories involve maps. I love unfolding them or leafing through the atlas, plotting a route with a highlighter in my hand, and imagining various routes that I can change as I go. Often I have been the navigator, proud of my ability to get us there and then fold the maps up neatly when we're done.

The advent of electronic aids such as Google Maps and navigation systems should have dealt a death blow to the paper map, but it hasn't. Like vinyl records, which are the music connoisseur's choice these days, the old-school atlas and map have their adherents.
Or, as Jean puts it, "nav schmav." She's a fan of paper maps, too.

Ninety Years of Navigation

With that in mind, come along with me on a little trip back to 1924. Two million Model Ts were produced in 1924 on the Ford assembly line you see at right, and people were filling them with twenty-one-cent-a-gallon gasoline and looking to head off somewhere. Rand McNally met that need when it came out with the very first U.S. road atlas. It was charmingly known as the Rand McNally Auto Chum, and it had no Interstate highways on it; there weren't any yet (not until the 1950s).

The coolest thing about the Auto Chum (besides the name, of course) is that it was organized geographically from east to west, starting with Maine. There's a  poetic implication there, the idea that you would open the book at Maine and drive through the pages until you hit California. It must have made for a bit of a geography lesson for kids on road trips, too.

From that auspicious beginning, Rand McNally atlases have lived on the back seats and in the map pockets of cars for ninety years. Lately, there are lots of electronic solutions to the question of "Where are we?" So, is it time to give up on the printed atlas?
Don't bet on it. For a ninety-year-old, Rand McNally is spry, and so the venerable company has come out with its 2014 edition in three formats: paper, iPad, and e-book.

Three Ways to Atlas

The e-book ($4.95, for iPad, iPhone, and iPod Touch) has features you also find in the printed version, such as a city locator, a mileage calculator, and tourism contact numbers and links. Once downloaded, it's also usable at times when you don't have Internet access.

I tried out the iPad app ($4.99) and found that it is pretty much a duplicate of the atlas. There are no pop-ups, no links, no newfangled games to play: you touch the name of the state, and you get the same map that's in the printed atlas. You can enlarge it, which is an improvement. It's better than Google Maps in that you can use it offline, but not as good in that you can't ask it to give you directions. I think it's something I will be glad to have on my next road trip as an easy-to-use, familiar friend alongside the Google Maps directions I will have printed out. The iPad atlas will surely entice me to toss the directions aside and explore some side road I hadn't considered, and that's what road trips are all about.

title: Our Rules of the Road
subTitle: Our editors live by three rules when planning a trip. (We don't all agree on what the rules are.)
promoTeaserSmall: What's your packing style?
promoTeaser: Our editors live by three rules when planning a trip. (We don't all agree on what the rules are.)
metaTitle: Our Rules of the Road - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Our Rules of the Road: Read the JeanKnowsCars.com editors' rules for preparing to take a road trip. Each of us has her own list and her own style for traveling in the car. See them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: We like to do things in groups of three, as you know if you watch Jean’s You Auto Know videos. It’s a good way to break any task down into manageable parts. For that reason, I asked our editors to come up with their top three rules when they’re setting off on a road trip. And here they are, starting with my own. You'll notice that we have very different styles of packing for a trip. Which JKC editor are you?

Laura Sky Brown: Same Hippie, Different Decade

I have gone on many extended road trips. The first one, at age eighteen, when I didn’t even have my driver’s license yet, was an extended five-week journey all over the country. Stuffed into a Chevrolet Vega with a teenage friend and her large dog—so, with barely enough room to sit, let alone bring stuff—we traveled from Michigan to Washington State, then from Washington to western Massachusetts, by way of the Grand Canyon and nearly every other place in between. Some things have changed: back in those days, I didn’t much care whether I changed clothes every day or not, but I do now. Nevertheless, that trip taught me to pack light and learn to like it. Here are my rules for a road trip.

Rule #1: Pack light. No, lighter than that. If you can’t carry it yourself, don’t bring it. Unless you are going off-road in the Yukon, there are stores out there that sell most of what you might need beyond the basics. I even like to pack cheap or worn-out socks and T-shirts that I can discard when they’re dirty, making room for things I have acquired on the road. So you’re out in Utah without the exact headband or conditioner you would use at home! Who cares? You also won’t have to spend any time sorting, classifying, and packing and repacking those things. Having a light load frees you up both mentally and physically.

Rule #2: Know what you want to eat, and have it with you in the car. Otherwise, you end up at gas station shops buying Pringles when you really should have had bananas and nonfat yogurt. A small cooler is worth any weight and space it takes up.

Rule #3: Have a carefully crafted route and plan, and then be prepared to deviate from it regularly. This means maps and atlases, not just a nav system, so you have the resources to see the big picture and change your route intelligently when you spot an interesting detour. (See our related article on the latest in road atlas technology.)

Jean Jennings: Packing Genius

After three decades of traveling to places as far-flung as Madagascar, China, and Abu Dhabi (only China was a real road trip…on motorcycles), I’m a packing genius.

The longest time actually spent in a car was the first of the three times I participated in the One Lap of America race. That first time was 9,000-plus miles with co-drivers Parnelli Jones The Great and off-road truck racer Walker Evans, but it was in a full-sized Dodge panel van (disguised as a Stroh Brewery delivery truck).
From that big adventure, I solidified these rules.

Rule #1: Always bring a map. If it is an interstate adventure, bring an atlas. You need perspective, you need emergency routes, you need to know where you are at all times, in relationship to the rest of the United States. And you must never put the map away while you are in the car. A passenger who can’t use a map is almost useless.

Rule #2: Pack light. The third One Lap of America completely refined my must-have road tripping list because it was in a Porsche 911. The frunk (short for front trunk—engine is in the rear) is deep, but it ain’t no minivan. One small duffel each for co-driver Hurley Haywood and me. He also needed the space behind the back seats for his racing suit and helmet, because we had racetrack segments all around the 5,000-plus-mile route.

Rule #3: Comfort items are essential. The 911’s back seatbacks flip down, allowing something smallish (like a memory foam pillow) on the seat before you flip the back down. You then have a surprising amount of room for other stuff, like a thin quilt or an Eddie Bauer summer-weight down comforter (mine has plaid nylon on one side and fake fur on the other) that can squish up really tightly. I also like earplugs and eyeshades to complete the sensory deprivation I need to get a good car nap. Plus, slip-on sheepskin slippers with road soles.
Rule #3B: Bring an iPad. It’s a comfort item, too. You can play games, read books, get e-mail, and check and maintain your social standing on the road.
If this sounds like I set myself up on the road like I’m staying in bed all weekend, well, yeah, I guess so! But don’t forget the map.

Molly Jean: Queen of the Road

On the longest road trip I have ever been on, we drove around Lake Superior, with four adults, four bikes, and camping gear in a Mercedes-Benz E350 wagon. We were so stuffed in that when we returned home we bought a van. I am now a firm believer that, for comfort, you need a vehicle big enough to bring everything you could possibly need with you. In that, I know I am the exact opposite kind of traveler from Laura and Jean. I wonder whether we should take a long road trip together and see what happens? Here are my rules:

Rule #1: Be overprepared. My technique is to leave nothing home. “Coffin” (car-top carrier) on top, bike rack in the trailer hitch, and stuffed to the gills inside. I try to make it so that if the brakes are slammed, heavy items will not kill the passengers. Otherwise, I fill it up. My goal is to keep the front passenger's footwell clear. It never happens.

Rule #2: Be flexible. We got the van stuck in the mud at a closed campground at one o'clock in the morning and had to unload the entire vehicle, including the bike rack, to lighten the load. A sense of humor is one of the many things you must bring with you on a road trip.

Rule #3: Bring an atlas of county maps. Along with a blanket and pillow, an eye shade, an iPod, and a bag of candy and gum, it’s one of the essentials that ride up front with me. If there are big roads, there are little roads nearby; why not take those instead whenever you can, and actually see something?

Annie White: Have Tent, Will Travel

Planning has never been my forte. I’m more of a fly-by-the-seat-of-my-pants kind of girl. As long as I’ve got a tent I’ve got a place to sleep, and that’s all the planning I need. Of course, this travel technique works best for the young and unattached and doesn’t go as well with a family or a strict schedule. But for now it’s working just fine.

My longest road trip to date was an 1,800-mile jaunt from the Oregon coast to Yosemite National Park and back again. Salty snacks, good music, swims in ocean streams, nights spent under the stars—that trip had it all.
Rule #1: Think before you pack. My mother always told me to make a list when packing for any trip, and even though I almost never do it, I recognize that it’s good advice.

I resist the urge to overpack by laying everything out before I stuff it in bags, then doing a second pass to eliminate unnecessary items. As long as I am physically capable of carrying all my baggage at once, I know I’ve done good work.
Rule #2: Keep it light. I learned a long time ago that the only things you really need when traveling are a toothbrush, a few pairs of clean underwear, and maybe a first aid kit.
Rule #3: Bonus points for electronics. It’s worth the weight to have a phone (with charger) and a solid playlist (no mopey music allowed).

Gabrielle George: Catching the Joy as It Flies

The longest road trip I've taken was five hours north, to Mackinac Island in northern Michigan during high school. My friends and I felt ready, prepared, and safe. We all took turns driving when a person felt like she wanted a rest. We stopped at rest stops and jumped around, got drinks, went to the bathroom then off on the road again. Nothing more than loud music, obnoxious singing, windows down, energies high, and spirits lifted. I did the navigation, Alice fed me cheesy Combos, and I handed Hayley our classic childhood snack, Gushers. Five hours later, we hit the dock. It was time to park our mini house of snacks and luggage and take the ferry boat off to the world where no cars are allowed. After the long weekend, we headed back to Ann Arbor. We continued eating Combos and watching the little blue dot on my iPhone go straight through the state of Michigan. I would totally do that again. Next stop... Canada.

Rule #1: Make lists and more lists. I'm all about to-do lists. They're the one thing that works completely. I usually forget less when I have my handy-dandy journal of to-do lists and goals. I sync the lists with my iPad, iPhone, and laptop. When planning for a trip, I’ll make a packing list, a list of places to visit, a list of phone numbers and contacts…the list of lists is endless.

Rule #2: Create a personal set of road essentials. Mine traditionally includes Pepperidge Farm Goldfish and iced tea, plus Dramamine whenever I take a trip out of town. Last but surely not least, I'll definitely always need my camera right by my side the whole time.

Rule #3: Watch out for the small stuff. The number-one thing that I always lose in my luggage is memory cards. You have to keep a close eye on those, plus small but pivotal items such as lens caps, bobby pins, and chargers, so that you don’t lose them on a trip.
So we've got to ask: What's your packing style?

pageElements.text: Detroit—They say that all manly conversations eventually degenerate into talk about one of two topics: women and cars. Well, that’s what [former Automobile Magazine editor] Kevin Smith told me once, and my experience says he’s probably right, as shallow as the thought may be.
Women and cars.

If it’s true, then men must be in hog heaven when the auto show season rolls around. For an evening, they can stow the chitchat about the stock market, chain saws, the painful itch of hemorrhoids, the lawn, and the Final Four and walk into a room where their supposed true passions coexist in forced harmony. Sports cars and spike heels. Plunging V-necks and V-12s. Big Foot trucks and beaded gowns. Is this really a dream come true for the men in the audience? What does all this mean? their wives and girlfriends wonder suspiciously. And what do the models see when they look back out at the crowd?

image.altText: do you come with the car honey

pageElements.text: There was only one way to find out: join the sequined ranks. It had been attempted once before, by Amanda Bennett, a reporter for the Wall Street Journal. When she presented herself to Affiliated Models, a major Detroit talent booking agency for auto shows around the country, they took one look at her compact frame and red hair and said, “Definitely Jeep.” So when I made my formal request, I wasn’t expecting charity. But I took comfort in the fact that Detroit’s Cobo Hall doesn’t have room to show motorhomes. My best chance, I figured, would be if one of the car companies needed a human tree or some other kind of heavily robed and mute character for an exhibit. Chrysler was the only company brave enough to call.
My best chance, I figured, would be if one of the car companies needed a human tree or some other kind of heavily robed and mute character for an exhibit.

“Glad to have you with us,” said my old Chrysler PR pal Moon Mullins. “We’re putting you on the Premier. You need to come down and get your script and be fitted for your gown.” And, with that great leap of faith, I found myself swathed in lame and spangles and with a great big head of ratted-up hair you could see through.

Models do not start out with that hair; they make it with lots of mousse, gel, and an especially tenacious hair spray called Final Net. Imagine thirty women spraying thirty spray bottles of Final Net in unison in a single room, and you have the gist of the Chrysler dressing room at Cobo Hall.

There isn’t much one can do to prepare for meeting a dressing room full of models. The best idea is to be there when they arrive looking like mere mortals in sweat pants and jeans, devoid of war paint, hair in ponytails and curlers. All the Cinderella gear hangs lifeless in the wardrobe; the ear chandeliers are jumbled together in a big Ziploc bag; harmless cardboard boxes hide the Cruel Shoes within.
You may think they are the most gorgeous women you have ever seen assembled in one location. But if you listen, you’ll realize that they have many problems.
“Oh, God, you should have seen my hair this morning,” wailed one, backcombing and spraying. “I looked like Don King.”
“I hope I’m not getting measles or something weird,” said another, her concerned face two inches from the mirror. “I’ve got these little red dots all over my face.”
I was introduced as a reporter who was going to write a story about them. They stared at me, meaning at my clothes, at my hair, at my shoes, at my abused body.
“What can I say?” I told them, grinning. “It’s been a bad winter.”
“Oh, you don’t look that bad,” said next year’s Miss Universe, trying to help.

“Just remember,” said model Ann Howard, who had just turned her thin little ponytail into a wild mane of hair that wouldn’t fit under an umbrella, “when you’ve got Final Net, you’ve got a styling tool.”

pageElements.text: Hello, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to the Detroit Auto Show, and to Eagle 1988, featuring the Eagle Medallion and Eagle Premier…

I had practiced my speech for a week, shouting it out in the car to and from work with the radio blasting to simulate Major Distractions. I didn’t sound like a model to me. I didn’t sound like a model to Affiliated, either. The agency sent in a one-woman SWAT team—local actor Sonya Avakian—to whip me into shape. So to speak.

“Look, this isn’t brain surgery,” said coach Sonya. “No one is going to live or die by what happens on that turntable. All you need to do is adopt a kind of warm, brainless tone, like a female Mister Rogers.”
Eagle is the first new domestic automotive brand in nearly thirty years. Eagle represents Chrysler Motors’ commitment to developing distinctive and sophisticated automobiles.
My face hurt from smiling The Smile. I positively oozed brainless.
“No one is going to live or die by what happens on that turntable. All you need to do is adopt a kind of warm, brainless tone, like a female Mister Rogers.”

image.altText: do you come with the car honey

pageElements.text: “Great,” said Sonya. “And if you project all your nervous energy straight into your eyebrows, you’ll have the look right, too. Just don’t worry about it. The people listening to you are the guys who crush beer cans on their foreheads.” How reassuring.

Delivery was one thing; content was an entirely different matter. Let’s not dwell on the script for long, but I would like to point out that the models don’t write their own lines. Give that some consideration the next time you hear one say something like:
The Premier has an exceptional knack for putting the right things in the right places!
What does this mean? you might well ask. They put the pedals on the floor? They put the steering wheel in the front seat? A roomful of models is asking the same questions.
This is my favorite:
The Premier was designed by Jee-o-jetty Jew-jar-o, the world’s leader in today’s automotive designs.
That is an exact transcription of the way the script read. Giorgetto (Jor-jet-o) himself couldn’t change the pronunciation once his poor bastardized name had been carefully and permanently memorized.

Joie Edwards, a four-year-veteran Chrysler model, knew better. “Hey! This guy’s name isn’t Jee-o-jetty. It’s Giorgio. I remember ‘cause he designed the Isuzu Impulse. I’ll always remember it because my girlfriend had to read that script the year the car was introduced. She couldn’t say his name, so when it would get slow, she would just say her boyfriend’s name instead of Giugiaro. But one time this woman in the audience said, ‘Who did you say? I thought Giugiaro designed this car.’ She was so freaked she never did it again.”
Well, I knew his name, I knew his script, and I had my outfit together. I climbed to the turntable with shaky legs and big hair. Thankfully, Elizabeth Carroll, a real model, was there to help.
“Oh, God. You look great!” she said. “We’re going to have a blast! Here’s the mike.”

“You could help me best by going first,” I mumbled, ever the wimp.

pageElements.text: I assumed The Position (back to driver’s door, right hand on roof, left hand in a loose fist on left hip, left foot at right angle to right foot, leaning back into straight left leg) as Elizabeth went to work. No one except me knew when she flubbed her lines, because missing a line never fazed her. She simply told all those upturned faces what she knew about the Premier. She smiled and joked. She answered questions that weren’t covered by the script. She knew where the Premier was made. She knew the base price. She knew how much it cost loaded. She knew that there are no four-wheel-drive Eagles. She knew the horsepower numbers. She knew how to say Giorgetto Giugiaro. They loved her.
My first try was a disaster. I flubbed my lines and stopped dead in mid-delivery.
“Premier’s streamlined design should be viewed…” I heard Elizabeth feeding me the lines, sotto voce, as her turntable passed behind mine.
Premier’s streamlined design should be viewed not merely as a technical exercise in aerodynamics but rather as a personal expression of contemporary style and sensibility.
I picked up in midstream, crimson face clashing unfashionably with copper lame. I eventually stumbled through to the end, unplugged the mike, and joined Elizabeth on her rotating platform.
As we trundled around on our exhibit, I realized that all the nearby models in the Jeep/Eagle area had stopped to watch my debut.

“You were great,” she breathed behind The Smile, as I assumed The Position on the other side of the car. As we trundled around on our exhibit, I realized that all the nearby models in the Jeep/Eagle area had stopped to watch my debut. Upturned thumbs and pantomimed clapping dotted our circular path. God love 'em, I thought. But I was still waiting for some indignant member of the crowd, feeling cheated by this obvious impostor, to yell, “What did you do to get that job?”
Some men do say very rude things to the models.

image.altText: do you come with the car honey

pageElements.text: “One guy asked me the EPA numbers on the Shadow concept car,” said Ann Howard later, during our break. “I told him I didn’t have that particular piece of information, and he said, ‘Well, I guess they don’t pay you to be intelligent, do they?’ I just walked to the other side of the car. I take it all with a grain of salt. It’s not a reflection on me, but on his personality.”

“This guy called me ‘biscuit,’ ” said Amanda Turner, whose five years’ experience on the circuit have taught her to wear slippers every second she’s not up on the display. “‘Biscuit!’ Ha! That’s a new one. ‘Hey, biscuit!’ he said. ‘Come here, or are you too busy talking to your sugar daddy?’”

I didn’t have any stories to tell, except the one about how a local high school marching band had burst through the double doors behind my exhibit, drums beating, cymbals clashing, horns blowing, right at the part where I say:
Inside, the Premier’s interior is more than roomy. It features a logical layout, sophisticated technology, and rich appointments.

I gave up, smiled, and waved my arm back and forth gracefully, like Vanna showing the Amana side-by-side refrigerator/freezer in the showcase on Wheel of Fortune. At least I hoped I looked like Vanna. (“I’ll take that Premier for $12,500, Pat. And put the rest into a gift certificate.”)

Once I had my script really memorized, no one could stop me. Not even the sales rep on the floor who came over and said, “You keep telling people to check out the Premier DL, LX, and ES models. But we don’t have the DL anymore. Chrysler dropped it.” Tough luck, Jack. It was burned indelibly in my memory at that point.

I was more concerned that someone would recognize me. The exact date of my appearance was a state secret; I wasn’t interested in being seen by a single soul that I knew, including my husband; anyone from Automobile Magazine; any engineers, car designers, or PR guys from the other car companies; any neighbors; any of my four brothers; or a stray cousin. But I was recognized twice.

pageElements.text: First came the trio of advertising agency clowns whom I got rid of by ignoring. Not so easy was the guy who stared at me from every angle for twenty minutes.
“I’ve got it!” he finally yelled. “You’re Linda from Automotive!”
“Uh, no,” I said. I cannot tell a lie.
“C’mon,” he insisted. “I fell asleep last night reading your column.”
Perfect.
It seems that when you dress like a model, talk like a model, rat your hair, and wear a ton of makeup during daylight hours, people think you really are a model.

image.altText: do you come with the car honey

pageElements.text: But I fooled the rest of them. It seems that when you dress like a model, talk like a model, rat your hair, and wear a ton of makeup during daylight hours, people think you really are a model. The crowd parted before me like the Red Sea before Moses when I left the platform for the dressing room. On my way up the back stairs, I passed two security guards.
“Hi, guys,” said Just Jean. They were stunned. As I went around the corner, I heard one say to the other, “Wow! Cool.” Okay, I loved it.
I asked the women in the dressing room how they handle this adulation.

“I love wearing fancy clothes and getting attention,” answered Karyn Lynn, who is a third-year advertising student at Michigan State. “Some girls take it for granted, but I just turned twenty-two, and I figure I might as well make the most of it. My boyfriend gets real jealous, and even my parents say, ‘Don’t let it go to your head.’ But deep down, I’m really concerned about my looks. I feel terrible when I get turned down at an audition. It’s bad to be sensitive in this business.”

“People are attracted to auto show models and to the idea of auto show models,” said Sarah Gorman, the Affiliated agency’s number-one auto show model. “But when you take the makeup and the fancy clothes off, it’s another story.”

The problems come when adulation turns to obsession. “Sometimes it’s all pretty harmless,” said Jean Reader, a Northwest stewardess in real life. “There’s this guy in Chicago every year who sits in cars and stares, and you can tell it’s at your feet. Sometimes he’ll come over and say, ‘Those sure are pretty shoes.’ ”
Sharon Coley rolled her eyes. “Right. He says, ‘You have beautiful feet. I’d love to touch them.’ ”

“There’s this guy here who follows us all over,” added Ann Howard. “I’ve seen him in Cleveland, Miami, Detroit, New York, and Chicago. Once he gave me a thirty-page letter about how to dress and wear my makeup to attract the right kind of men. It closed with a Bible verse. I showed everyone, and almost all the girls had a mimeographed copy.”
No one was amused by this.
“And don’t forget Dr. Chan, the anesthesiologist,” added Sarah Gorman. “I’ve seen him everywhere. He only likes blondes. He weighs about forty-five pounds.”
“Did I tell you about the guy who relieved himself sexually in front of me in a packed crowd?” asked Carrie Hall. Everyone in the room squealed. “I went nuts!”

“God came to my display yesterday,” said Jean Reader. “He’s short, fat, black, and balding. ‘I think I’ll take you,’ he said to me. ‘I can have anything I want—I’m God.’ I told him that I had to do my speech. And then some kids crawled into my truck and started kicking on the hockey puck that was glued on the dash for a contest. They finally got it loose and stole it.”

image.altText: do you come with the car honey

pageElements.text: The one-hour dinner break finished, heavy beaded gowns were slid back onto raw shoulders while swollen feet were wedged into shoes designed by men. The makeup cases and the Final Net came out for a quick once-over.

I hurried back to my Premier, hoping for a weirdo of my very own. All I found was a little chubby guy who held a video camera pasted to his face during my entire spiel.

pageElements.text: Premier’s smooth body shape runs virtually uninterrupted—without sharp angles in shape or form...
Whir, whir, went the camera.
...from its sloping nose to its aerostyle side mirrors, highly sloped windshield, semiflush side windows, and integral rear bumper.

The camera panned as I strode across the stage doing my Vanna hand thing, when all of a sudden my spike heel found the tiniest hole in the platform and buried itself, stopping me dead in my tracks. The Smile never wavered. The camera never stopped. I continued, discreetly trying to tug my shoe out of the hole.

The power behind Premier is its standard 2.5-liter fuel-injected four-cylinder engine. Teamed with a convenient four-speed automatic transmission, this advanced powerplant delivers quiet, smooth performance and impressive fuel economy.

I finished, unplugged the mike, and reached down to grab my shoe and yank it from the hole. At which point the cameraman stopped. “Could you just say your name?” he asked, and slapped the camera back to his eye. Whir, whir.
“Margaret,” I said, tugging mightily. “My name is Margaret.”

My last interesting visitor was proof that not all wives and girlfriends stare at the models with dagger eyes. A woman in her mid-fifties stared at me during my entire presentation. She was pressed against the turntable, head craned all the way back, eyes riveted to my face. When I finished, she said, “Those long earrings are in now, aren’t they?”
“Sure,” I said. Hey, I read Elle.

“My son is getting married, and I bought a dress from Jacobson’s for $400—well, it was really $200; I got it half price. But, it’s red and it has a red rose right here and I was wondering…well, do you think I can wear long rhinestone earrings with it?”
I told her what she wanted to hear. “As the mother of the groom, I think it’s your prerogative to outshine the bride.” The blind leading the blind.
She started at me. “Do you really?”
“Yes, ma’am, I really do.”
“Thank you so much,” she said, and she left.

Oh, yes. One guy did ask me if I came with the car. This question is asked more often than “How much does it cost?” I was carefully coached by Karyn Lynn on how to answer should the opportunity arise.
“I sure do,” I said with The Smile. “And with a husband, two dogs, and a big mortgage.” He loved me.
Thank you for your attention, ladies and gentlemen. And don’t forget—please buckle up for safety on your way home.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: New cars are packed with technology most of us couldn’t have imagined ten years ago. This is good news for tech-savvy early adopters, but for the rest of us, all these new functions can be overwhelming. For the owners of new Ford vehicles, the learning process is about to get a little easier.

Ford has just launched a new video orientation program, which makes use of short instructional videos (Ford is calling them “video snacks”) to help consumers discover the potential in their new cars. New owners will go over a list of features with their salesperson when they purchase their car and decide which features they’d like to receive guidance on via the short videos Ford has created. The customer will then receive an e-mail with links to the videos they wanted to see, which they can then watch at their leisure and as often as necessary until they feel comfortable with their car’s technology. Customers can also single out car features that they would like to discuss with a salesperson on delivery of their car, what they’d like to talk about during a Sync My Ride session, and topics they’d rather not cover at all.

Ninety Ways to Explore Your Ford

Ford has created more than ninety of the videos, choosing topics based on the questions new owners ask on online forums most frequently. Topics range from technology like My Key, which allows parents to limit a car’s functions when a teen is driving, to simple instructions like how to operate a car’s electronic parking brake.

The company hopes that the short videos will allow customers to master their new car’s features on their own time instead of attempting to absorb all that information in one visit to the dealership. The videos could be considered a little cheesy by some, but they’re undeniably informative and easy to follow. Ford has also posted the videos to the “Know Your Vehicle” playlist on its Ford Owner YouTube channel, allowing current owners can reap the benefits without having to make a return trip to the dealership.

metaDescription: Lamborghini Aventador in Yellow, a 50th anniversary special edition, will be sold in a limited edition of 100 after its debut at the Shanghai Auto Show. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Lamborghini turns fifty this year, and the Italian exotic-car maker is (not surprisingly) going over the hill with a bang.

At the Shanghai Auto Show next week, the company will unveil a special edition of its Aventador supercar. The Aventador LP720-4 50° Anniversario will have a run of only 100 vehicles and can use its astounding 720-horsepower 6.5-liter V-12 engine to propel the car from 0 to 60 mph in less than three seconds.
Blistering power is all well and good, but what will it look like standing still?

Glittering Giallo

This special edition will be a vision in yellow—or, more specifically, Giallo Maggio (May yellow), a brand-new paint color meant to reference Lamborghini’s founding in May 1963 and the historical preference that its customers have for yellow exteriors. Lamborghini assures us that the color will have a “particularly intense glitter effect,” so you may have to pull out your shades in the unlikely event that you spot one of these ultra-exclusive supercars cruising around town.

The interior will be similarly eye-catching in black and brown (or black and yellow) leather. What shade of yellow? you may ask. It's Giallo Quercus, which harmonizes with the exterior. It's named for the yellow oak tree displayed in the coat of arms of Sant’Agata Bolognese, Lamborghini's home town.

Even if Lamborghinis aren’t quite your cup of tea, you can’t deny the superior craftsmanship at work here. The semi-aniline leather was developed especially for the LP720-4 and preserves the material’s natural grain and textures. A special diamond stitch pattern was also introduced for this model, a further celebration of the fine Italian craftsmanship at work.

Exterior tweaks to this special Aventador include performance-oriented changes to the front and rear fascias, which will also help careful observers distinguish this triumph of machinery from Lamborghini’s more run-of-the-mill masterpieces.
No word on price, but if you have to ask…and the 100 customers who will be able to buy this limited edition most certainly don't.

pageElements.text:
2013 Nissan Quest 3.5 LE


Vital Stats

Pricing: The Quest 3.5 LE is the top-of-the-line model and reflects a $16,650 premium over the base 2013 Quest 3.5 S. The base 2013 Quest 3.5 S starts at $26,815, including destination. All of the Quest models are equipped with the same powertrain, a 3.5-liter V-6 engine linked to a continuously variable transmission. This Quest is priced at $43,675, including shipping, and includes one option: $210 carpeted floor mats for all rows.
EPA fuel economy: 19 mpg city/25 mpg highway. The 2013 Chrysler Town & Country with a 3.6-liter V-6 and six-speed automatic transmission returns 17/25 mpg, the 2013 Honda Odyssey with 3.5-liter V-6 and six-speed automatic transmission returns 19/28 mpg, and the 2013 Toyota Sienna with a 3.5-liter V-6 and six-speed automatic transmission returns 18/25 mpg.
Standard safety features: Six airbags, stability control, traction control, child safety rear door locks. This LE also includes standard Around View monitor and advanced blind-spot warning (via a warning indicator light on side mirrors). Both are new for 2013.
Chief competitors: Honda Odyssey (top EX-L Touring Elite is $44,855), Toyota Sienna (top Limited model is $45,055), Chrysler Town & Country (top Limited model is $41,740)
<iframe width="420" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/T3rB7HRZWuM" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Key Points

- Sorry, Quest. The 2014 Honda Odyssey Touring Elite just introduced a major minivan game changer with the first-ever built-in vacuum in a minivan.
- Nissan has aimed the Quest at “the woman behind the mom.” During a media presentation in 2004, it flashed a picture of Marion Cunningham, the sweet but frumpy mom on the old TV sitcom Happy Days, with a slash across her face, and said the Quest isn't for women like her.
- The Quest has been set apart as the radical design alternative in the minivan category.
- Let’s talk practicality. If your family is large, the Quest only seats seven passengers. The Odyssey and Sienna (depending on trim level) can seat up to eight.
- Quest also has less cargo capacity than most of its rivals.
- On the plus side, Quest has a modern, upscale and sophisticated cabin and a relative rarity among minivans – a standard push-button start. The LE model also includes a thirteen-speaker Bose sound system, a third-row power return seatback, and a DVD entertainment system. (The DVD system is standard on this model but a $2,100 option on other Quest models; buyers will also pay $1,350 extra for a dual-opening glass moonroof, available only on SL and LE models.)
- Rear visibility from the driver’s seat is not great.
- Some entertainment and climate controls are blocked by the gearshift lever.
- Smooth ride, but it tends to lean in corners (may cause carsickness in some kids!).
- Six cupholders and six bottle holders. Sienna has twelve cupholders, plus front and rear door map pockets with bottle holders. The top-of-the-line Odyssey Touring Elite has total of fifteen beverage holders.

title: Horseless Carriages in Central Park?
subTitle: Would you go on a romantic EV ride?
promoTeaserSmall: Would you go on a romantic EV ride?
promoTeaser: Electric cars that look like 1909 Pierce-Arrows could replace horses, if animal rights groups win the day.
metaKeywords: Horse and Carriage Association of New York City
metaDescription: Horseless Carriages in Central Park? Animal rights groups are helping fund a prototype of an electric car to replace the horse-drawn carriage. It's controversial, like most issues in New York City. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I don’t understand people who dislike driving. I really don't. The freedom of getting behind the wheel of a car and just taking off can't be compared with anything else. You really feel that you’re in charge: in charge of the car, in charge of the road, and in charge of your life. Why on earth would you want someone else to drive you around when you could do it yourself? It’s so liberating! Obviously, I love driving. I suppose that isn't a particularly original statement for a Detroit native, but it's true. I was a little late getting my driver's license because of that pesky parallel parking, but once I got it, nothing could stop me. It doesn't matter if I have to chauffeur my grandmother to the bank less than a block from our house or drive across town. If I have my green Chrysler LHS--affectionately christened "Betsy" by my mother--and some gas in the tank, and if I am somehow able to avoid getting pulled over for driving just a little too fast, I'm good to go.

Since I graduated from the University of Michigan, in April 2012, Betsy has taken me everywhere. She has been my steadfast companion on trips to buy more supplies for various sewing projects, leisurely drives along Jefferson/Lakeshore Drive in Grosse Pointe Shores, Michigan, and frequent jaunts to the bookstore to buy yet another copy of Hamlet, a 500-plus-page book on Elizabeth I, or a good book on British history that isn’t as dry as a piece of chalk…And, yes, there is a little bit of theme there. Not only am I a bibliophile, but I’m also a self-proclaimed Anglophile who loves Shakespeare and Elizabethan verse and one day plans to see the Houses of Parliament, visit the Tower of London, and, perhaps most important, eat real fish and chips. If only I could drive Betsy "across the pond…"

pageElements.text: Taking a nice, leisurely drive through Central Park in a horse-drawn carriage is a longstanding tradition, but if a certain New York-based animal welfare nonprofit gets its way, that tradition will be changing.

In late April, New Yorkers for Clean, Livable, and Safe Streets (NYCLASS) signed a contract with Jason Wenig, founder and president of The Creative Workshop, a coachbuilding and restoration firm in Florida, to build a full-scale prototype of an all-electric, seven-passenger horseless carriage. He's calling it the Eco-Carriage.

“Even though passengers will feel like they are being transmitted to the Gatsby era, the electric car will have cutting-edge battery and EV technology and many ergonomic and safety features not found on the horse-drawn carriages or the original cars for that matter,” Wenig said. “Not to mention, it can hold more passengers than the carriages and is outfitted and amenable to all types of weather.”

This Is a Big Controversy If You Live in New York City

Although Wenig’s car, inspired by a 1909 Pierce-Arrow and a 1909 Packard, isn't exactly Jay Gatsby's 1920s-era Rolls-Royce, NYCLASS has been petitioning the New York City Council to approve a pilot program that will run the prototype through Central Park along the carriage route. NYCLASS has been agitating for changes to city regulations that would increase safety and animal protection for the 220 horses that pull carriages—mostly without success so far. NYCLASS is a five-year-old organization that has the support of the ASPCA, which has long opposed putting horses to work inside the city. The group also claims support for its goal, getting rid of horse-drawn carriages, from a coalition of animal rescue groups, PETA, and more than half of the city council members, including Melissa Mark-Viverito (D-Manhattan), who has sponsored legislation offering an alternative to horse-drawn carriages.

According to NYCLASS and the ASPCA, carriage horses are to be pitied. They work for at least nine hours every day while inhaling exhaust fumes and navigating streets choked with cars and buses. Because horses are generally unaccustomed to urban life, they can become scared quite easily by traffic noise and congestion and have been known to cause accidents, endangering coachmen, pedestrians, other drivers, and themselves. Replacing the carriages with turn-of-the-century-inspired EVs, they say, could reduce the number of horse-related accidents in the city and improve the quality of life for both horses and humans, all while retaining the romance of a carriage ride.

However, Mayor Bloomberg himself is against the idea, and in that he's joined by the Horse and Carriage Association of New York City (naturally), whose employees are represented by Teamsters Local 553, as well as the politically ambitious speaker of the city council, Christine Quinn.

But How Do The Horses Feel about It?

If the proposal succeeds, the horses would be out of a job, but they wouldn't have to fear the glue factory: NYCLASS and the ASPCA declare they'll find "retirement homes" for every horse.

“[Our] objective is the well-being of the horses,” said Bret Hopman, senior media and communications manager for the ASPCA. “While we welcome regulations that would improve their well-being while they're on the streets, we ultimately view the provisions outlined in [Councilwoman Mark-Viverito’s] legislation that calls for a phase-out of horse carriages in New York City, replacing them with electric-powered classic cars, as the best approach, because they address the economic, environmental, and quality of life interests of the horses as well as the people.”

In addition to the political complexities of legislating the horses out of Central Park, a major obstacle to the horseless-carriage plan would be cost: the pilot program would cost $450,000 for just one prototype car. NYCLASS intends to pay this cost, but so far, there has been no word on a financial plan beyond that.
