pageElements.text: Mercedes-Benz Financial Services employees are doing community projects in Detroit all this week in an initiative called “Week of Caring.” The employees are wearing T-shirts labeled ROI, for Return on Involvement, and they’re spreading out to charities, including Habitat for Humanity homes, the American Red Cross, the Community Food Bank, Greening of Detroit tree-planting efforts, and even a local elementary school.

This is an annual event for the financial arm of Mercedes-Benz, and it’s not limited to Detroit: more than 1,000 employees in five countries across the continent are working for a total of thirty-five nonprofits. The other major U.S. effort is in Fort Worth, Texas.

Employees at Mercedes-Benz Financial Services get to work with other employees in their departments once a year, as well as another day of their choice, for a charity they choose, that is offered as a paid personal holiday. These photos are from the Mercedes-Benz Financial Services Facebook page. Visit the page for more images of their work.

Mercedes is not alone in organizing a charity-oriented week for employees. To name just two, Ford ran its seventh annual community service week last September, and General Motors’ inaugural teamGM Cares week of charity work also took place last September. It’s great to see a big company reaching out into the community in this way.

title: 2014 Mercedes-Benz Sprinter
subTitle: New look for the long tall European
promoTeaserSmall: You don't have to need one to like this multitalented vehicle (or fantasize how you'd modify it).
promoTeaser: You don't have to need one to like this multitalented vehicle (or fantasize how you'd modify it).
metaDescription: 2014 Mercedes-Benz Sprinter has been updated and refreshed. Now you can get navigation! Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: We greeted the news of an all-new 2014 Mercedes-Benz Sprinter with more than casual interest. We don’t like to use the word “empowerment” too much around here, but when a vehicle is this capable and still has a veneer of German-automaker chic on it, we’ve got to admit it’s likeable.

Perhaps you aren’t in the habit of carrying eleven people, or big stacks of full sheets of plywood, or all the equipment and supplies of a small business. You’ve still got to admire the can-do spirit couched in Mercedes luxury that is a Sprinter van. I mean, really, doesn’t it make you want to start some kind of dog grooming service or florist shop, just so you have an excuse to own one of these?

And, as it happens, a million people around the world have found a reason to buy a Sprinter. True, most of them aren’t in the United States, but just wait. As Claus Tritt, general manager of commercial vehicles, freely admitted, speaking of the Sprinter’s run in North America, “We were the oddball for more than ten years; now we’re the benchmark.” Now that rival vans are coming onto the market such as Nissan’s NV and the upcoming full-size Ford Transit and Ram ProMaster, the European-style tall-roof van will become a little more common on U.S. streets.

Changes for 2014

With the new model’s debut—it goes on sale in early September—Mercedes-Benz has added a four-cylinder BlueTec diesel engine, mated to a seven-speed automatic transmission, that should be popular around town as a money saver. With it, fuel economy is expected to be up eighteen percent. You can still get a V-6 BlueTec diesel, but now it’s optional. On the inside, there's an audio system with a 5.8-inch screen, an optional navigation system that lives in the glove compartment, and a new seat design.

It’s not only the three-pointed star that will remind you that you are driving a Mercedes; you can get the famed Mercedes-Benz safety systems on the 2014 Sprinter: collision prevention, lane keeping, blind spot, and high-beam assistance systems, and the segment-exclusive load adaptive control, which detects if your load is shifting. And, starting at just over $40,000 for the passenger van (2013 model prices; the 2014 prices won't be announced until closer to launch), it’s a pretty affordable vehicle for what you get.

Now if you want to go north of $40,000 and way north of utility, there are eighty-five companies licensed as Preferred Upfitters for the Mercedes-Benz Sprinter. As an example of the kinds of customization you can get, Mercedes showed us a passenger van transformed by Midwest Automotive Designs Corp., which made a fully Kardashian-worthy limousine out of the Sprinter that would cost around $150,000 (Sprinter included). If you choose to have a Sprinter upfitted, Mercedes-Benz will handle all the arrangements through a specialized Sprinter dealer. “The dealer will make it happen for you,” Mercedes promises. Three-quarters of Sprinter purchasers take advantage of that opportunity, whether to get specialized work equipment, wheelchair lifts,  or to turn the Sprinter into an ambulance or a luxury camper.

Not ready to buy a Sprinter of your own? Play with this design program for fun. Or enjoy looking at the Sprinter's ancestor (right) the truly adorable 1955 Mercedes-Benz L319, which makes a delightful contrast to the sleek 2014 model. It made an invigorating 40 horsepower but got the job done. There are wood slats across the cargo area in the back, perfect for sliding in your wood crates of Gewurtztraminer wine. That's some work heritage to be proud of.

pageElements.text:
If you haven't already, you can get up to speed by reading Part One. Okay, ready?

Thursday Afternoon

This is the day when we just sit and wait. The start is tonight at 8:30. Right now, it's pouring rain, and I'm sitting next to Gina Lollobrigida. But I digress. Here's what has happened so far.

The Welcome Dinner

Last night, Mercedes-Benz threw a giant welcome dinner for its team: fifteen cars, including ours, supported by about forty people. Mercedes has rented out the Museo Mille Miglia, and the museum store has actual Ferrari engine heads for sale. It has an original Mille Miglia scarf from around 1950 that you can get for about 1,500 euros. There’s another one from the 1960 Mille Miglia that's silk, priced over 2,000 euros. Original posters for sale! Reproductions, too. I just love it.

For dinner, all the drivers sat at a long table, and all the support staff filled the museum around the drivers’ table. David Coulthard is proving to be very funny, very nice, and very friendly. Jochen Mass is a total joker. He's a riot. Karl Wendlinger is very serious. We haven’t seen him smile once in two days.

By the time they were getting ready to serve the meat course, we were full and finished in every way. Team USA, with our faces inches from the plate, decided it was better to leave. We repaired to our rooms, and I hit the hay and woke up at 7:30 a.m. without having moved once. The other American members of the team reported doing the same.

We Consider Ourselves Warned

This morning, we gathered at the Fiera di Brescia, a giant open exposition center where all the cars were and where the tech inspection took place. Steve Cannon and I took out our #303 Mercedes 300SL and drove around in the parking lot. We needed to get used to the very bad feeling of drum brakes, which I remember from 1970. I'd forgotten just how bad the brakes were.
We kept telling ourselves over and over again: As you’re driving with these brakes, you’ll get used to them. They'll feel really good. You have to remember to pump.

Next we had a personal seminar from one of the mechanics. He told us, “Every Gullwing is different. There's a row of switches and buttons that are not labeled at all. They’re fuel, and interior lights, and fuel pump, and heater. There’s also a hidden one that will release air from underneath the dash and blow cold air. This is very important because this Gullwing has an exhaust system running underneath the floorboard, so on a really hot day your tennis shoes will get very tacky, because the floorboard gets so hot.”
Not on a day like today, when it's cold and rainy. We feel like winners as we watch other people in open cars driving in the pouring rain, looking just miserable.

Jochen Mass Lends His Perspective

We did notice, however, that the windshield wipers were at about eye level on their upward motion. They didn't seem to get much higher than halfway up the windshield. So I corralled Jochen Mass and asked him, “How many of these have you been on?” He flashed his fingers through the air. Five, ten, so many times I couldn’t count, and he laughed. I asked him, “What’s the most important thing to worry about: the windshield wipers or the brakes?” He said, “Both. The windshield wipers are here [putting his hand horizontally across the bridge of his nose], so you have to brake differently.”

I'm pretty sure that what he meant is, neither one of them is exactly perfect. I can’t tell you how many times one of the mechanics has already come up and said things like, “The brakes will be very bad. The tires will be like driving in snow. Please be very careful.”
I’ve already decided that if I crash this million-dollar car, I'm planning to die in the wreck. I won't want to come home and face the music.

Auspicious Beginning for the Navigator

An hour later, we were suddenly called to our cars by the team and told to go to the Piazza della Loggia in Brescia. We jumped into our cars and lined up to go. Steve was driving. I opened my route book, and it's at that point I realized we had no directions. None.

We followed the cars in front of us. Within minutes we lost the car in front of us. That's when I pulled out the beautiful Mercedes-Benz map and realized it was no use to us, because they put the symbol for where we needed to be across the map in such a way that it completely obscured the names of the streets. We were somewhere in the city of Brescia, but where? Great start for this navigator who was so highly touted by everyone from Stirling Moss to herself.
Steve noticed a sign for Centro, so we decided, that's it. Go for the center and look for the castle. I said to Steve, “We track like guided missiles. Actually more like scuds.”

We wandered around. Another Gullwing was following us, which we thought was hilarious. We found a cop who couldn't speak English but gave us the idea that we had to turn right three lights up and look for a street. Then we saw another cop. She took one look at our car, then pointed everyone else to the left and us to the right. Suddenly, we found ourselves in a line of cars going where we needed to go.

We Felt as Important as Any Movie Star or Formula 1 Driver

The streets were mobbed, despite pouring rain and gusting wind so strong that there was a stack of inside-out, broken umbrellas at every corner trash can. Some guy off to my right was yelling, “Attenzione! Attenzione!” I turned around, and it was an old guy, who said, “Buona Giornata!” He was just trying to get our attention so he could wish us a good day.

Once you're going slowly, the car gets a little hot and steamy with the rain coming down and the exhaust heating up. We opened the gull wings and were driving slowly with the doors open. Some kid put his head into the car. We couldn’t quite understand what he was saying, and then we realized he was asking: "David Coulthard? Karl Wendlinger?” And he took our picture.

Then We Met True Italian Royalty

They put a sort of zip tie around the steering wheel shaft of the car. We entered the incredibly ornate opera house in Brescia, the Teatro Grande, which has a ceiling that resembles the Sistine Chapel. The SLR Club, the whole team, and all the drivers were there. But everyone bowed down to Gina Lollobrigida, who is eighty-five and has not a line on her face.
We had our team photo taken inside the opera house. I just saw Aida in Detroit last Sunday, so I was especially excited to see an original poster for Madama Butterfly, which opened here in 1904.

Ready to Start

Any minute now, we’re going to get in our cars and head back to the museum. The start is at 8:30 tonight.

We’re not nervous at all. Steve is the nicest guy in the world: really calm, really excited, comfortable driving in the rain. Also, the only person I’ve met who drinks as much coffee as I do. He keeps talking about bucket lists; I think he’s already overflowed his.
The story continues tomorrow!

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: New cars these days—even entry-level models—come packed with technology that would have been downright luxurious five years ago. That's all well and good for people who are in a position to buy or lease a new car. But what if you're still making payments on a car you bought just before sleek touchscreens and satellite radio made their way onto standard equipment lists?

As usual, the aftermarket electronics folks are here to save the day. Whether it's a full-on navigation and stereo system or just a stand to give your hands a rest from holding your iPad, there are gadgets that can improve your driving experience without (totally) breaking the bank.

In-Dash Navigation and Stereo

If you're ready to make a serious upgrade, or if you’re just sick of using your phone as a map, you can spring for an in-dash setup that will make you forget that you're not driving a brand-new car. A number of different companies make these systems (an Alpine system is shown at right), but, essentially, all have the same features: a color screen that combines navigation, stereo, Bluetooth, and a CD/DVD player. All are priced around $800, and all require professional installation. Some of the systems will allow drivers to hook up phones and use Pandora or other Internet radio apps. Some can be paired with aftermarket backup cameras, and many include auxiliary jacks or USB inputs to allow you to listen to an iPod or other music player while driving. Best Buy sells a full complement of the systems and offers installation services from the Geek Squad.

Portable Navigation

For drivers on smaller budgets, there is a seemingly endless supply of portable GPS systems that can get you where you’re going for a modest price. You can find a portable navigation system like the Magellan at right for less than $100, and even the low-end models often have features like lifetime map updates and Bluetooth connectivity. More expensive models add features like traffic information, Wi-Fi capability, and even weather updates. Garmin, Magellan, and TomTom all offer affordable systems that can solve your navigation woes.

Rear DVD Player

At Jean Knows Cars, we’re big believers in actually spending time with your family when you’re in the car together, but there’s no denying that a DVD break can keep everyone sane during long rides. If your car didn’t come with rear entertainment, a couple hundred dollars can get you a overhead or headrest-mounted DVD player (with headphone jacks, in case you don’t want to listen to Finding Nemo for the thousandth time). Overhead screens tend to be larger but are not necessarily more expensive. A couple of headrest-mounted screens (like the Audiovox example at right) with built-in DVD players can help avoid the inevitable fights that will come when siblings are asked to agree on a single movie.

Tablet Mount

If you don’t have a DVD player in your car, chances are your passengers are using iPhones or iPads to entertain themselves in the car during lulls in conversation. Whether they’re playing games or watching Phineas and Ferb on Netflix, tablets and smartphones are easily accessible entertainment options that you probably already own. So why spend $200 for a DVD player when you can just download a movie on a device you already own? If your family is maxed out on screens, consider a headrest-mounted tablet holder instead, which will keep that multi-hundred-dollar touchscreen away from your kids’ gooey little hands and prevent the hunchback position many of us assume when staring at phones in the car. Best of all, a tablet mount can be had for less than $40, making it the cheapest upgrade on this list.
Are infotainment upgrades on your wish list, or are you and your ride happily behind the times? Let us know in the comments below!

pageElements.text: Chevrolet’s mid-size sedan, the Malibu, is getting a redesign for 2014. It might not look much different on the outside, but Chevrolet is counting on interior and powertrain improvements to have customers flocking to dealerships.

The Malibu sits above Chevrolet’s pocket-size starter cars, the Spark and the Sonic, and the slightly roomier Cruze in the Chevrolet lineup. The new ’Bu has been tweaked to offer a roomier interior, greater efficiency, and new safety features.

image.altText: chevrolet malibu gets a face lift

pageElements.text: The Malibu gets a revised front end for 2014 that's intended to make it look more like a sibling to the big 2014 Chevrolet Impala. The Impala will also lend suspension enhancements to the Malibu, contributing to what Chevrolet describes as a “more refined” ride. Reshaped front seats will make room for a whole 1.25 inches of extra knee space for rear passengers, and a longer center console will have space for two cups and storage space for two cell phones.

In addition to the currently available rearview camera, desirable new-tech safety features on the 2014 Malibu include side blind zone alert and rear cross traffic safety alert, both of which are optional.

But the most significant changes for the new Malibu will come under the hood. The standard engine for the 2014 Malibu will be an all-new 2.5-liter Ecotec engine that makes 196 horsepower. Using start/stop technology and intake valve lift control, the 2014 Malibu will eke out an extra mile per gallon in both city and highway driving over last year’s model, earning 23 mpg in town and 35 mpg on the highway. Updates to the Malibu’s available 2.0-liter turbocharged powerplant will add fourteen percent more torque to that 259-horsepower engine.
Look for the 2014 Malibu to hit dealer showrooms this fall.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: New Yorkers with a love for aluminum, SUVs, and art: please report to the meatpacking district. Land Rover and Architectural Digest have teamed up to create a popup architectural installation to celebrate the 2013 Range Rover. It will only be displayed from June 7 to June 9, so procrastinators are sure to miss out.

I fell in love with large outdoor sculptures when my design class from Northern Michigan University took a trip to Chicago. I had never been to the Windy City, and I remember the feeling of walking around the enormous Pablo Picasso sculpture titled The Chicago Picasso, Alexander Calder’s Flamingo, Jean Dubuffet’s Monument with Standing Beast, and Joan Miró’s Miró’s Chicago. The massive size of the sculptures with the architectural backdrop of Chicago made the experience magical. Land Rover’s project goes after the same aesthetic of mixing architecture and design on a large scale.

Architectural Digest selected the architectural firm HWKN, whose founders, Matthias Hollwich and Marc Kushner, developed more than fifty concepts to present to Land Rover. They immersed themselves in the Range Rover to draw inspiration. The aluminum of the Range Rover’s body became a muse to the designers and played a significant role in the direction of the design.
“We were inspired by the assembly, form, and performance of the 2013 Range Rover, and that dictated everything we did,” Hollwich said.

“The design of the vehicle itself is so rooted in architecture, and we wanted to translate that DNA into our installation,” Kushner said. “At the same time, we wanted to convey how strong—yet light—the all-aluminum vehicle structure is.”

Ultimately, Land Rover selected Climbing Up as the winner. The design incorporates a series of aluminum plates and the vehicle seemingly floats at a 45-degree angle. Kim McCullough, brand vice president at Land Rover North America, commented, “This spectacular public art installation speaks to the physical properties of high-strength aluminum, as well as the design aesthetic of the 2013 Range Rover, and we're excited to see how it draws attention and discussion to our next-generation Range Rover.”

Visitors to the installation will be encouraged to interact with the exhibit through social media, including Instagram, and their feedback will be shared on flat-screen monitors embedded within the structure.

In a world literally awash with vehicles—from rusty cars that have lived bland, useful lives to rock stars like the Range Rover—we rarely stop and take a 360-degree view of these works of art that dozens of designers painstakingly create for us. Even if we will never get to call this luxury barge our own, we can still appreciate it as a rolling work of art.

The installation premieres on June 7 at the intersection of Ninth Avenue and West Fourteenth Street in Manhattan. The installation will be open to the public from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. on Friday, June 7, and Saturday, June 8, and from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. on Sunday, June 9.

metaDescription: Meet Heather Sager, a member of the Jean Knows Cars Group of Seven reader panel, and read some of her thoughts on life with cars. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Heather, age 37, is a born-and-bred Ann Arbor resident. She makes her living as a salesperson for Sysco Corporation. She leases a 2012 Lexus CT200h, but her dream car is a Bugatti Veyron.
“I saw it at the auto show and went crazy for it,” she says of the Veyron.

Heather attended Eastern Michigan University and studied art appreciation and business. Her family includes her four-year-old son, Sebastian, and one dog, a Borzoi named Boris. Heather loves fashion, but also enjoys painting and making jewelry (she has a jewelry business called Mabella), listening to music, and gardening.
These are her thoughts on auto-related issues:

Distracted Driving/Texting while Driving: “This is an important issue for me because I get called while driving constantly. I have Bluetooth, but I do not text while driving. I’m not allowed (corporate regulations).

“I drive in Ann Arbor and [drivers] are crazy! They run stop signs all the time. I’m scared about bad driving. I’ve seen my kid go after a ball in the street. I’m trying to teach him not to run in the street. I’m worried that somebody might not notice him if they are texting.

“I think it’s good that the feds want to limit distractions in cars. From what I can see with myself, I’m getting e-mails in the car, and it’s hard not to look at them. The radio is on—it’s all a distraction. I’m in the car a lot, and it’s nerve-wracking. When you get an e-mail that’s cryptic, your mind goes to that. My mind can be on other things besides driving. I’m trying not to be a distracted driver, but it’s hard. I’d be lying if I said I wasn’t distracted.”

Auto Styling: “I think it’s come a long way, and it’s getting better and better. I’m only drawn to certain cars. I only like cars that are styled sleekly. A minivan has no draw for me. I’m drawn to the fashion of the car. My dad has always driven Infinitis or Lexuses, so I like a lot of foreign cars. I like a lot of the hybrids because they are smaller and fashioned sleekly. The Fords have more styling to them. I like Mini Coopers. I like small cars; I feel like they are better for the environment. The green movement is appealing to me.”

Gas Prices: “They don’t faze me that much because I have a hybrid. But I was paying $25 to fill up in October, and now I’m paying $29 to $30. I’m not as upset as other people because I don’t burn through as much gas.”

Technology/Autonomous Driving: “I think a self-driving car would concern me. I’d be e-mailing and texting, and that’s scary. I don’t know how a car could be completely in control. But maybe they’ll be safer. [The automakers] would have a big job in convincing me the cars are safe.”

Electric/Alt-Fuel Vehicles: “I love that. I think it’s amazing. I think it’s the direction that we need to go in. I’m willing. It’s something I started thinking about when I became a mom. I think about the future for my son and his generation being dependent on foreign oil. I’d be willing to pay the price for green technology. Absolutely.

“My car is not cheap to lease or buy [because it's a hybrid], but it’s better for the environment. I probably drive ten miles a day, and I wanted to go to a hatchback to have a smaller car. The cars I looked at included the Ford Fiesta hatchback. I could have leased it for $165 a month. I pay $400 a month for my Lexus because of the hybrid system. It’s a better-made car. It’s very presumptuous of me to think people with big families and one income would look at hybrids, but it’s something they should look at. It’s all about what you value.”

pageElements.text: Good news for people who own both General Motors vehicles and smartphones: General Motors announced Wednesday that it will make certain features from OnStar’s smartphone app, RemoteLink, standard and free for five years. Included are thirty-six 2014 Buick, Cadillac, Chevrolet, and GMC models equipped with OnStar. Owners of compatible vehicles will be able to lock and unlock their cars, start them remotely, and engage and disengage the alarm with the touch of a smartphone screen.

Free Remote Access Is Good

GM says the RemoteLink app already has more than 320,000 regular users. The company receives roughly 60,000 remote unlocking requests per month. The automaker hopes that making remote access features standard will make life just a little bit easier for their customers. As long as users have a cell phone or wireless Internet connection, they can use the RemoteLink app to connect with their vehicle, even from far away. No more running back to the car from the restaurant to make sure it’s locked—just open up the app and lock it remotely.

OnStar Plans Still Cost, Though

Free access to these basic functions is a new perk for GM customers. Use of the RemoteLink app costs current users $18.95 per month as part of OnStar’s Safe and Sound plan, which also includes vehicle diagnostics, emergency services, and roadside assistance, among other features. For the $28.90-per-month Directions and Connections plan, subscribers can get access to all of the Safe and Sound plan’s services, plus turn-by-turn navigation.
Drivers will still need to pay a subscription fee if they want access to OnStar’s full suite of features. RemoteLink is available for free from the App Store, Google Play, and BlackBerry App World.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: The Porsche 911 is a gorgeous automobile. But is it practical? That's a question you might not be asking. But we did. Back in 2011, Automobile Magazine tested the everyday usability of a Porsche 911 (in the spirit of Porsche's ad campaign "Porsche Everyday"), seeing how much we could get done with it in twenty-four hours. It made a great story and an even better video as the black-on-black 911 Carrera GTS was used for errands, golf outings, and to drive out to the riding stable. Personally, I filled it to the brim with flowers and was amazed at how many I could get in there.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/w-dLEBljNvc?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

For this Jean's Driveway review of the 2013 Porsche 911 Carrera S, I invited the three most white-hot auto enthusiast members of my Group of Seven to review it with me: Anna Eby, Val Luepke, and Heather Sager. Did they love the yellow Porsche? What do you think?

Vital Stats

Base price: $97,350 (includes destination)
This car’s price: $144,350 (includes destination). Among the many options are a black leather interior ($3,330), Premium Package Plus with eighteen-way seats ($6,155), sport suspension ($4,050), Porsche PDK seven-speed transmission ($4,080), Burmester audio package ($5,010), Sport Chrono package ($2,370), sport exhaust system ($2,950), ceramic composite brakes ($8520), and a SportDesign steering wheel ($490); on the list of options exclusive to this model are painted air vents ($1,710), racing yellow seatbelts ($540), leather-backed Sport Seats Plus ($1,870), painted center console trim ($290), plus a special painted vehicle key in the color and shape of the car ($335)
EPA fuel economy: 19 mpg city/27 mpg highway
Safety features: eight airbags, including knee airbags; stability control, Hill Hold
Tech features: The world's first seven-speed manual transmission in a passenger car; Auto Start/Stop technology shuts off the engine at stoplights; lightweight body with doors, hood, and roof made of aluminum, all in the name of fuel efficiency
Chief competitors: Chevrolet Corvette Stingray (base price $51,995), Nissan GT-R (base price $100,590), Audi R8 (base price $116,150) (all prices are for 2014 models and include destination)

Key Points

• Porsche is the number-one-selling brand of sports car in the world
• How fast is this car? you ask. Zero to 60 mph in 4.6 seconds; top track speed of 179 mph
• Fascinating factoid: No Porsche, including this one, made the EPA’s list of 2013 Least Fuel Efficient Cars. The Bugatti Veyron topped the list with 10 mpg combined. The list also includes the Chevrolet Camaro, Cadillac CTS wagon, and Ferrari FF
• Cool touch: exhaust button that allows exhaust sound to be funneled directly into cabin
• Purists will like retention of traditional five-gauge array on dash
• Sport Mode is now standard on 911. It adjusts the engine’s response to suit your driving style
• This car has a Sport Chrono package, which adjusts the engine and transmission for high-performance driving. The package includes a stopwatch mounted on the dashboard that shows lap distance, individual lap times, lap number and total driving time
• Porsche Entry & Drive feature lets you keep key in your purse to start car
• A recent demographic study (TrueCar, April 23, 2012) found that the car purchased by the highest majority of men was the Porsche 911. The car with the highest percentage of female buyers was the Volvo S40. Porsche statistics consistently show that the overwhelming majority of 911 buyers are men (around 90 percent) with an average age of fifty-one and a median income approaching $400,000. Porsche has described these men as “determined,” i.e., they made up their minds a long time ago that they would have a 911 when they reached a certain stage of life
• Porsche has not gone after women in any noticeable way. However, Porsche's ad agency surveyed kindergarteners in San Francisco about ten years ago and asked them to draw their dream car. Nearly every child drew a red convertible. Porsche considered it a major win since these kids would aspire to own a Porsche when they grew up

I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Pretty big week in Ann Arbor, following Sebastien Vettel’s decisive Formula 1 win in Montreal last Sunday—his first win at that circuit after several attempts, and his third win this season. If you don’t follow Formula 1 racing like I don’t follow Formula 1 racing, you’ll have many questions, as I did. First of all, why was it a big day in Ann Arbor? Well, because he came here to the Automobile Magazine/Jean Knows Cars offices to give us an interview. The list of questions was the subject of intense back and forth between Vettel’s Red Bull Racing team handlers and our editors.

They wanted to vet all Vettel questions and, of course, we said no. We wanted to ask our readers and Facebook fans what they wanted to know from him. This was not necessarily anything that he’d want to answer.

The first question might be, why should anybody care about Sebastian Vettel? Who is he? He’s a slightly built, curly-haired German kid, twenty-five years old, who has won the last three Formula 1 championships in a row. He is dominating the points lead after seven races out of nineteen, with a major lead (see below) of thirty-six points on his nearest competitor, Ferrari’s Fernando Alonso from Spain.

The next question might be, why is the team called Red Bull Racing-Renault when he was coming to see us was in his new role as Infiniti’s performance director? Well, it goes like this: Renault owns Nissan, and Infiniti is part of Nissan.  The engines are from Renault, which has been in Formula 1 racing for a long, long time. Infiniti is trying to become a bigger entity in Europe, and Formula 1 racing is the number-one automotive billboard for the rest of the world outside the United States. So it makes sense that Infiniti would buy into a sponsorship of the team and Vettel to amp up its presence.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/c6G3IvGcgfM" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

You might wonder why they wanted to vet our interview questions. Why would they care? Because Vettel’s first win this year, in Malaysia, came at the closing moments of the race when the driver separating him from his teammate, Mark Weber, who was running in first place, dropped out. Vettel then ignored team orders, passed Weber, and won the race. He later apologized, but the die was cast, and the fans have been unruly ever since. In fact, when he won in Canada, he was booed loudly by the crowd. We actually did ask him about his reception after the Canadian race. He rightfully pointed out the huge number of Ferrari fans and said he was encouraged by the increasing number of blue-hatted Red Bull fans in the crowd. Watch the video for the answers to this and other questions from our Facebook fans and readers.
Then he was gone, leaving behind a big stack of Red Bull/Infiniti hats with a big, fat number 1 on each bill.

title: 2013 Hyundai Sonata Hybrid Limited
subTitle: Should you buy this car?

promoTeaser: I like its dynamic looks; driving it didn't thrill me. But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
metaDescription: 2013 Hyundai Sonata Hybrid Limited: Should you buy it? Here's what we think. Read our review on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $32,490 as tested (including destination charge) 
Engine: 2.4-liter DOHC four-cylinder, 159 horsepower
Electric Motor: Permanent magnet synchronous, 47 horsepower, 199 total system horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic 
Fuel economy: 36 mpg city/40 mpg highway
My favorite standard features: Heated front and rear seats, SiriusXM satellite radio (three-month trial subscription)
Option I can’t live without: Panoramic sunroof ($1,000)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Volt, Ford Fusion Hybrid, Kia Optima Hybrid, Toyota Camry Hybrid
See more specs in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

Hybrids have come a long way since the first Honda Insight and Toyota Prius graced our shores. No longer total niche vehicles, there are now hybrid versions of everything from the Cadillac Escalade to the Porsche Panamera. If you’re looking for a green machine that falls somewhere in between a massive family hauler and a six-figure performance sedan, the Hyundai Sonata Hybrid is worth a look.

I drove a Sonata Hybrid Limited around town last week and was impressed by the sedan’s upscale leather interior and dynamic exterior styling. The seats were wide and comfortable, and there was plenty of room in the back seat for extra passengers. The optional panoramic sunroof is pricey at $1,000, but it gives the cabin a more spacious feeling.

This car’s hybrid system means that it gets stellar fuel economy ratings, especially in city driving, where it earns 36 mpg. The Sonata Hybrid can operate in electric vehicle (EV) mode for short periods at speeds of up to 75 mph. The transition is fairly smooth from EV mode (when the car is powered only by its battery) to normal driving powered by the internal combustion engine. You can feel the engine kick in if you’re paying attention, but you could easily miss it if you aren't.

The Sonata Hybrid isn’t exactly thrilling to drive, but it has enough power on tap for drama-free passing on the highway, thanks to the combined efforts of the gasoline engine and the electric motor.
 
If you want to keep tabs on how efficiently you’re driving, the driver information display can tell you how green you’re being. You can choose from several different displays, including a real-time representation of which source (engine or electric motor) is powering the wheels, a somewhat confusing eco score tally (you earn points for green driving and are rewarded when plants appear on the display), and a reading of average and immediate miles per gallon.

I mostly relied on the power distribution screen. This showed me that the Sonata was saving fuel by switching to EV mode fairly frequently during normal driving, whenever I allowed the car to coast or applied the brakes (regenerative braking technology has become de rigueur in hybrids). Around town, the car switched to battery power at stoplights and stayed in electric mode under light acceleration.

Perhaps the best news for drivers who have been worried about switching to a hybrid vehicle is Hyundai’s lifetime battery warranty, which will cover the replacement of a failed battery pack at any point in the Sonata Hybrid’s life cycle.

The Verdict:

The 2013 Hyundai Sonata Hybrid Limited gives its drivers the best part of hybrid technology—the ability to sail by gas stations—without asking them to sacrifice looks or comfort. If you're looking for an easy way to increase your range between fill-ups and can learn to work with the Sonata Hybrid's fussy information displays, this could be the car for you.

Peanut Gallery:

Laura: My comments are mainly aesthetic. On the outside, I love the sharp lines along both sides that look like you could slice a piece of cheese on them. On the inside, I don’t love the feeling of sitting down low inside a pod, exacerbated by the swooping front console. But I do appreciate that people who like this kind of car can get one as a hybrid.

Molly: As with all hybrids, the lack of sound when you start the car is disconcerting. I am constantly wondering if the car is started. The steering on the Sonata was very responsive, and the engine was surprisingly peppy, providing a fun driving experience. However, I found the ride harsh and the road noise very loud.

Christina: I wasn't too excited about hybrids until recently. I liked the idea but didn't like how they drove or how they were priced. This car made me want to buy a hybrid. You only know when you're in EV mode when you see the EV indicator light up in the information display; the shift from engine powered driving to EV mode is smooth. The price is reasonable. The interior is comfortable. This car was a pleasant surprise.
Scott: I felt like a cut in the passenger's seat because the interior looks like a giant Band-Aid…however, the drive was the Neosporin. When I got behind the wheel, I was instantly healed.

title: Ford's Thermal Imaging
subTitle: New method made the Fusion quieter
promoTeaserSmall: Heat-seeking: Not just for cops. Ford is using it to make car interiors more soundproof.
promoTeaser: Heat-seeking: Not just for cops. Ford is using it to make car interiors more soundproof.
metaDescription: Ford's Thermal Imaging: Read about how Ford uses the same thermal imaging used by law enforcement, only to find air leaks that cause road noise rather than to catch bad guys. The story is on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Ford is using a new tool in its battle to fight road noise, and while it’s new to the car industry, it will be familiar to watchers of TV crime dramas. Traditionally, auto companies used strategies such as filling a car with smoke and watching for leaks or circling a vehicle with a nonmedical stethoscope to pinpoint pesky air leaks. Instead, Ford is now seeking out weak spots using the same thermal imaging technology that law enforcement and military personnel use to locate criminals.

Ford is using the thermal imaging to identify places where noise or air could leak into or out of a car, leading to increased road noise during driving. In order to check for leaks, Ford pumps test vehicles full of hot air, then trains a thermal camera on them to check for so-called hot spots, areas that show up as red spots on a car’s otherwise blue-green exterior.
Areas most at risk for unwanted noise leakage are moonroofs, window glass, door trim, the trunk lid, doors, and the base of the windshield.

Once weak points have been identified, engineers can take steps to correct the problem. A Ford video shows engineers tacking pieces of padding into the insides of doorframes to better insulate the cabin.

This may seem like an extreme measure to avoid a little road noise, but interior noise levels are no laughing matter to Ford. The company has identified road noise as a key factor in a customer’s perception of quality, so creating a quiet cabin could help improve a car’s overall image. Ford says its 2013 Fusion already has a 67 percent approval rating for interior quietness, compared with 58 percent approval for the 2012 Toyota Camry. And you know that has to give the automaker a nice, warm, insulated feeling.

pageElements.text: July 16 was the ten-year anniversary of an incident in which an eighty-six-year-old man drove through a farmer's market in Santa Monica for hundreds of yards, running down and killing ten people. More than sixty were injured.

In the Melbourne, Australia, area this week, there have been three separate cases in eight days in which elderly drivers have plowed into buildings. Five passers-by were injured, and one of the drivers died.

The AARP says car accidents are the leading cause of injury-related deaths among sixty-five-to-seventy-four-year-olds and the second leading cause (after falls) among seventy-five-to-eighty-four-year-olds.

Now, obviously, these are nightmare scenarios. Most people will be able to drive safely, well into retirement years, without incident. But it's important for everyone to keep tabs on his or her own driving skills and to reevaluate whether any skills are slipping. It's equally important for us to look around at our parents and our older relatives and friends. There are several resources that are intended to help older drivers check up on themselves and thereby, perhaps, postpone as long as possible the day when they can no longer drive.
The AARP has just published a guide for physicians to counsel older patients about driving.

There's also a wealth of information on the AAA Senior Driving website, including a self-evaluation questionnaire available for download. The AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety also has an online tool, Roadwise Review Online, that helps drivers over age sixty-five evaluate their own physical mobility, flexibility, memory, and reaction time.

Tech Can Help

pageElements.text: Newborn Prince of Cambridge, meet another new Brit that’s destined to rule: a 2016 SUV that will join the three existing Bentleys in the lineup. In more welcome news this week for Great Britain, Bentley announced that the company will build the new vehicle at its headquarters in Crewe, England, creating more than 1,000 U.K. jobs, even though Bentley is the property of the Volkswagen Group.

Details on the upcoming SUV were sparse, although VW Group chairman Martin Winterkorn characterized it as “powerful, exclusive, and successful” and “the most luxurious and most powerful SUV in the market.” He also said the Bentley SUV will feature styling that will “set it apart from any other SUV on the road and will be true to the Bentley design DNA.” So you can expect every luxury, and then some.

The Bentley SUV has been talked about for some time, and reportedly some 2,000 people have already pre-ordered the future model. A concept was shown at the 2012 Geneva Auto Show, the EXP 9 F (right). Our friends at our sister publication, Automobile Magazine, say its name is likely to be the Falcon; a V-8 is expected to be standard, with a twin-turbocharged W-12 as an option.

Bentley is far from a mass marketer, having sold 4,279 cars in the first half of 2013, but the Americas are responsible for nearly a quarter of sales, so adding an SUV makes sense. The current model lineup includes the Flying Spur, the Continental, and the Mulsanne.
Are you going to start saving up for a sport-utility Bentley?

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $51,205 as tested (including destination charge) 
Engine: 3.7-liter V-6 
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
  Fuel economy: 18 mpg city/26 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Push-button shift 
Option I can’t live without: Inflatable rear seatbelts  ($195)
You might also be considering: Audi A4, Buick Regal, Cadillac CTS, Lexus ES350 

See more specs on the MKZ in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

It has been almost sixteen years since I have really taken notice of a Lincoln. It was the debut of the Navigator in 1997 that demanded I pay attention. The Navigator was a game changer in the luxury SUV market, and its sales helped catapult Lincoln over Cadillac in annual sales volume. Times have changed. The Lincoln brand has plummeted, and Cadillac is on the upswing in sales. However, Lincoln has repositioned itself as the Lincoln Motor Company, and the new MKZ is poised to give Cadillac a reason to keep its eyes on the rearview mirror.

The MKZ was completely redesigned for 2013, including all-new choices in available engines. The vehicle I tested had the Preferred Equipment group (a $5,330 option), which included nineteen-inch polished aluminum wheels, a rearview camera, navigation, a blind spot information system with cross-traffic alert, rear heated seats, and a THX premium audio system. It also had a jaw-droppingly fabulous retractable panoramic roof ($2,995).

I spent the past week getting to know the MKZ. Every time I drove it, I discovered another feature that made me slowly fall in love. The standard push-button transmission kept me on my toes—I constantly reached for the windshield wiper control stalk as I tried to switch from park to reverse to drive. But with time, I grew fond of the buttons and how they were seamlessly designed into the center console. As always, I enjoyed the ability to shift manually while in sport mode using the paddles behind the steering wheel.

The center console swoops at armrest height between the driver and the front-seat passenger. It incorporates the best-looking, most self-explanatory set of controls that I have seen. The convenience starts with an eight-inch LCD touchscreen for the Sync with MyLincoln Touch system, which is located at the ideal height and distance for the driver. I have heard complaints from fellow automotive journalists about how difficult the MyFord Touch system is to use, but I found the Lincoln version intuitive and user-friendly. I synced my phone easily and enjoyed using the integrated speaker to communicate with my posse. My husband did complain that he couldn’t hear me when the fan was on high, but his audiologist says he is nipping at the need for hearing aids.

The stereo volume and fan speed are controlled by long horizontal bars that you run your finger over to change, and the remaining controls also require just a touch to engage—no knobs here. The open shelf area underneath the center console is genius: it’s lined with a rubbery coating to grab and hold your various accessories.

The exterior styling is unique in the premium mid-size segment. Starting with the split-wing grille—which honestly makes me think of animal whiskers—to the stylishly elongated rear, it has taken a giant step in the right direction. The sleek design has improved the aerodynamics by ten percent over its predecessor.

The MKZ sports LED lamps in the headlights that turn in unison with the steering wheel. In the rear, thin LED taillights stretch across the entire width of the car. The combination of the panoramic roof and the distinctive taillights makes this car a standout not only in this segment but also in the entire sedan world.

The MKZ is rife with standard safety features, but my favorite is the MyKey system, which can be programmed to limit speed and stereo volume. It could be a major disappointment to my teenage daughter but a possible life saver as well. I also was intrigued by the optional inflatable rear seatbelts, which seem like a prudent investment, as do the optional lane keeping system, blind spot information system with cross-traffic alert, adaptive cruise control, and collision warning with brake support. All put together, they make a very pretty face.

I was happy to be driving the V-6 version and played with the standard Lincoln Drive Control, which offers Sport, Normal, and Comfort modes that affect the suspension, steering, and noise control systems—basically how the ride feels. I would also like to spend a little time in the hybrid version, which is available only with front-wheel drive and the four-cylinder engine. On the plus side, it costs the same as the gasoline-engined version. It also gets 45 mpg both in the city and on the highway. By comparison, the front-wheel-drive MKZ with the four-cylinder gets 22/33 mpg, and the V-6 that I drove achieved 18/26 mpg.

I very much enjoyed zipping around town in the MKZ. I did find the road noise a little distracting, and I pondered whether it was the tires, the glass roof, or possibly a combination of both. Speaking of the panoramic roof, it blocks a good portion of the back window when in the fully open position,  but I think it is worth it. However, you should spring for the blind spot monitoring to compensate. On my summer drives I wasn’t able to appreciate the all-wheel drive, but I am sure that it would be a plus when winter rolls around.

The Verdict:

I am not a person who owns luxury-class cars. My driveway generally has much more prosaic vehicles in it. But I have to say that I loved spending a week inside the MKZ, and I wish I had a second week with it. I felt special the whole time and found myself looking for more errands to give me an excuse to drive it more.

In this segment, it is going to be the style that swings a buyer to put down the money. For me, the MKZ has risen to the occasion and could have a spot in my driveway. Best of luck to Lincoln in marketing this vehicle so that it gets the sales it deserves.

Peanut Gallery:

Scott: I liked the simplicity of the MKZ’s interior. I didn’t feel overwhelmed by too many electronics. The only thing that I truly disliked is that, when you fully open the panoramic roof, you can’t really see through the back window very well because the frame of the roof gets in the way. I would get my MKZ without that panoramic roof.

Christina: I was impressed with the design of the MKZ and couldn’t wait to drive it. When I did, I was, for the most part, pleased. The only thing that really bothered me was the distance I had to reach, when comfortably seated, to operate the controls for the side mirrors. Other than that, I loved the sleek controls in the center console and the way the natural light filtered in through the panoramic roof.

Annie: I really like the way the redesigned MKZ looks and was impressed with the package as a whole. There's plenty of technology, some unique features (like the push-button shift), and the interior is comfortable and attractive. But I couldn't get over the price. Options accounted for just about a quarter of the price of this vehicle, and while I loved the panoramic sunroof and the driver assistance technology (including active park assist, lane keeping system, and adaptive cruise control), I'm not sure I loved the prices. If I were buying an MKZ, I'd get one with fewer options. But if I wanted to spend $50,000 on a car, I wouldn't buy an MKZ.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. Key Points

• There is a Celebrity Cars Blog that tracks what the stars are driving. It frequently shows the famous filling up their vehicles in Hollywood. Among those shown with their Bentleys: David Beckham, Sylvester Stallone, Ludacris, and Lisa Vanderpump from The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills.
• On a classier level, the Bentley has long been the ride of queens. Queen Elizabeth II, who is celebrating her sixtieth year on the throne, has a state Bentley estimated by the voracious British media to be worth more than $15 million. It was a gift from the automaker on the occasion of Her Majesty’s Golden Jubilee, in 2002. Curiously, that car stalled this January as the queen was leaving a church service at Sandringham.
• It’s not unusual for this to be a chauffeur-driven vehicle.
• The elephant in the room with the Bentley? The V-8. An exclusive British car like the Bentley typically comes with twelve cylinders.
• You could argue that the V-8 is a more respectable choice. For one thing, it doesn’t squander as much fuel: 14/24 mpg is decent for a luxury convertible, even if the Continental doesn’t escape the gas guzzler tax. Plus, it saves the customer probably close to $20,000 to choose a Bentley with a V-8 as opposed to a W-12.
• Power is not an issue: Bentley says the V-8 engine sprints from 0 to 60 mph in less than five seconds and has a top speed of more than 180 mph.
• Huge amounts of optional creature comforts are on board, including massaging front seats, wonderful deep pile carpeted floor mats, and embroidered Bentley headrests. In fact, there are sixteen options or packages on the Bentley I drove, which added up to $36,410 over the base price of the car.
• The super rich can go beyond even these substantial option choices and create a one-of-a-kind Bentley Continental GTC. Have a favorite lipstick or handbag? All you have to do is let the Bentley artisans borrow it to create a custom exterior shade to match.

relatedArticles.title: 2013 Toyota Camry

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $32,090 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.5-liter 24-valve V-6, 268 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 21 mpg city/31 mpg highway
My favorite standard features: Ten airbags, including side curtain and rear seat-mounted side airbags; sporty-looking front mesh grille and integrated underbody spoilers
Option I can’t live without: Blind spot monitor ($500)
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Mazda 6, Nissan Altima, Volkswagen Passat

What I Think:

The Toyota Camry has a reputation as a solid, practical, smart choice in a five-passenger sedan. It’s rated as the top mid-size car in the J.D. Power Initial Quality Study. It is a Top Safety Pick of the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. Wait, keep reading! Yes, as with so many things that are solid, practical, and smart, you can be excused for feeling a little bored and reluctant about the Camry. Lentils and carrot juice are similarly good choices, but you probably don’t want them for your birthday dinner.

But don’t sell this fine car short. The reason so many people choose the Camry—ten million of them since the mid-size sedan went on sale thirty years ago—is that they can count on it. It will go and go, and then it will sell at a nice value-retaining price later. Toyota says almost six and a half million of all the Camrys sold are still out there on the road. You probably parked next to one last time you went to the store, although you probably didn’t give it a second glance.

It may be uncool to look at a car as an appliance. But let’s face it, to most people a car is exactly that: it is made out of metal, it has moving parts, and it makes their daily lives easier. With the amount of money a car costs, I think it’s perfectly reasonable to want to buy the longest-lived, most reliable car you can find.

Do you want to have some fun while getting where you want to go, though? Well, you might want to look at the Toyota I looked at: the one with a V-6, eighteen-inch wheels and tires, a sporty grille with mesh accenting and fog lamps, dual chrome exhaust….Yes, on a Camry. It even came in a fetchingly sporty shade of Barcelona Red that I’m calling Verbal Warning Red, since no Camry could ever wear Arrest Me Red, could it?

That depends. Take it on the expressway, as I did, and hit it. The car’s 268 horsepower is more than adequate for everyday driving, and all the Toyota quality and solidity you’d expect can be felt whenever you hit the gas. You do give up some fuel economy with the V-6, but it’s a free country: go ahead and get the 178-horsepower 2.5-liter four-cylinder instead, mated to the same six-speed automatic transmission. Doing that, you can pick up 4 mpg (to 25/35 mpg). Or get the Camry Hybrid, with that same four-cylinder engine making 156 horsepower and getting an even better 43/39 mpg. Up to you.

But let’s talk about the interior. I get what Toyota is going for: predictability and simplicity. You could also call it excessively sober, but there is no doubt where the controls are or how to operate them, and the matte black flush surfaces are stress reducing and not distracting. On the minus side, I dislike the thready-looking silver surfaces (right), which are actually supposed to be an upgrade on the SE model. The leather seats look like something designed by a committee to appeal to male buyers. They’re okay, but they feel stiff and therefore aren’t terribly comfortable. Since people buy the Camry at least in part for reliability, I would think details like the flimsy-feeling sun visors would be turnoffs to prospective buyers.

Among the interior options I liked are a Display Audio package ($650) that includes a 6.1-inch touchscreen display with backup camera, navigation, seven speakers, and HD radio, plus a ninety-day free trial of SiriusXM. The optional blind spot monitor would be $500 well spent. The Camry I drove had a power tilt/slide moonroof that cost $915. I wouldn’t pay that much to get one—but you might want to.

The Verdict:

I’ve heard it said that children are happiest if they have a common first name, even if it makes them one of three Jacobs or Jessicas in their classroom. So go ahead, be like millions of other appliance buyers, and get yourself a Toyota Camry. That’s if you are more interested in reliability and sturdiness than excitement, and if you don’t care that you are driving the same kind of car as millions of other people.

Personally, if I made that decision, I’d probably go with the lower-end Camry with the more fuel-efficient four-cylinder engine. Since the base Camry starts just over $22,000, that choice would save me a few thousand dollars that I would spend to make myself stand out in some other way.
But there’s no doubt that the V-6-powered Camry SE was pretty fun to handle, even if it’s no midlife-crisis treat. You probably can’t go wrong either way.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly: The Camry is simply a vehicle to get you from Point A to Point B without getting in your way. It is perfectly fine to drive but will not impress you. I am a fan of excess, so perhaps I’m not the best critic for this daily driver, but the interior really is numbingly dull. I find myself wondering, why is the Camry America's number-one-selling vehicle? I cannot answer that.

Scott: I thought the Camry was super boring, but I’m really happy that it was, because most cars I test for this website are flashier and have a distracting number of perks and luxuries. The Camry was simple, so I could focus on driving it. It looks outdated compared with a lot of fancier cars, and I prefer that. Some cars are like a trip to Universal Studios. I enjoy going to amusement parks, but I don’t want to live there.

Annie: Color me impressed! I wasn't expecting to have a lot to say about the Camry, but I was pleasantly surprised by the SE's powerful V-6 engine. The Camry isn't going to turn any heads, but it's also not likely to leave you stranded on the side of the road somewhere. If you're looking for reliability with a touch of sportiness, the Camry SE is worth looking at.

Jean: The Camry is the gold standard of reliability and resale. You don’t have to search long to hear a story from someone who’s sold his or her five-year-old Camry for $15,000. This is not, in itself, a reason to recommend a car. Here are the reasons I recommend the Camry SE V6: It’s tight. It’s fast—I spun the wheels from a stop. It’s very nice inside. It has great seats. The steering is surprisingly connected. The console and controls are elegantly executed.

The brakes are not as responsive as I would like, and the body—despite the addition of a little tail spoiler and deep go-fast-looking panels front and rear—is ho-hum and slab sided compared with the competition. If you loved your entry-level Camry over the years and you’re convinced that to stray from the gold standard is a risk you don’t want to take, then by all means move up into a new, loaded Camry SE V6. It’s a honey. A zillion Camry owners out there can’t be wrong.

pageElements.text: “One Careful Lady Owner.” Now there’s an auction listing for a vintage car that should draw some attention. In this case, the Lady Owner of the car, a 2001 Daimler V8 Super LWB, is none other than Queen Elizabeth II. Once her personal vehicle, the Daimler, clad in British racing green paint, is a member of the Jaguar family. The car is going up for auction by Historics at Brooklands in the U.K. on August 31.

And you thought Prince William’s star turn in a Range Rover, when he actually drove his wife and newborn princeling child home from the hospital last week, was all the car news you were going to get on the British royal family. Not a bit of it.

The queen had this car built specifically for her own private use, meaning she herself was the one behind its regal wheel. Her Majesty racked up 11,000 miles over three years, mainly driving it between Windsor Castle and Buckingham Palace, a distance of some twenty miles each way. She kept the car until 2004, and it is now being held by the Jaguar Daimler Heritage Trust. It currently has 15,242 miles on the odometer and was last publicly displayed at the 2012 Goodwood Festival of Speed, as part of the Cartier Royal Jubilee display.

The Daimler has lamb’s-wool rugs and a full leather interior, along with all the expected luxuries. However, imagine you were queen and could choose whatever extra amenities you like. True to her no-nonsense nature, Elizabeth II’s custom choices include a center armrest with a slide-out section for her legendary handbag, as well as switches to allow her to operate all the windows from either side. The monarch got those because she wanted extra fresh air but specified she doesn’t enjoy having it blow directly on her face. Well, who does?

Another interesting touch on the car is a set of communication equipment to put Her Majesty directly through to the Home Office or to the prime minister at No. 10 Downing Street. Sadly, that feature is disabled, so the next owner will have to get in line like anybody else. However, still operational is a set of blue lights hooked up behind the rearview mirror to tip off security forces about which car held the queen. There are also strobe lights that, the auction house points out, provide the bonus of extra visibility in the unlikely event of a smoke attack.
The Daimler has a supercharged 4.0-liter V-8 that makes 375 horsepower. Because Elizabeth II, as is well known, likes horses quite a lot.
The auction house is looking to get somewhere in the $40,000 range for the car. Ready to place your order for it? Go peruse the Historics at Brooklands listing and register to bid.

pageElements.text: Do you have a recurring dream in which you are piloting a Maserati along California roads, making your way toward a racetrack for an afternoon of action? Here's your opportunity. As part of the Danville d'Elegance Concours and Tour d'Elegance, one lucky bidder will get the chance to get into a new Maserati for a rally drive, followed by watching Maserati Trofeo MC Series cars on the track at Sonoma Raceway from the comfort of the Maserati VIP hospitality area, for you and a guest. The winning bidder gets to drive a 2013 or 2014 Maserati Quattroporte, GranTurismo, or GranTurismo Sport. Best of all, the auction proceeds will go to support Parkinson's research and care.
The event takes place on Saturday, August 24. It all starts at the showroom of event sponsor Maserati of Walnut Creek. Auction bidding started today, August 2, and will continue for seven days.
You can bid at this link.

Why Parkinson's? This charitable connection is in honor of the late Phil Hill, the great American racing legend, whose first Grand Prix race, in 1958, was in a Maserati 250F. Hill, who died in 2008 from complications of Parkinson's, was a supporter and participant in the Danville d'Elegance festivities. The Danville d'Elegance Foundation has given more than half a million dollars to Team Fox, the grassroots wing of the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's research. The Danville organization also gives generously to the Parkinson's Institute of Sunnyvale, California. The weekend activities are led by volunteers, many of whom have a Parkinson's connection in their own lives. So what's keeping you from bidding?

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid.
