metaDescription: A Detroit Weekend with Volvo's XC60: From the Detroit Tigers at Comerica Park to the apple orchard at Wasem Farms, this crossover was capable and comfortable. Read about my adventures at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: It seems to have happened all at once: temperatures are dropping, the leaves are starting to change, the days are getting shorter. All signs point to fall. And while I love a good, crisp autumn day, I struggle with my yearly revelation that it will be at least six months until I feel warm again. So last weekend, in the waning days of summer, I decided to go out and drink up the last bits of warm, beautiful weather by knocking a few things off my to-do list. The items in question: attend one last Detroit Tigers baseball game, sample one of Detroit's famous Coney Island hot-dog joints, and visit Wasem Fruit Farms in Milan, Michigan.

Of course, every good weekend needs a good car to go with it, and this one was no exception. A 2014 Volvo XC60 T6 AWD was my companion for these several jaunts across southeast Michigan. This shiny white Volvo was brand spanking new, with fewer than 600 miles in the bank when it was dropped off at our office.

This XC60 crossover can be had for as little as $35,765, including destination, but the one I drove is several notches up the latter at $53,215, thanks to a powerful 300-horsepower six-cylinder engine, all-wheel drive, and optional safety technology. Even the paint, a metallic Crystal White Pearl, cost $550 extra.

And, as you might expect, this Volvo had more safety features than you could shake a stick at. Blind spot monitoring, cross traffic alert, lane change assist, and front and rear park assist came in the $900 Blind Spot Information System package. Another $1,500 got us adaptive cruise control, collision warning with full auto brake, lane departure warning, distance alerts, and other features. All that safety technology helped the XC60 earn a five-star overall safety rating from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, and it’s a Insurance Institute for Highway Safety Top Safety Pick + for 2013.

Our XC60 also boasted creamy white leather seats and elegant wood trim. (JKC's Molly was so inspired by the wood in this Volvo that she wrote a whole story about it.) The seats and wood are part of the Inscription package, a $2,300 option. Suffice it to say the XC60 was several notches up the ladder from the car I normally drive around on weekends, and I was thrilled at the substitution.

The first stop of the weekend was Comerica Park, where my parents hold truly prime season tickets to our beloved Detroit Tigers. This meant driving the twenty miles from Ann Arbor to Plymouth to pick them up so we could all drive downtown together. Traffic was slow on the freeway, so I ducked off and took dirt roads most of the way to the family seat, but the Volvo was unfazed by the rougher terrain—although I did manage to dirty up the dazzlingly white paint.

Parents collected, we headed off together to downtown Detroit. The XC60 isn’t a huge car, but we managed to squeeze four adults inside in relative comfort. I watched from the back seat as my father toggled through the electronic dashboard’s settings, which had completely flummoxed me (turns out it’s controlled by a knob on the wiper stalk. Who knew?), to call up our real-time fuel economy. The XC60 is rated at 24 mpg on the highway, 20 mpg combined. We managed 21 on that trip, the best of any of the weekend’s trips, and Volvo is anxious to point out that its cars, unlike others from luxury brands, don’t require premium fuel.

On Saturday, I made a return trip downtown for visits to the Detroit Institute of Arts and Lafayette Coney, a classic Detroit hot dog joint. I was driving with all of the Volvo’s available safety systems on, which meant that my ride was frequently interrupted by small beeps and flashing lights (You’re following too closely! There’s someone in your blind spot! You’re drifting out of your lane!).  If you’re fully focused on the task of driving, this can be a little annoying, since the car is reminding you of things you already know. But if you allow your attention to wander at the wrong moment, those little beeps could save you a lot of trouble. I found that out when I briefly turned my head to talk to my passenger as we approached a green light. Suddenly I heard loud beeping coming from the dash and turned my head back to see that the light was no longer green and the car in front of me had stopped. I hit the brakes in time to keep Volvo’s collision avoidance system from doing it for me, but for the rest of the day I kept wondering if the warning system had just saved me from a crash.

By Sunday it was officially, undeniably autumn, so I took my Volvo to Wasem Fruit Farms for apple picking and doughnut eating, a favorite fall activity. I’d been slowly familiarizing myself with the XC60’s infotainment system all weekend, but three days later I still found its combination of buttons and knobs confusing and far from intuitive. Happily, the rest of the XC60’s interior was far less troublesome. The white leather seats and attractive wood trim give it the right amount of upscale feeling, and it was a comfortable place to spend a weekend.

The Volvo’s 300-hp engine is mated to a six-speed automatic transmission and makes the XC60 feel much sportier than your average crossover. You’ll never want for power in this vehicle, but it also won’t overwhelm you. The exterior styling is different enough to stand out in the crowd of look-alike crossovers, but not outlandish enough to turn you into the pariah of the country club. In other words: it’s just the right dose of attitude in a generally sedate segment. A Swedish crossover may have been an odd choice for a thoroughly Midwestern weekend, but the XC60 was up to the task.

title: Understanding the New Crash Tests
promoTeaserSmall: Here's your easy-to-understand guide to the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety's newest testing.
promoTeaser: Here's your easy-to-understand guide to the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety's newest testing.
metaTitle: Understanding the New Crash Tests - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Understanding the New Crash Tests: Have you heard about the new crash tests? Advanced safety ratings? Here's your easy-to-understand guide to the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety's latest testing. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: If you've shopped for a new vehicle recently, you've probably consulted some source of safety information, and you've probably been very interested in crash test results for the model you have in mind. Crash testing from the federal government's National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, or NHTSA, is one of the two sources for this data. The other is the insurance industry's Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, or IIHS—the organization that hands out the Top Safety Pick and Top Safety Pick+ awards. And you probably have a mental picture of what they do, i.e., smash a car into something, wreck it, and see how the crash test dummies make out.

With that in mind, you may be shocked to discover that a new crash-avoidance rating system by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety skips traditional crash testing in which the car is totaled. But don't be dismayed; the new setup actually provides some of the best information on whether crash-prevention systems are worth the money.

Helping You See the Benefit of Anti-Crash Technology

The new IIHS testing examines modern safety systems, including forward collision warning and autobrake systems. Forward collision warning alerts a driver when the vehicle is about to crash into another vehicle in front, but the system doesn’t slow down or stop the vehicle. Autobrake systems do; they can slow down or stop the car to avoid front-to-rear crashes if the driver doesn’t respond to a warning.
Safety experts say the benefits of these fancy and expensive systems are often lost on consumers.

“Front crash prevention systems can add $1,000 or more to the cost of a new car,” said David Zuby, IIHS chief research officer. “Our new ratings let consumers know which systems offer the most promise for the extra expense.”

What Does the Testing Look Like?

The new IIHS rating system evaluates safety software and sensors in vehicles instead of structural integrity. And that’s why the IIHS did not need to total any vehicles.

Running into an actual car puts the test driver at risk and is expensive, so the IIHS used a stationary target as a stand-in. A foam dummy with a metal frame and a vinyl cover was designed to look like a car to radar and image-recognition software. A GPS system and other sensors monitor the test vehicle’s lane position, speed, time to collision, braking, and other data. The effectiveness of the systems was gauged in tests at 12 and 25 mph.
The new tests are important because they mark the first time the insurance industry-funded group has used anything besides conventional crash tests to pick its annual Top Safety Pick+ winners.

How Does IIHS Rate the Cars?

For crash-avoidance technologies, the IIHS developed a three-tier rating system—Superior, Advanced, and Basic—to show that even a basic forward collision warning system has “significant” benefits. Vehicles rated Superior have autobrake and can avoid a crash or substantially reduce speeds in the 12-mph and 25-mph tests.

In this first round of testing, an elite group of seven vehicles equipped with optional autobrake and forward collision warning systems earned Superior honors. They are the 2013-14 Cadillac ATS sedan and SRX SUV, the Mercedes-Benz C-Class sedan, the Subaru Legacy sedan and Outback wagon, and the Volvo S60 sedan and XC60 SUV.

Six other models earn an Advanced rating when equipped with autobrake and collision warning. They are the 2014 Acura MDX SUV, the Audi A4 sedan and Q5 SUV, the 2014 Jeep Grand Cherokee SUV, the Lexus ES sedan, and the 2014 Mazda 6 sedan. In addition, the Volvo S60 and XC60 earn an Advanced rating when they aren’t equipped with an option called Collision Warning with Full Auto Brake and Pedestrian Detection. The S60 and XC60 are the only models in the new test program with standard autobrake: Volvo's City Safety system.

Thirty models received a Basic rating; they have forward collision warning but not automatic braking. These include the 2013 BMW 3 Series sedan, which earned a Basic rating for front crash prevention.
The 2013 Toyota Prius v wagon, which, IIHS notes, "claims to have autobrake," did not qualify for an IIHS front crash prevention rating.
The new IIHS testing is expected to roll out to other vehicle categories in the coming year.

title: In Search of Detroit
promoTeaserSmall: We're spending a day at TEDx Detroit, looking for people who can believe in Detroit the way we do.
promoTeaser: We're spending a day at TEDx Detroit, looking for people who can believe in Detroit the way we do.
metaDescription: In Search of Detroit - We're spending a day at TEDx Detroit, looking for people who can believe in Detroit the way we do. Read our update at JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
photos by Molly Jean

We're Michiganders, and Jean Knows Cars was founded on the basis that we love Michigan, we love Detroit, and we proudly share a Midwestern sensibility. We've been proud that Automobile Magazine, our brother publication, has been in Michigan for all of its nearly thirty years.

However. You all know how people think about Detroit: a barren, crime-ridden wasteland. Its best days are behind it. "Nobody" lives there anymore. Well, we have a little trouble accepting that. And it's for that reason that Molly Jean and I are spending today at TEDx Detroit, a day of inspiring talks from some of the people who are making Detroit livable again.

So far, we've already heard from three people who have given us a lot to think about. While the federal government is shut down, this is a really good time to imagine ways in which regular old people (like us) can help grow the economy in simple ways without 'em. Here's some of what we heard today.

John Capp, General Motors Futurist: "We're looking for true 360-degree sensing around the vehicle."

John Capp only looked a little out-of-place amid the black-clad, youngish crowd of entrepreneurs in the capacity crowd of hundreds in Cobo Center. Having gone to an autonomous-driving confab in Detroit this summer, I was already prepared for what he had to say, but I loved hearing him say it to this crowd. He laid out the history of GM's autonomous-technology work, starting with Harley Earl's 1958 Cyclone concept and highlighting current products including Cadillac's Driver Assist technology and the vibrating Safety Alert Seat that I appreciated (even though it annoyed me) on the Buick LaCrosse.

"What we're moving toward," Capp told the crowd, "is sensor fusion," which he described as technology intuitive enough to assess a road situation that same way we do, when walking down the street. "We're on a journey," he concluded, promising that GM will be rolling out better autonomous technology step by step, all the way to a "chauffeured" experience eventually.

While I don't look for General Motors to be the first to market with autonomous technology, you never know. And I'm glad to think about Detroit having an important role in it. I'm also glad to see GM send someone to talk about it in this kind of venue.

Matthew Naimi, Recycle Here: "If they build it, they will stay."

Naimi, a smiling but unprepossessing guy in a baseball cap, made it clear as he stepped on stage that he was "just a garbage man," but he's a garbage man with an idea. He started a recycling program in central Detroit that, to date, has recycled 11 million pounds of trash. But that's not the most interesting part: he got people to volunteer to clean up the back lot of his facility and turned it into the Lincoln Street Art Park in a supposedly dangerous part of town. As he describes it, it's a place where people can put their art, plus a party space with a community bonfire pit. One rule: You can't exclude anybody. More than fifty artists have placed their work there, and there's no fence.
"To rebuild Detroit," he said, "we must re-create what made cities in the first place: the collective energy of citizens working to live together in a defined space."

Jackie Victor, Avalon International Breads: "In 1997, the narrative was pretty much uniform: Detroit was closed for business. We changed that narrative."

Seventeen years ago, this suburbanite and University of Michigan graduate, whose hippie past (and, likely, present) showed in her every movement, co-founded a "socially responsible" bakery in the Cass Corridor, the most blighted part of a blighted city. There was a tent city right down the street with 300 homeless people camping in the depth of a Michigan winter. Yet the bakery not only survived; it's got sixty employees, mostly Detroit residents, who are paid an average of $12 per hour and full benefits. A manufacturing facility is about to open on Detroit's East Side that she envisions could "become a live-work neighborhood once again."

Victor also enumerated several businesses and projects that are also thriving in Detroit: the urban agriculture movement, which has grown to see 1,500 gardens under cultivation in formerly abandoned lots; the James and Grace Lee Boggs School, an ambitious charter school just opened in a neighborhood that, she said, "I almost guarantee nobody here has been to";  the African Bead Museum on Grand River. "Who's been there?" she asked. "Gotta go!" As soon as we saw the slides she projected on the screen, Molly and I realized we had driven by that museum with its colorful wall murals on our way in. 
And she's right: We've gotta go there.

I used to come downtown with my grandparents as a child. I remember the excitement of a fully active city, and right now, I am squinting and trying to see it again. Looking forward to more inspiring stories this afternoon.
Your correspondents, Laura and Molly

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: It’s a strange thought, especially for those of us who love to drive, but the day of the self-driving car could be close at hand. Auto companies are working hard on technology that would allow vehicles to do most of the work of driving for us, and there are already vehicles on the market, like the new Infiniti Q50, that can manage semi-autonomous driving in certain conditions. But these cars won’t create themselves — there’s a lot of work to be done first to ensure the technology will be safe and reliable.

Right here in our hometown of Ann Arbor, the University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute is emerging as a leader in connected vehicle research. We’ve told you before about UM-TRI. For over a year, they’ve been running a 3,000-car study on connected vehicles, with hopes that they will learn more about how connected vehicles could work in the real world. Now, they’ve announced plans for a $6.5 million thirty-acre test facility to test automated vehicle technology.

The facility should be completed by Fall 2014. It will include a five-mile test track designed to replicate real-world driving conditions, like curves in the road and lane merges. UMTRI hopes to test a variety of technologies at the track, including automated cars and vehicles that can sense changing traffic patterns, although no specific projects have been announced.
Right here in our hometown of Ann Arbor, the University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute is emerging as a leader in connected vehicle research.

Peter Sweatman, director of the University of Michigan Mobility Transformation Center, said in a statement that the test track, and facilities like it, are crucial because connected vehicles and autonomous driving technologies will need to be extensively tested “before a significant number of vehicles can be safely implemented on actual roadways.”

Talk of implementation on real roadways isn’t just hypothetical for UMTRI – the institute, the auto industry, and the government plan to team up to develop “an entire system” of connected vehicles in southeast Michigan by 2021.

The reality of the self-driving car can be a little worrying for enthusiasts, but researchers hope the technology will drastically reduce traffic fatalities by minimizing human error. And that’s a goal we can all get behind.

I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Women drivers in the United States may be the butt of jokes from obnoxious young men or get occasional subpar service at dealerships, but we’ve got a lot to be thankful for. Women in the United States now make up more than 50 percent of the driving population and make 80 percent of car-buying decisions. But, perhaps most important, we can drive wherever we want, whenever we want. The same cannot be said for women in Saudi Arabia, the last country in the world to ban women from driving. But Saudi women are working to change that.

On Saturday, October 26, dozens of women in Saudi Arabia got behind the wheel in a much-publicized protest against their government’s ban on women obtaining driver’s licenses. Yes, the ban is on getting licensed; there is no law that specifically prohibiting women from driving. Some of the women posted pictures and videos on social media sites of their acts of defiance, calling worldwide attention to Saudi Arabia’s arcane law. Here's an example in which a woman can't disguise her excitement at getting behind the wheel. And here's another one, in which a woman drives her son to a doctor appointment. Revolutionary!

Saudi police were on guard against women participating in the protest and reportedly stopped several women who were caught driving. Fawaz Al-Meeman, a spokesperson for the Riyadh police department, reported to CNN that the police held women who were caught driving until a male guardian could come pick them up, and had the women sign a pledge that they would not drive again before releasing them.

Driving is hardly the only privilege that Saudi women can’t take advantage of. Without permission from a male relative, the BBC reports, Saudi women aren’t able to travel abroad, open a bank account, or work without the permission of a male relative. Although some of the videos posted on YouTube showed male drivers giving thumbs up and waving at female drivers in support, the Saudi government has shown no sign that it will change things. Some conservative Islamic clerics staged a counter-protest outside a royal court (since Saudi Arabia is an absolute monarchy) last week in support of the current law.

Supporters of the protest are encouraging Saudi women to make the protest last longer than just one day. A new hashtag has emerged for supporters of the event: #Nov31Driving. There aren’t 31 days in November, so protest organizers are using the date to signify an open-ended commitment to their cause, and to encourage Saudi women to keep driving, despite the risk.

title: Why I Love My 1999 Lexus RX300
promoTitle: Why I Love My 1999 Lexus RX300
promoTeaserSmall: Has any car since the Model T had such a revolutionary role as harbinger of a new era? I think not.
promoTeaser: Has any car since the Model T had such a revolutionary role as harbinger of a new era? I think not.
metaTitle: Why I Love My Lexus RX300 - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Why I Love My 1999 Lexus RX300: Has any car since the Model T had such a revolutionary role as harbinger of a new era? I think not. Read as I make my case in JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I was a contributing editor to the (now sadly defunct) Art Economist and have been published in Cosmopolitan, New York magazine, the New York Post, US, and Avenue magazine. I blog (about arts, not cars) for The Huffington Post, and you'll notice in my photo there that I am also a hat lady.

pageElements.text: No one stops to admire my car, to remark on its not exactly sleek but most attractive rounded shape and pretty claret color (what they now call Matador Red Mica, although mine was called Venetian Red Pearl in 1999), all packaged in a handsomely matured fifteen years.

Why doesn't anybody fawn over my vehicle? Why are there no covetous glances from fellow drivers or winks of shared satisfaction of the kind given to other owners of the same model? How prescient we were, we ought to be declaring, with smug nods.

When I travel from Manhattan to the Hamptons in my cousin's 1964 Ford Mustang, strangers honk; I've even witnessed them running up to the car as she parks it, peering through her driver's-side window and offering piles of money for the car, which is most definitely not for sale. Yes, those early Mustangs are fabulous and innovative; they represented a new lifestyle, the kicky Sixties and all that.

But the same could be said about the 1999 Lexus RX300, except for the part about the kicky Sixties. It was a mold breaker, a game changer, a maverick (not a Ford Maverick) in the annals of vehicular history.

Look to the road now, and it seems that a quarter of all driving machines are modeled after my Lexus: sedan-sized sport-utility vehicles built for convenience and comfort rather than off-road activities. Why don't people observe the importance of my superannuated car? The innovation, the cutting-edge uniqueness? Why isn't the RX300 considered a sure bet for classic cardom?

All right, you laughers, it's not a sleek and elegant sports car. Some might even consider it a mom-mobile. It isn't sexy and temperamental. Its turning radius is wide. But it was the very first luxury SUV to be built on an automobile chassis rather than that of a truck. It is the precursor!

Prior to the RX300, I drove a Chevrolet Suburban for ten years. I wanted something smaller, but I still wished to be seated high and have access to four-wheel drive. I was tempted to buy a handsome Jeep Grand Cherokee, which fit the bill, but the ride was rather stiff and rough. It was a real off-roader, not the comfort car with off-road abilities I was seeking.

I tested the other luxury SUVs: the new Mercedes ML320 and the Infiniti QX4. They were definitely both appealing. Then I entered the Lexus showroom on Eleventh Avenue in Manhattan, and there, showcased, was cherry metal in a unique vehicular shape I had never seen before, with funny little triangular windows but great visibility. Dare I say it was cute without being girly?

Inside was a glabrous cream leather interior with super-comfortable adjustable seating, memory, and fine walnut trim. And the back seat featured something I'd never witnessed, except in limousines: a VCR. Here, it was mounted on the ceiling facing any would-be back-seat passengers. (After purchase, my kids watched Jurassic Park countless times, as that was the only tape that seemed to dwell in the car.)

I test-drove the RX300, and it was the quietest vehicle I had ever encountered. Its ride was so much smoother than the other luxury brands: the Mercedes, the Infiniti, and the larger Lexus LX, all built on truck platforms. The car that was to be mine was set on a Toyota Camry chassis. It had a V-6 engine, 220 horsepower, a 3.0-liter four-speed automatic transmission, and a 103-inch wheelbase, all-wheel drive, and front and side airbags. It propelled from 0 to 60 mph in 8.8 seconds. Some aficionados appreciated it right away: it became the first Motor Trend Sport-Utility Vehicle of the Year in 1999. And it had no problem with floor mat entrapment like some later Lexuses.

Over the past fifteen years, it has traveled back and forth across the country. It has masterfully handled harsh weather: snow, mountains, mud. Its drive has remained, if not quite as silky as it once was, still a pleasure, even though the steering wheel now squeaks, a reminder of how whispery quiet it formerly was.

Was the '64 Mustang more revolutionary than my RX300? Did it lead an innovation revolution of this caliber? Has any car since the Ford Model T been such a forerunner (not a Toyota 4Runner, which is truck based)? Millions of passenger-car-based all-wheel-drive vehicles have followed in the template tracks of my luxurious Lexus.

Once I owned the RX300, I began to notice more and more twenty-first century smallish SUVs that resembled mine. There were ultra-luxurious Porsche, Audi, Mercedes, and BMW models, and popular vehicles from Ford, Hyundai, Nissan, and Mazda. Someone even came up with a name for them: CUV, for crossover utility vehicle. There are dozens of them now, from the Acura MDX to the Cadillac SRX, from the Kia Sportage to the Buick Encore. But they were not the original. They were all copies, all followers, all metal acolytes of my Lexus.

Even the later Lexus RX models have tended to stay ahead of the pack. Lexus revamped my vehicle in 2004, although its appearance wasn't altered drastically. By then, the RX had 28 percent of the luxury-SUV market. And the 2006 RX400h became the first luxury SUV hybrid. Today, the 2014 Lexus RX350 doesn't look a whole lot different from mine (or from all the other crossovers out there). Lexus has even reissued the pretty claret color, not seen since 1999. I have heard that RX stands for Radiant Crossover.

pageElements.text: One of the very best things about cars is that they can take you to far-off places where you can meet new people and experience new things. But once you get to that far-off place, sniffing out the coolest places in town—you know, the places the locals actually go to—is easier said than done. That job just got a little easier for iPhone users, with the launch of the CO Everywhere app.

CO Everywhere is available for free from Apple's App Store (iPhones only, for now). It allows users to choose a spot on a map, say their neighborhood or a city they’re traveling to, and see a stream of aggregated social media posts from users in that area. CO Everywhere’s developers are aiming to fill a gap they see in hyperlocal news. There’s plenty of information out there for a person seeking a restaurant in Chicago, but what if you’re looking for the best restaurant in just one neighborhood of Chicago? Or just one street? CO Everywhere can help with that.

It works like this: once you’ve downloaded the app, you can pick any spot in the world, draw a circle on a map, and see a real-time stream of social media updates from that area. CO Everywhere picks up location-tagged posts from Instagram, Twitter, Yelp, Facebook, and other sites to give users a picture of what’s going on in the selected area. You can choose multiple locations, too. So you could have one map keeping you updated on what’s going on at home, another in the town you grew up in, and a third gaining intelligence on your destination for the weekend. The results can range from mildly interesting to genuinely helpful.

I drew a map around Ann Arbor this week and was confronted with a predictable string of Halloween-related Instagram photos from Ann Arbor’s student population. A map of my college campus in Boston that same day flooded my feed with posts about the Boston Red Sox's World Series victory. More helpful than the tweets of strangers, though, are the restaurant reviews sourced from Yelp and local deals from Yipit, a site with daily deals to local establishments. My Boston map showed a coupon for 50 percent off food at a popular restaurant and deals to a local cycling gym. Ann Arbor’s Yelp reviews suggested brunch at Café Felix, a restaurant that’s been languishing on my to-try list.

I’m generally against downloading every iPhone app that crosses my path, since most of them end up going unused for weeks or months at a time. But with its innovative approach to local information sharing, CO Everywhere may just earn itself a place on my home screen.

title: Keys to the Kingdom
promoTeaserSmall: Anna and Suzi have found a simple, brilliant way to support Saudi women's right to drive. Join them!
promoTeaser: Anna and Suzi have found a simple, brilliant way to support Saudi women's right to drive. Join them!
metaKeywords: Jean Knows Cars Group of Seven
metaDescription: Keys to the Kingdom : Suzi and Anna of our G-7 are campaigning to support Saudi women's right to drive. How you can help.

pageElements.text: Have you been following the movement of Saudi Arabian women to gain the right to drive? It is almost unbelievable that women there are not allowed to have driver's licenses and are therefore unable to do something we women in the United States take for granted: get in the car and go where we want or need to go on our own. It’s the only country in the world where women aren't permitted to drive.

Well, in the past month, there is a small but significant movement of Saudi women getting in the car and driving.  Hashtags including #LetThemDrive and #Nov31Driving have sprung up on Twitter from both inside and outside the country, supporting their brave efforts to join the twenty-first century.

At Jean Knows Cars, we know a little about women and driving. Two members of our Group of Seven consumer panel, Suzi Hileman and Anna Eby, are right up there with the most car-crazy women you’ve ever met. They, like us, have little patience with limits placed on women’s ability to do what we want to do. The two of them have been following this story, and they've come up with a brilliant idea to let you make a statement about it.

Join Project Keychain!

It’s called Project Keychain, and like most great protest movements, it’s simple. Yes, women supporting women: it’s an idea as old as civilization. (Probably older.)

Here’s the simple plan. Go root around in your junk drawer and find a keychain or two. Put them in the mail to this address that Suzi and Anna have set up. Add a note of support. They're going to collect a whole lot of them as a show of solidarity, photograph them, and post the images. And we have no doubt they're going to make a hell of an impact, with your help.

4500 Williams Drive, Ste 212
PMB 258
Georgetown, TX 78633

You can also go to their Facebook page, Let Them Drive, and add your voices to theirs. And follow their efforts on Motorista, Anna's blog, and The Burrow, Suzi's blog. As Anna writes: "You can also post about this…everywhere! On Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, you name it. Please use the hashtags #Nov31Driving, #LetThemDrive, and #ProjectKeychain, so that we can create a unified effort, support each other, and, most importantly, support the women of Saudi Arabia."

Here in the United States, we may think we don’t need to think about organized feminism anymore. It has been decades since anybody looked askance at a woman doctor, a woman executive, or a woman in sports. We women may be far from equal on the pay charts, and there may not yet be a female president, but the glass ceiling is looking thinner and more vulnerable by the year.

It's all too easy to stay wrapped up in our First World Problems, such as: which $30,000 car do I like best?, and forget that in a country that has been a longtime U.S. ally, one with plenty of resources and wealth to call its own, women can’t even get driver’s licenses. Let’s stand behind the brave women who are flouting this ban.

pageElements.text: Tuesday was the first press day of the Specialty Equipment Market Association’s 2013 trade show, and there were plenty of hot cars to be seen. From beautifully restored vintage cars to insanely modified new vehicles, there was something for just about everyone. One of the stars of today’s show, earning accolades for the Hottest Car and Hottest Truck of SEMA 2013, was the Ford Motor Company. Those honors came for the Ford Mustang and the company’s F-Series trucks. Not content to rest on its laurels, Ford had a few more tricks up its sleeve today in the form of a couple of hot concepts and a classic truck restored for a good cause.

Hot Wheels Transit Connect

At a press conference on the show floor Tuesday afternoon, Ford unveiled a special collaboration with Hot Wheels (yes, that Hot Wheels): a race-inspired Transit Connect cargo van, designed as a support vehicle for drivers spending a day at the track. The van features an eye-catching blue and orange paint scheme, a sporty grille reminiscent of Ford’s Focus and Fiesta ST models, and custom wheels. On the inside, there’s everything you might need for a day at the track: a tool box, a fifty-five-inch TV, and two Hot Wheels tracks, in case real-life action gets a little dull. Hot Wheels also created a 1:64 die-cast model of this one-of-a-kind Transit Connect, which will hit toy stores in the fall of 2014.

Snakebit 1956 F-100

Ford didn’t save all the glory for brand-new models this year. The automaker also displayed a custom 1956 Ford F-100 pickup, dubbed Snakebit. The F-100 has been lowered, and features a grille that’s inspired by a Shelby Mustang, a stretched wheelbase, custom headlights and taillights, and a billet silver paint coat. The Barrett-Jackson Auction Company will auction off the truck in 2014 to help fund a children’s hospital in the Canadian province of Saskatchewan. The truck was unveiled Tuesday by rocker Gene Simmons and his wife, Shannon Tweed. Tweed hails from Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, and has taken a special interest in the project.

Chip Ganassi Daytona Prototype, Now with EcoBoost

Ford also announced that it has developed a new 3.5-liter EcoBoost V-6 engine that will be used by the Chip Ganassi racing team in their Daytona Prototype cars, and it showed a real-life version of the Fiesta ST that gamers can drive in the upcoming Forza Motorsport 5 Xbox game.

pageElements.text:
1954

I met Nuccio Bertone in January 1981, under heavy guard. It was during the terrible times of the murderous Red Brigade terrorists. All of Fiat—its research facilities, design centers, museums, and favorite coachbuilders—was protected by heavily armed security.

Nuccio had a car show waiting in his courtyard for the arrival of our small band of journalists from the U.S. I went straight past the exotica, stopping at the charming little Alfa Romeo Giulietta Sprint. He was delighted at my infatuation and found this black-and-white glossy photo, which he signed with a flourish and presented to me. When I discovered that the car had been introduced at the Turin Motor Show in 1954, the year of my birth, it sealed our bond.—Jean Jennings

1955

The 1955 Volvo PV444 represents something extra-special because of its importance to our family. We had a later model, the 544, but you'd have to know what you're seeing to tell the difference. Along with several other European brands, Volvo was just getting established in the United States in the mid-1950s. It became known for safety, but at first the brand was about efficient performance. In Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, the Volvo always stood out. Whenever I see one now, I marvel at the gawky but not unappealing shape and the details that really did set it apart. —Ronald Ahrens

1957

It’s almost foreordained to choose a favorite car from 1957: it has to be the Chevrolet Bel Air, doesn’t it? The '57 Chevy is one of the most desirable and iconic classic cars there is, and one look at it tells you why. I actually remember gracious, wide-hipped, tailfin-wearing turquoise cars like this from my early childhood. You can hear the Frank Sinatra music and see the saddle shoes when you look at this picture. It was the peak year for both Baby Boom births and quantity of chrome on the Bel Air.

The Bel Air was the top trim level of the '57 Chevrolet, with anodized gold trim to help it stand out from the lower One Fifty and Two Ten models, and it started at just over $2,200. I just learned that the first car Jean ever owned was a 1957 Bel Air coupe. It might have been my first car, as an infant, but I don't remember.—Laura Sky Brown

1963

Both the Buick Riviera and I came screaming into the world as 1963 models—and coincidentally, we were both conceived and delivered in Flint, Michigan. The Rivera, however, actually hit showrooms in October 1962 and cost $4,333. At the time, the Ford Thunderbird had been winning American hearts since 1958. The Buick's distinctive egg-crate grille, pontoon fenders, and razor-edged details made the American public pay attention. In 1978, my dad hit a deer with our station wagon on the eve of our family trip to the exotic state of Florida. We were concerned that we would not get to see Disney World or the gorgeous beaches that we had dreamed about. But that night, when he arrived home, he had a spankin' new Buick Riviera. It was white with a red velvety interior—and it was clear that my dad was cool.

The Riviera remained an American luxury brand until it started to lose its mojo in the late 1980s, and it was long in the tooth when it finally was put to rest in 1999, at the ripe old age of thirty-six. I have not given up hope for the Riviera, and this year there was a concept Riviera at the Shanghai Motor Show, complete with gull-wing doors. It isn't often that I see a Riviera on the open road, but when I do, I get a quick flashback to family trips in the velvety goodness of the back seat of my childhood.—Molly Jean

1968

I like the 1968 Jaguar for its long, languorous lines and elegance, but the 1968 Mercedes-Benz SL is what is in my head, because that's the car that emoted sophistication when I lived in Germany.—Catherine McCurrach

1976

As an automotive technology journalist, I tend to focus on cars emerging on the horizon and rarely peruse cars of the past. When I think about cars from 1976, only two come to mind: the pale blue 1976 Chevrolet Caprice my friend, Brandon, drove throughout high school, and my parents' Volkswagen Beetle of undetermined year (shown here, with me inside). The features I liked best about the 1976 Chevrolet Caprice aren't fit to print, and I am probably the only person waxing nostalgic about a '70s-era Beetle where my strongest memory is of the choke not working.—Liane Yvkoff

1983

I have to go with the De Lorean DMC-12, because of the movie Back to the Future which came out in the year of my birth.—Scott Allen

1991

I don't remember 1991 very well, having spent most of the year as a fetus and the rest of it crying. But as far as I can tell from a quick Wikipedia search, the best car that shares my birth year is the Audi S4, a performance variant of the Audi 100 sedan. Introduced late in the year, just like me. German, just like me. Drives fast, just like me. As a bonus, the nameplate has hung on and now graces a faster, sleeker version of the Audi A4. Perfect.—Annie White

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: We’ve been bringing you updates about the Specialty Equipment Market Association show all week, and now, on the last day of SEMA 2013, we’re bringing you a rundown of three of our favorite cars from Vegas.

Chevrolet Performance 1978 Chevy 4x4 Pickup Concept

It’s all well and good to celebrate the newest, hottest thing in automotive technology. But there’s something to be said for celebrating the classics. That’s exactly what Chevrolet did with its concept version of a 1978 4x4 pickup. Chevrolet gave this old Silverado a 5.3-liter V-8 engine that pumps out 326 horsepower, nearly twice the truck’s original output. The truck also has a shiny new black and red paint coat, an updated dashboard, and a red leatherette interior with red and black hound's-tooth inserts.

Linda Vaughn LV-1 Camaros

Linda Vaughn is an old friend of Jean’s and is known to drag racers as the First Lady of Racing, so it’s no surprise that two custom LV-1 Chevrolet Camaros inspired by the legend herself were unveiled at SEMA. During her heyday, Vaughn was Miss Hurst Shifter—Hurst as in the manufacturer of aftermarket shifters for automotive enthusiasts—and these cars feature Hurst/Oldsmobile coloring. The two LV-1 Camaros that were unveiled at SEMA will be auctioned off in Scottsdale this January at the Barrett-Jackson Auction. Proceeds will benefit Dreamakers, a nonprofit organization that uses automotive marketing and product development to raise money for charity. Funds from these cars will be directed to IKAN, the International Kids Alliance Network, which focuses on education and fighting illiteracy.

2014 Kia Soul, Music Editions

Kia brought not one, not two, but five music-inspired editions of its funky, redesigned-for-2014 Soul. My favorite is the one inspired by NBC’s The Voice, a show I’ve recently become a fan of. The car is fitted with four chairs custom designed to match the coaches’ chairs on the show, airbrushed logos on the exterior, and the words “I Want You” (a phrase used often in the TV show) emblazoned on the lower grille. Inside, there’s a forty-inch LCD TV paired to a wireless microphone and an iPad Mini with The Voice app. The setup is specifically designed to allow driver and passengers to showcase their karaoke skills. Sounds like a party to me.

2014 Lexus IS350 F Sport by VIP Auto Salon

Remember when we told you about Lexus’s contest that allowed deviantART users to submit their dream IS350 F Sport design, with the winner to be unveiled in the flesh at SEMA? Well, this week, Lexus announced the winner of the contest and brought along the real-life model of the car, built by VIP Auto Salon. The car features a wide-body kit with sculptural wheel wells, twenty-inch wheels, Brembo brakes, and a 143-mph electronically limited top speed. A run-of-the-mill white paint job can’t disguise the fact that this Lexus is one of a kind.

These are just four out of dozens of standouts from this year’s SEMA show. There was much, much more stuffed inside the 27,000-square-foot convention center. And while this year’s extravaganza may be drawing to a close, we’ll take solace in the fact that SEMA will be back in just twelve short months, crazy as ever.

pageElements.text: This is a story of two rebirths: Detroit's, still in progress, and the Dodge Challenger's. After an over twenty-year hiatus, the Dodge Challenger reemerged onto the marketplace in 2008, and it was a stunner. Back in 1983, when it ceased production, it had devolved into a subcompact that held little resemblance to its heyday as a Detroit muscle car in the 1970s.

image.altText: http www lifeedited com live life just in time

pageElements.text: It seemed fitting to take the 2013 Challenger SRT8 392 to the Cass Corridor in Detroit. Once the part of Detroit with the worst reputation, the neighborhood is reemerging from its years as a crime-ridden, downtrodden district of Detroit to become a re-energized cultural center. The juxtaposition of the iconic muscle car and the gritty rebirth of the corridor provided the perfect backdrop.

As long ago as the 1950s, the Cass Corridor had already been abandoned by the middle class, and its once opulent homes and apartment buildings had become rooming houses and seedy apartments. It was no longer the hub of commerce and entertainment but rather was known as a dangerous, poor area of the city. Detroit’s original Chinatown had been displaced by the construction of the Lodge Freeway, and its businesses and residents had migrated into the Corridor. The auto shows that had been held in Convention Hall had moved to Cobo Hall. Even its architectural gem the Masonic Theater fell into disrepair.

But counterculture loves a gritty home. Wayne State University is located just to the north and the Detroit Institute of Arts and the Society for Arts and Crafts (now known as the College for Creative Studies) to the east. Combine that with low rents and a racially diverse population, and the Cass Corridor was the perfect incubator for the subculture of the turbulent 1960s and 1970s.

Meanwhile, the first-generation Dodge Challenger was built as a muscle car from 1970 to 1974 in the city of Hamtramck on the edge of Detroit. I can imagine it rumbling down Second Street in the Cass Corridor along with its peers of the day like the Plymouth Barracuda, the Ford Mustang, and the Chevrolet Camaro. The cultural revolution of the area did not, however, bring prosperity, and the corridor continued its downward spiral.

The Challenger returned, rebadged as a Mitsubishi Galant Lambda, from 1978 to 1983. It was rear-wheel drive and had no resemblance to its predecessor. Meanwhile the corridor continued to have a seedy reputation throughout the 1980s and 1990s. Since my college days, a group of my friends from school meet at Mario’s, an Italian restaurant in the Corridor reputed to cater to Mafia types, at least once a year. In the worst years, we would drive through the desolate neighborhood and only Mario’s would be gleaming in the night. We would pull up and hand our keys to the valet and get inside as quickly as possible. It felt dangerous. At the end of the night, when you got back on the highway, there would be a wave of relief. Businesses such as Mario’s, the Traffic Jam and Snug restaurant, and the historic Temple Bar still held on through the darkest days.

image.altText: http www lifeedited com live life just in time

pageElements.text:
Avalon Bread

In 1997, Avalon International Breads opened in the heart of the Cass Corridor. At the time it was a bold move, perhaps even crazy. The concept was to hire local residents to create artisan bread with 100 percent organic flour in a blighted area of a dying city. But, in fact, they were not crazy, and their business has thrived. The owners have put in a lot of sweat equity as well as being community organizers and are currently building a 15,000-square-foot bakery in the city and relocating the original storefront to a larger space.

image.altText: http www lifeedited com live life just in time

pageElements.text:
The Bronx Bar

This place was built in 1921 as a grocery store, but it has been a bar for decades. In fact, the bartender, Charlene, has been behind the bar for thirty-seven years. You know the type; she calls you honey, is brusque with her coworkers, slightly impatient—but efficient—and makes you feel welcome. It is a great old bar that serves really good food. On the day we visited there was a group of young tech developers at one table, a young college girl typing away on her computer taking advantage of the free wi-fi, and several more customers eating at the bar and enjoying a nice cold beer on the sunny fall day.

image.altText: http www lifeedited com live life just in time

pageElements.text:
City Bird and Nest

Slowly, other ventures have joined the effort to brighten up the Corridor, and honestly the area is downright vibrant now. Yes, there are still lots of buildings in disrepair, and you need to be cognizant of your surroundings, but it is definitely an exciting, hip place to be in 2013. When we ducked into City Bird, we found a store, studio, and gallery rolled into one. The focus is on Detroit-themed housewares, accessories, and paper goods as well as work by hundreds of other artists and designers. They have also opened a second store next door, Nest, that sells upscale housewares. In true Corridor fashion, the brother/sister team behind City Bird are real, sixth-generation Detroiters. She earned an MFA, and he holds a master's degree in urban planning, both from the neighborhood's Wayne State University.

image.altText: http www lifeedited com live life just in time

pageElements.text:
Shinola

Across the street is Shinola, a completely different concept. There is nothing Detroit about this venture. It is the brainchild of the founder of Fossil watches, Tom Kartosis, whose company Bedrock Brands has also purchased the outdoor apparel company Filson. Shinola sells high-quality, desirable watches, bicycles, leather goods, and journals. The company's shtick is that it is based in Detroit because of our rich manufacturing heritage, but in reality the watches and bikes are just being assembled here. It is surreal to walk into the high-fashion showroom with its very expensive products and pair it with the real world outside the door.

image.altText: http www lifeedited com live life just in time

pageElements.text: The showroom sports highly fashionable sales professionals and a security guard who I am confident would make many Corridor residents feel uncomfortable. Don’t get me wrong; I think it is great that this company has chosen to have a presence in Detroit, but it is a marketing-driven company that sees Detroit’s gritty image as manna from heaven.  I wish them well, but scratch the surface and you can tell shit from shinola.

image.altText: http www lifeedited com live life just in time

pageElements.text: Our shiny Challenger looked right at home in the Corridor, and I felt proud to be driving it. Unlike Shinola, it is a Detroiter, not a poser. The name alone speaks volumes. The SRT (Street and Racing Technology) moniker denotes that the performance-tuning engineers at Chrysler were involved in the development of this model. The wide silver stripes on the glittery black body stretch from tip to tail, and its retro styling screams, “Look at me.” And indeed, the locals did turn their heads as we purred through the streets.
The Challenger SRT8 392 feels like a big car, and there are some blind spots to be aware of, but this is a car that is damned fun to drive.

I am inherently lazy, so I was thrilled that our Challenger sported a five-speed automatic transmission to tame the 6.4-liter V-8 Hemi. And when the driver wants to put his or her driving shoes on, the steering-wheel-mounted paddle shifters can double the fun. It feels like a big car, and there are some blind spots to be aware of, but this is a car that is damned fun to drive.

Be careful when parking that you don’t nick the big low nose, and leave plenty of space when parking. The leather seat fit me perfectly, and the seating position felt just right (like the littlest bear's bed)—I am 5’7” and think a more vertically challenged driver may have trouble getting a comfortable seat with adequate sight lines. The Harmon Kardon sound system was appropriate for a car that will most likely be kickin’ out some tunes, but it makes sense to dial back your sound so that you can appreciate the exhaust note that has been lovingly tuned to perfection.

The steering is responsive, and although there is a slight roll it feels generally stable. I am not a boy racer, so my impressions are more in line with using this as an everyday driver, rather than as a street racer on Woodward. The ride was incredibly smooth for a muscle car, and I would recommend the Challenger SRT8 for anyone who wants to up their cool. But you can also up your cool by spending some time in the Cass Corridor. I only scratched the surface of this vibrant community that will welcome you with open arms.

2013 Dodge Challenger SRT8 392

Price: $51,665 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 6.4-liter Hemi V-8, 470 horsepower
Transmission: Five-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 14 mpg city/23 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Heated steering wheel
Option I can’t live without: Harman Kardon eighteen-speaker audio ($1,995)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Camaro, Ford Mustang, Hyundai Genesis, Nissan 370Z

contributors.bio: I'm the auto and motorcycle critic for the Orange County Register. Previously, I  was a staff writer at the Los Angeles Times for fourteen years, writing about motorcycles, cars, green living, and anything else that caught my fancy. Originally from Ann Arbor, Michigan, I currently live in Los Angeles with my ten-year-old son.

pageElements.text: You've taken the safety course, and you're ready to ride. Now comes the part that's both fun and challenging: Figuring out what bike to buy. The best beginner bikes have low enough seat heights to make riders feel in control. They're both lightweight and nimble enough to be unintimidating, yet challenging enough that riders won't grow out of them before getting their money's worth.

Fortunately, there are more entry bikes than ever before to choose from. The down economy has had an upside for beginning riders. Long neglected by motorcycle manufacturers, small bikes are where most of the action is, in terms of all-new, affordable and easy-to-control models. The last couple of years have seen brand-new beginner bikes from all the Japanese manufacturers and, most recently, Harley-Davidson. And here they are:

Honda Grom

Honda is the global market leader when it comes to small-scale motorcycles, and its new Grom offers proof. The smallest, and least expensive, motorcycle on the market, the 125cc Grom has a starting price of $2,999, a top speed of about 60 mph, and fuel economy that exceeds 100 mpg. Diminutive in size but satisfying in performance, the Grom weighs about as much as many American men (225 pounds) and is probably even easier to control.

Honda CBR250R

Beginning riders who want to look more experienced than they actually are might want to consider the $4,199 Honda CBR250R, an entry-level sport bike that looks similar to its big-boy brethren, the CBR600RR and CBR1000RR. With a low weight of 357 pounds and a top speed of 87 mph, the CBR250R is agile and powerful without being overboard. Still, it's enough to get riders in trouble if they don't know what they're doing. At least the CBR250R offers combined and anti-lock brakes as an option. For 2014, the slightly more powerful, but even lower weight, Honda CBR300R is likely to replace the 250.

Kawasaki Ninja 300

The Honda CBR300R was developed in response to the $4,799 Kawasaki Ninja 300, which has become the entry-level sport bike to beat in the year it's been on the market. It's the most powerful beginner sport bike and the one that is designed to most closely replicate its larger, true-sport-bike siblings, the Ninja 600 and 1000, both in looks and aggressive performance. With a top speed that exceeds 100 mph and a weight of just 379 pounds, it oozes macho character with a surprisingly growly exhaust and joe-racer profile.

• Related stories:
    Five Musts for the New Motorcyclist October 16, 2013
    Falling in Love with Motorcycles October 9, 2013

Suzuki GW250

Suzuki is the last of the Japanese motorcycle makers to introduce an all-new beginner bike. Available since early fall, the $3,999 GW250 is a mini "naked" bike that's jettisoned the plastic bodywork common to sport bikes and modified the riding position so it's more upright and comfortable. Easy to operate, the GW250 weighs 403 pounds and uses a liquid-cooled parallel twin as its mule to offer good acceleration and even better fuel economy of 65+ mpg.

Yamaha SR400

Yamaha will capitalize on the raging trend for retro next year when it introduces its SR400, a throwback to its SR400 from the 1970s. Highly customizable, the 2014 SR400 can easily be converted into the most popular retro styles of today, from cafe racer to street scrambler. Powered with an engine that splits the difference between yesterday and today, its 400cc single cylinder is air cooled but also fuel injected, for improved fuel economy.

Harley-Davidson's Upcoming Street 500 and 750

Harley-Davidson shocked the world last week (Nov. 5) when it introduced two small-displacement cruisers for the entry-level urban rider, both of which will be available in the spring. The $6,700 Street 500 and $7,500 Street 750 are a radical departure for the country's largest motorcycle maker. Harley-Davidson has long had a rep as the builder of 900-pound status symbols. Its new Street models are powered with cruiser-style V-twins with a crucial twist for stop-and-go urban riding. They are liquid rather than air cooled, and they're far lighter weight than Harley's previously smallest bike, the 883cc Sportster. The Street 500 weighs 480 pounds, almost 100 pounds less than the Iron 883.

pageElements.text: One of the most attractive things about the Fiat 500 is its styling that puts one in mind of the European minicars of the past. Fiat wisely builds on that La Dolce Vita appeal with the release of a 1957 Edition, which will make its debut at the Los Angeles Auto Show next week.

Why 1957? That’s the year that the classic Fiat Nuova Cinquecento came out in Italy—the “new 500”—and 2014 marks fifty-seven years since then. Between 1957 and 1975, there were almost 3.9 million of the affordable little cars built and distributed all over Europe.

The 1957 Edition will pay homage with cosmetic touches that echo the original, including vintage Fiat badging front and back, retro-looking sixteen-inch wheels, and white-painted roof and mirror caps. The interior has a special brown-and-ivory leather interior, including a leather-wrapped steering wheel with another vintage Fiat logo on it. Based off the 2014 Fiat 500's top-end Lounge model, it comes in Bianco (all white), or you can make it two-tone in either Verde Chiaro (light green) or Celeste (celestial blue), the color shown here, which is exclusive to this limited-edition car. Even the key fob is special, with a 1957 graphic and a casing that matches the car’s leather interior.

And, since this is a Fifties-inspired model, it comes with a five-speed manual transmission, although a six-speed automatic is an option, and a sport-tuned suspension with a driver-selectable Sport mode.

Fiat has done an admirable job of positioning the current 500 as a romantic and hip choice that’s still very practical, and it has worked. Since the 500 was relaunched in 2007, more than a million have been sold all over the world. I can see the Fiat 500 enthusiast being tempted to collect these like toys: one of every limited edition. If you’re interested, you can get this one next spring. Pricing will be announced closer to launch, but for reference, the 2014 Lounge model starts at $19,300. Orders will be taken starting early in the new year.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
Price: $23,985 as tested, including destination
Engine: 1.8-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 170 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 25 mpg city/36 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Leatherette seating surfaces with driver and passenger power recline
Option I can’t live without: No options on this model
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Cruze, Honda Civic, Mazda 3

What I Think:

I’ve always been a fan of cars with distinctive design and quirky features. The cars we drive say something about us, and I’ve always hated the idea of driving a car that labeled me as traditional or boring. But it seems as if today’s affordable-car market may be listing toward too much style, not enough class.

Cars like the new Toyota Corolla, the Chevrolet Spark, and the Fiat 500L are interesting to look at and they’ll set their owners apart. But what if you’re looking for a car that won’t break the bank with a design that will age like a fine wine? They’re out there; you just have to know where to look. And I suggest you look at the Volkswagen Jetta.

German cars are many things, but frivolous and faddish are not among them. I was surprised to learn that a Volkswagen Jetta can be had for around $20,000, because it has the class and sophistication of a more expensive car. You won’t find any weirdly shaped headlights or special edition pastel paint colors on this baby. Just clean lines and German engineering.

The 2014 Volkswagen Jetta SE I tested tipped the scales at $23,985 including destination, thanks to the Connectivity and Sunroof package, which adds $3,170 to the price of a base SE model. The package adds keyless access, push-button start, a power sunroof, and Volkswagen’s Car-Net connectivity features. It also makes a Jetta that might be just out of reach for someone looking in the low-$20,000s range. If you’re willing to forgo those features, though, an SE can be had for $19,715. And you’ll still get attractive leatherette seats, SiriusXM capability, partial power front seats, and a media device interface with iPod cable.

I liked the Jetta’s clean-looking interior. The touchscreen radio that came as part of the Connectivity package was easy to use, although not nearly as attractive as the systems offered by some of Volkswagen’s competitors. I found myself appreciating, too, that the steering wheel was relatively free of buttons. I may not have been able to launch a missile from the driver's seat, but I was happy to be holding a simple, uncluttered wheel in my hands for a change. No one will confuse the Jetta with a luxury car; leatherette’s no leather. But I did think our car’s all-black interior, like its inoffensive exterior, would age well. It’s the kind of car you could buy right out of college and still be proud to drive five years and a couple of promotions later.

And you’d be happy driving it, too. Our Jetta had Volkswagen’s new 1.8-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine. It’s a replacement for the Jetta’s outgoing 2.5-liter five-cylinder engine. This new offering makes 170 horsepower and feels quick and sure-footed on the road, while getting 36 mpg on the freeway. Yes, you could find a small sedan that earned 40 mpg on the highway if you really wanted to, but I for one would miss the Jetta’s pep.

The Verdict:

Buyers looking for a car in the Jetta’s size (small) and price range (affordable) are lucky to have a lot of good choices. I was impressed by the Jetta’s styling and driving dynamics, but it’s not the only worthy choice. Many cars in this class are more efficient than the Jetta and, to be honest, have a little more character. I’d be tempted by the Mazda 3, for instance. It’ll come down to personal preference for most buyers, but I think the Jetta’s classic looks and lively driving character tip the scales in its favor.

Peanut Gallery:

Laura Sky Brown: I used to enjoy the quirky Germanic feeling all Volkswagens used to have: that train-station chime when you first turned the key, the tiny little fussy controls, and the seat that had to be dialed to move the seat forward. It’s slightly disappointing to find that the modern-day Jetta is very much like the modern-day Honda Accord or Chevrolet Cruze inside. That, I think, is a loss, but I’m glad that the Jetta still looks like a VW on the outside, and it still feels tight and controlled to drive, another fine Volkswagen trait.

Molly Jean: This is a great car. It has classic beauty. Like Cindy Crawford, it is still going to look good as it ages. The view of the instrument panel through the steering wheel is perfect; no need to twist your head around. In fact, the whole cabin is logical, and the materials, although basic, seem like they will hold up through the years. This is a car that I can see being handed down for several generations.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Give yourself a reality check when you go to the dealer to buy a new car. Think about three considerations:
    Who's in your car most of the time, and what do those people (or animals) need?
    Does fuel economy matter a lot to you? How much do you drive?
    How do you use your car, and where?
Take the time before you go into a dealership, and it will be a lot easier to get not only a good deal, but a car that is absolutely right for your needs.
Except for you midlife-crisis types: You should go get whatever you want.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
Overview:

This year Detroit is the go-to source for going green. Doubt it? Just take a look at Ford’s updated C-Max Hybrid. Cute, yes, with a sporty comfort that makes driving fun. It launched last year but this year Ford has improved aerodynamics and gear shifting for even better fuel economy than last year. Ford was already claiming 7 mpg better economy than the Toyota Prius v’s highway numbers. The C-Max’s lithium-ion battery recharges while you drive using gasoline and regenerative braking recaptures up to 95 percent of the energy used in braking and uses that to recharge the battery. That’s some nifty energy recycling. The C-Max is not only efficient; it reminds you of how socially conscious you are by displaying more leaves and vines in the Smartgauge display as a “visual reward” for your good, as in energy efficient, driving, thereby making a game out of your urge to conserve. The C-Max’s popular price, starting just over $25,000—lower than its closest rival, the Toyota Prius, and some $10,000 cheaper than the Chevrolet Volt and the Nissan Leaf—will help you conserve that other important green stuff in your wallet as well, always a plus.
