pageElements.text: I like to think I'm immune to Hollywood "glamour" and "magic." After all, it's all good PR and airbrushing, right? Things like that don’t line up with my solid Midwestern DNA. The only time I paid any attention to the Kardashians was when I binge-watched their show when I was sick a while ago. Hollywood stuff just leaves me cold. Except for the Los Angeles Auto Show.

The true stars of this event don't have entourages, PR people, or pending
court dates. None has done five stints in rehab or has had plastic surgery (although the Toyota Camry SE was rocking some serious nips, tucks, and tweaks that looked great). I got to meet these stars up close and personal, and no one shooed me away or tried to confiscate my iPhone lest any incriminating shots appear on TMZ later in the day. These stars were truly a class act, from the gorgeous Kia K900 to the I-just-wanna-pinch-its-cheeks cute Fiat 500 1957 Edition.

There were periodic crushes of media folk and bursts of applause throughout the day, but it wasn’t for an underweight starlet on the red carpet; the fuss surrounded a new-model introduction or debut. Each unveiling brought a storm of flashes going off and the momentary crush of photographers trying to get a closer shot. Part of me was so caught up in the excitement of each debut that I was surprised I didn’t wave my iPhone and squeal like a tween fangirl. There is so much to love about the L.A. show.

I loved how every stand reflected the personality of the cars presented.
(Honda, I'm still trying to figure out what your stand conveyed. Oh wait.
I got it. "Zzzzzz..." Duly noted.) There were splashes of light, color, 
and sound. Smiling PR reps handed out swag and press kits and answered questions. Press conferences were mobbed dozens deep, but I didn’t care because I was part of the action and had the chance to see some stunning introductions. Much more fun than I imagine a movie premiere to be.

There was really nothing for me to dislike about the show, except for the lack of device charging stations (do not die, phone. I need you stay with me now) and the lack of hours in a day to see everything there is to see. I was truly starstruck by it all. So much for being indifferent to Hollywood magic.
Air kisses, L.A. show. You look fabulous, I just loved your latest project, and we will have to do this again next year. My people will be in touch. Mwah!

pageElements.text: The Los Angeles Auto Show’s press days have drawn to a close, and automakers and spokesmodels are preparing themselves for the onslaught of public attendees who will flock to the show’s public days to see everything from the redone 2014 Honda Civic (above) to the most out-there concepts. The public show runs from today, November 22, through December 1. Here are five of my favorites from this year’s show; if you’re planning on stopping by the show before it closes, make sure you swing by these stands.

2015 Audi A3

Mercedes-Benz made a big splash this fall when it began selling the entry-level CLA-Class for just $29,900 (before destination). Now Audi’s getting in on the compact luxury game with the all-new 2015 A3, which will also start at, you guessed it, $29,900 before destination. The new A3 will also be available in a performance S3 variant, as a plug-in hybrid dubbed the A3 e-tron, and as a cabriolet. (See the photo gallery below.) The new model was unveiled this week in L.A., and it looks like it will give the CLA stiff competition. Among the enticing available features are Audi’s MMI system, leather seating surfaces, and the first in-car availability of 4G LTE connectivity with the new Audi connect system. Just don’t get too tied to that sub-$30,000 asking price. By the time you walk out with the keys, you’ll probably have spent several thousand more in options and extras.

2015 Chevrolet Colorado

Chevrolet is fresh off a total redesign for its full-size truck, the Silverado, but that doesn’t mean the company’s truck division is twiddling its thumbs. At the L.A. Auto Show, Chevy unveiled its brand-new mid-size truck, the Colorado. The new offering is aimed at young, active buyers who want the utility and flexibility of a truck but don’t want that truck to be gigantic. The Colorado’s dynamic styling is intentionally set apart from that of the big, boxy Silverado, but the two trucks share other features. The Colorado, for instance, makes use of the Silverado’s triple-sealed doors for improved aerodynamics and a quieter cabin. If this is the truck you’ve been waiting for, you’ll have to wait a little longer. The Colorado won’t go on sale until next fall.

2014 Land Rover Range Rover Long Wheelbase

In contrast to the Audi A3, the Land Rover Range Rover Long Wheelbase Autobiography is anything but small and economical. Instead, this is a stretched, ultra-luxe version of the already large, already luxurious 2014 Range Rover; the Autobiography Black model is long-wheelbase only. Jaguar Land Rover’s Engineered To Order division is behind the bespoke feeling of this special Range Rover. A limited build of around 100 units is planned for the U.S. market in the 2014 model year. The first twenty-five will wear Valloire White pearlescent paint.The Range Rover Long Wheelbase Autobiography Black will tip the scales at a cool $185,000, but if you want it in the even more exclusive Valloire White, it's $199,500 (including destination). Land Rover calls this SUV “the ultimate in peerless luxury” and says it will give rear seat passengers 7.3 inches of extra legroom over a regular-wheelbase Range Rover. If you spring for the Executive seating package, you’ll get power rear seats and power folding leather tables for each rear passenger. And, of course, if you need it to climb a mountain or cross a river, it can do that, too.

Ford Edge Concept

The Ford Edge may not be the most exciting car in Ford’s lineup (case in point: rabid fans will finally get their first look at the 2015 Mustang on December 5), but that doesn’t mean it’s not worthy of a spot on Ford’s L.A. stand. Ford debuted its Edge Concept at this show, and although the car didn’t have any earth-shattering design changes, it did feature a host of safety and connectivity technologies that Ford plans to bring to its cars in coming years. The Edge Concept has a self-parking feature that allows drivers to park it using a remote control device, new technology that makes steering at low speeds much easier, adaptive cruise control, and a lane-keeping assist system. Many of these technologies are available today in luxury vehicles, but we’re happy to see that Ford is interested in bringing them to mass-market vehicles.

Nissan Sentra Nismo Concept

The Nissan Sentra as it exists today isn’t exactly an enthusiast’s dream. It’s a safe, solid, but determinedly run-of-the mill compact sedan that makes just 130 horsepower and fails to inspire daydreams of any kind. But the Sentra Nismo Concept that Nissan brought to this year’s Los Angeles Auto Show is anything but boring. It’s got a more aggressive front fascia, nineteen-inch wheels fitted with performance tires, Brembo brakes, and performance suspension parts. The 1.8-liter turbocharged engine is mated to a six-speed manual transmission and makes 240 horsepower and 240 pound-feet of torque. The Sentra Nismo Concept has traditional Nismo styling cues like red doorsill accents, Recaro front seats, a leather-and-Alcantara-wrapped steering wheel, and a rear spoiler. Nissan hasn’t said if it will bring the Sentra Nismo to the real world, but I sure hope so.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: I have a crush on a luxurious composite material. It’s Alcantara, a fake suede that is popping up in the interiors of vehicles from General Motors to Lamborghini. The last time an interior material received fame and fortune was the "fine Corinthian leather" that had Ricardo Montalban as the spokesperson. But watch out: there is a new material in town worthy of a spokesperson—Alcantara.

Enter Rosa Clandestino, a fashion house led by founder and creative director Silvia Arguello. In an interesting PR move, Alcantara partnered with Rosa Clandestino to showcase the high-end material in a high-fashion runway show during the Los Angeles Auto Show. With invitees ranging from designers to auto industry executives, the show took place at the gorgeous Vibiana—the former Cathedral of Saint Vibiana, now an event venue.

You may have seen Arguello (seated at left in this photo) as a contestant on the NBC reality-TV series Fashion Star, or if you are an astute fashionista, from Vogue Italia, Vogue Latin America, WWD, Corriere della Sera, Elle Italia or Grazia. The likes of Eva Longoria, Milla Jovovich, and Willa Holland choose to show up for red carpet events in her pieces. Although not the ultimate winner of Fashion Star, this Milan-based, U.S.-born, Honduras-raised designer is definitely still on trend to be a superstar designer. She is known for her blend of high tech and natural fabrics, so she was a perfect fit for this collaboration.

pageElements.text: “Alcantara is versatile, smooth, refined, and pliant,” Arguello noted, saying it is "an absolute luxury” to work with.

The Alcantara collection shown that night has a Sixties flair with baroque-inspired laser-cut details. The dresses are gorgeous, the setting was dramatic, and it was a perfect beginning to the L.A. Auto Show. Although these works of art were not intended for sale, I am going to keep an eye on both Rosa Clandestino and Alcantara; either one is welcome in my driveway or closet.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

Vital Stats


Base price: $33,315 (includes destination)
This car’s price: $38,715 (includes destination)
EPA fuel economy: 21 mpg city/30 mpg highway
Engine: 3.6-liter V-6, 292 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Safety features: City Safety low-speed collision avoidance system, six airbags, dynamic stability traction control, corner traction control, anti-whiplash system
Tech features: Keyless drive with personal car communicator, HomeLink, rearview camera (all part of $3,150 Premier Plus package)
Chief competitors: Cadillac ATS, BMW 3 Series, Volkswagen CC
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/GttGYdNSo5c?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
Key Points

• Safety is often a prime consideration when people shop for a Volvo. The S60 received five out of five stars in National Highway Traffic Safety Administration front, side, and rollover crash tests. The 2013 Volvo S60 is a 2013 Top Safety Pick Plus by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, scoring Good ratings in every category, including the small overlap front crash test. The 2014 S60 is a carryover model.

• The Volvo S60 stands out from the growing pack of luxury cars because it’s a crash-test ace. When NHTSA launched its more rigorous crash tests in 2011, the S60 stood out as one of the only cars to completely ace all of the revised tests’ categories.

•  The Volvo S60 has also grabbed lots of safety awards, including receiving a rating of Superior in a new front crash program by the IIHS for cars equipped with auto brake and forward collision warning. In test results released in September 2013, among the seventy-four moderately priced and luxury cars and SUVs tested, Volvo’s City Safety was the only low-speed crash prevention system offered as standard.  City Safety prevents low-speed collisions by monitoring traffic in front of the car. When driving at speeds between 2 mph and 19 mph, the car can automatically apply brakes to prevent fender benders. The IIHS notes that users of City Safety wind up filing about 27 percent fewer at-fault claims than drivers without the system.

• The car we tested has four options: The Premier Plus package ($3,150) includes a power glass moonroof, leather seating, keyless drive with a personal car communicator, power passenger's seat, an auto-dimming rearview mirror with compass, side-window brightwork, adaptive digital display, HomeLink, a rearview camera, and a grocery bag holder; the Sport package ($1,200) includes sport seats, paddle shifters, sixteen-inch alloy wheels, and a dynamic chassis; metallic paint ($550), and heated front seats ($500).
• The S60 T5 is the value leader in the S60 lineup.

• When the 2015 S60 comes out in late January in the U.S., the car will features a new eight-speed automatic transmission and a new 2.0-liter inline four-cylinder engine that uses both an Eaton supercharger and a Borg-Warner turbocharger. It’s the most potent gasoline engine in Volvo’s new Drive-E family of 2.0-liter engines.

• The new T5 and T6 four-cylinder engines will only be offered on front-drive models for the 2015 model year. All-wheel-drive models will continue to use Volvo’s five- and six-cylinder engines for a couple more years.

pageElements.text:
The Farmer in All of Us: An American Portrait ($45)

Yesterday was a day to be thankful, and I am personally thankful for all the farmers who grow our food. At the Super Bowl last February, the Ram truck brand ran an ad that featured American farmers and launched a year-long initiative to bring attention to American farmers. Now a book is available to showcase the year, and up to $1 million of the proceeds of the sales of the book will be donated to the Future Farmers of America. Love. Get the book.

Corvette Bowtie Neon Sign ($359)

The Corvette turned 100 this year, and nothing says happy birthday better than neon. I can immediately think of three people on my list who would swoon for this.

Volkswagen Bus Tent ($650)

I have always wanted a VW bus. Now I can buy one for under $1,000. (Or many other, less expensive VW-logo-bearing items from the same site.)

Drop Stop ($19.95)

I am a sucker for infomercials, but I think these two guys will win you over, too. No free Ginsu knives, but there are two freebies.

Mini Car Wash (free)

This is my Black Friday gift to you. No need to say thanks, but if you insist, share a comment at the end of this article.

Ladies’ Vintage Derby Cap ($14.95)

For all the Mustang Sallys out there, here is a chapeau that is worthy of both you and your ride. Ride, Sally, ride.

BMW Baby Racer II ($108)

There is no reason to wait until your baby turns sweet sixteen to buy his or her first car.

Women’s Prancing Horse Ultra-Shiny Nylon Jacket ($357)

Everyone and your mother has a black puffy coat, but I have never seen one with a little red prancing horse, and I have a weakness for anything shiny.

Vintage Overnight Bag ($35)

When I was knee-high to a grasshopper, my swim bag looked exactly like this one, and I thought it was the bees' knees. Now Fiat has made one even better: it is red, and it says Fiat. Winner.

Richard Scarry's Cars and Trucks from A to Z ($3.99)

This book is not a new release, but it is a must-have for any little nuggets on your gift list. The crayon car is my fave.

pageElements.text: At the L.A. Auto Show, Kia design chief Peter Schreyer walked me around the company's rear-wheel-drive flagship, the 2015 Kia K900, which is expected to be priced starting above $50,000 when it goes on sale next spring. Automobile Magazine named Schreyer our 2012 Man of the Year because of his impact on the Korean company's product lineup. As automotive design editor Robert Cumberford wrote:

"Six years ago, Kia cars were nondescript tin boxes of no particular consequence in the grand scheme of things, sold on price and certainly not as world-class desirable objects. Today's Kia range is admired, respected, even envied. Its cars are well-made, good performers, and—above all—good-looking. That quality can essentially be attributed to one man, Peter Schreyer, chief design officer for Kia and our unanimously chosen Man of the Year."

pageElements.text: Pop the champagne corks! There is a momentous news flash today. General Motors has named Mary Barra, 51, its next chief executive officer.
The announcement came from chairman and CEO Dan Akerson, and Barra will take the title of CEO when Akerson steps down at the first of the year.
If anyone wants to know how far General Motors has come since the Troubles? Mary Barra becomes the first female CEO of a car company in history.

Mary Barra has been quickly gaining gravitas. She came out of HR to be named head of global product development, and then earlier this year added global head of product purchasing. I know her, and I've always liked her. Her persona is best older sister. Her personality is calm in the eye of a storm. She is passionate about General Motors and passionate about the people who work there, and she has teenagers. In fact, she recently blew out the stodgy GM dress code and was quoted in Businessweek saying, “So you’re telling me I can have you responsible for tens of millions of dollars, but I can’t trust you to dress appropriately?”

The only other candidate for this job in our eyes was Mark Reuss, who is president of General Motors North America. He is a consummate product guy, which is really what this business is about: great product. But it makes sense to keep your product guy in a position where he won't be burdened by the compromises that frequently have to be made in big business. 
As enthusiasts, we were pulling for him, but the argument against putting your product guy at the top was in fact, his own father, a great product guy, who took a fall as a scapegoat for the problems of General Motors. When Lloyd Reuss lost his position on the board, General Motors and all its customers lost a great product guy.

In my estimation, Mary Barra only has to do a couple of things. The cars can't break; she has to manage production so the cars aren't overproduced; and she has to make GM manage incentives so they don't take over and ruin the gains that have been made in the past few years.
More important is that she has to count on Mark Reuss, who has highly refined product sensibilities, and Ed Welburn, who has done a masterful job bringing General Motors design out of the darkness.
It's an incredible team. And the fact that it is going to be run by a woman is one of the most amazing feelings I have had in a really, really long time.

title: 2014 Mazda 3 S Grand Touring
subTitle: In search of the elusive Holiday Spirit in a great little car for adventure.
promoTeaserSmall: In search of the elusive Holiday Spirit in a great little car for adventure.
promoTeaser: In search of the elusive Holiday Spirit in a great little car for adventure.
metaDescription: 2014 Mazda 3 S Grand Touring: I headed off in search of that elusive animal, holiday spirit. Well, getting there was way more than half the fun. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
Price: $29,185 as tested, including destination
Engine: 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 184 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic with Sport mode
Fuel economy: 28 mpg city/38 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Rearview camera
Option I can’t live without: Navigation system (a no-cost option)
You might also be considering: Ford Focus, Hyundai Elantra, Nissan Altima, Volkswagen Golf

As I grow older, I can feel my levels of adrenaline and other risk-taking hormones plummeting year by year. Never a thrill seeker on my best day, nowadays I am increasingly interested in staying home and staying comfortable.
It’s for that reason that the Mazda 3 was such a revelation to me. This is a reasonably priced car that you can climb into and immediately feel young, adventurous, and ready for anything.

Well, maybe not ready for towing a boat, or carrying a family of six, but anything that a person on her own might find fun. It is for that reason that I climbed out of my dull, ordinary weekend routine and took a little road trip. My goal (other than enjoying the drive) was to stalk that elusive animal, Holiday Spirit, to its small-town lair.

One place where the Christmas frame of mind was advertised as still alive and well is the town of Holly, Michigan, about an hour’s drive north of Ann Arbor. Philosophically, it’s several decades removed: five miles off the expressway, with no city, shopping mall, or chain store anywhere within range, and with a deliberately charming main shopping area. My choice of a drive up to Holly was determined by the fact that the 40th Annual Charles Dickens Festival was in progress. Would this warm my Grinch-like heart or sicken me? I was about to find out.

It was a good thing I started my trip by heading north on the always unpleasant U.S. 23 North, because it made me appreciate the Mazda 3 immediately. There is something about this unremarkable straight stretch of divided highway that makes people drive like idiots. They tailgate, they speed, they pass unsafely, and they talk on the phone while they’re doing it. So I was especially enjoying the Mazda driving experience and the Mazda 3’s ability to pour on the power instantly, whenever I asked for it.  You always hear cars referred to as “nimble,” but in the case of the 2014 Mazda 3, that is not an exaggeration.

High Praise for the Mazda 3

The car I was driving was the five-door model in top-end Grand Touring trim. It has many of the modern features that I am quickly coming to find indispensable: push-button start, heated front seats, rain-sensing wipers, a seven-inch touchscreen display, and a navigation system. In the case of the Mazda, it was a navigation system that was so intuitive that I actually used it instead of asking Siri on my iPhone for directions, and that is high praise.

The safety features are also up to date: blind spot monitoring, rear cross-traffic alert, traction control, and a rearview camera. And did you see those mpg numbers (28/38 mpg), thanks to Mazda’s Skyactiv engine technology? All of this for an out-the-door price under $30,000. The price of entry to the Mazda 3 family is a very youth-friendly $17,740 (including destination) for the base four-door S with the 2.0-liter four-cylinder making 155 horsepower and a six-speed manual transmission. That one gets 29 mpg in town and a sterling 41 mpg on the highway.
This is a car that knows who it’s for: enthusiastic young drivers, the kind without a lot of money but with plenty of taste. Everything is just right for that driver.

This is the third generation of the Mazda 3, and as the automaker says, it’s “all new from the ground up.” It is already critically acclaimed for its sleek, attractive, dare I say hip, yet not extreme styling, and for how much zoom-zoom you get per dollar. It was even a finalist for our brother publication Automobile Magazine’s 2014 Automobile of the Year award, high praise indeed for what used to be dismissed as an economy car.

The energetic, rewarding driving experience, the comfortable, cosseting driver’s seat, the expensive appearance, and the miserly fuel economy all combine to make you ask yourself, What am I doing just sitting here when I could be driving?

Where Is Charles Dickens When You Need Him?

After leaving U.S. 23 at the town of Fenton, I had the best part of the drive ahead of me: five miles down the evocatively named Grange Hall Road and then up North Saginaw Street into Holly. I was pleased to see that these, unlike the highway, were gently curving roads with very little competition from other cars. I thought it would be nice to wash the car, but after unwisely bypassing a mom-and-pop shop right at the highway exit, I never found another. Nor did I see a McDonald’s, a Starbucks, or any of the other bright and shiny detritus of modern life. It was handpainted signs and tree farms all the way.

Pulling in to the main drag in Holly, there were unmistakable signs of small-town Michigan life that I recognized from my childhood in a burg with population 4,300. Kiwanis Club guys were standing in the middle of the street, asking for donations at red lights, which they dropped into red buckets. The streets were being blocked off by logs on stands painted orange, block-party style.  And slowly at first, but in growing numbers as the afternoon wore on, I spotted people dressed in what, to central Michigan, passes for authentic Victorian apparel. Yes, some of this was about pulling in tourists from the Detroit suburbs, and there they were, crowding the six (count ‘em) antique and gift shops that line Saginaw Street downtown. I wound my way through them, too, comforted by knowing that my Mazda 3 couldn’t fit any of the charming antique furniture that was selling for reasonable prices at The Pigeon in the Parlour in its 1865 building. I did buy a little hardcover book with a pigeon on the spine, which opens to reveal a secret compartment. See if you can find it in my house, burglars!

Then, on the edge of the railroad tracks that cross diagonally right through the heart of town, I spotted the Historic Holly Hotel, which is just as creaky-looking and old as its name implies. No fake-restored McMansion here. You make your way up onto the elderly porch on the side, and once inside, it’s a plush Victorian refuge from the twenty-first century. I held the door for a mother and daughter; the mother, struggling up the stairs with the aid of a walker, was in her Sunday best and elaborately done hair, while the daughter was rocking a hand-knit Christmas sweater. This was obviously a much-looked-forward-to occasion for them.

High Tea, Middle American Style

I was seated in a comfortable booth deep in the bowels of the hotel and offered High Tea. This is something you don’t often see in mid-Michigan. I remembered where I was, though, when the waitress offered me a tray of tea bags with a pot full of hot water instead of brewed tea, and when I asked for Earl Grey and was met with a look of incomprehension. “We don’t got any of that, but you might want to try this Oblong tea. It’s pretty popular,” she said, pointing to the Oolong tea bags. (I settled for English Breakfast. It was fine, and the salmon, dried-cherry salad, and scones were all excellent.) The Holly Hotel also trades on its glamorous interior with elaborate Sunday brunches and dinners, “fairy” tea events for children, and other special meal occasions. Worth the drive—but bring your own Earl Grey unless you want to try the Oblong Tea for yourself.

Now in the mood for Dickens, I made my way through Battle Alley, named for its reputation as a street-brawling kind of place in the long-gone days when train travel brought lots of partiers through town, and over to where the Lions Club was putting on A Christmas Carol in a kind of beer tent on a side street. Townspeople, more than out-of-town shoppers, seemed to fill this audience. They were seated on long benches, bundled up against the cold while a roaring propane heater almost drowned out the dialogue. Clearly, the actors were enthusiastic amateur locals, and they were really in the spirit of the thing. After watching them thoroughly revel in their moment upon the makeshift stage, I am not sure I want to watch any lavish PBS versions of this story ever again.

Being Here Now

When I was a young hippie, I had a book called Be Here Now. The lesson from that is as important to me now as it was then: the secret of happiness is, really, to be where, who, and what you are, and not covet another life, another experience, or another reality. In the little town of Holly, where they are ambitious enough to honor Charles Dickens, they are being the creaky little village they are, and enjoying it. Sure, there must be teenagers here who are numbering the days until they can move to Chicago or anywhere but Holly. But, if the specially constructed sledding hill, the street carts of food (“Bless their hearts being out in this snow!!!” commented someone about a Facebook photo of the street barbecue), and the choirs of high-schoolers dressed all in red hats, cheerfully mobbing the street corner, lead me to think, this is a town that knows how to be what it really is.

Which inevitably leads me back to the Mazda 3. This is a car that knows who it’s for: enthusiastic young drivers, the kind without a lot of money but with plenty of taste. Everything on this car is just right for that driver, from the appealing exterior to the plethora of safety features to the delicious feel of your hands on the steering wheel commanding it. I’m no twenty-five-year-old, but like the town of Holly, I can look back and honor the twenty-five-year-old I once was by holding a festive commemorative weekend, and that’s exactly what I did.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I had a throwaway 2004 Kia Rio, a car that I purchased for a family member in 2008 (and wrote about in a column in Automobile Magazine). Today's Kia Rio is a great little car. Ten years ago, the Rio, for a throwaway car, was pretty damn good, but as it approached its next timing belt replacement called for by maintenance, it was gliding on its path down to where everything that needed to be repaired cost $500. So, rather than be $500ed to death, I went into buy-a-used-car mode and decided I'd donate the old Kia to charity, which I eventually did (as you see from the photo). But first, I had to deal with the dealers to replace it.

It began with looking at newspaper ads, and it ended with a trip to two good car dealerships in Ann Arbor. One turned out to be not so good; the other one, a dealership where we had previously made videos on the car-buying comfort zone and relationship building, was everything I thought it should be and would be, and it was even more than that.

I suppose anyone can have a bad experience, so I’d like to tell you exactly what made it bad. First, it was the phone calls. No matter what I said or didn't say to him, the salesman incessantly called me to the point of annoyance. Then, the car wasn’t ready when they said it would be. The paperwork they gave me was Experian’s version of Carfax, which looked on the up and up, so I decided to take the used car for a quick ride around the parking lot, and the noise it made was horrendous. It was abominable. The salesman kept pointing out all the extra features on it. I, of course, said I didn’t give a shit about the features; I cared that the car was in good shape and was going to run.

In the meantime, I got three email messages (and no phone calls) from our friend at Dunning Toyota, Beth Bashert. Each email message had a link to complete information on each of the cars that met my requirements. From that, I could quickly pick three hot prospects. One of them was a super nice prospect, but it took me three days to get there, and that car had flown out the door by then. But she had a couple of new things to show me.

It was a snowy evening. Beth had Carfax reports waiting for me. The cars that I looked at were super clean, and she gave me a sheaf of papers to go with them, including the checklist that her dealership goes through when a used car comes in and the service papers that detailed every single thing they did to the car in response to the checklist. I narrowed it down to a Saturn: a one-owner car, ten years old, with 70,000 miles on it, which is way below the average. There was not a dent, scratch, bubble...nothing wrong with the car.

I took it for a drive, and it was like brand-new inside. In the drive, the steering was absolutely tight, the brakes were perfect, and there wasn’t a rattle or a squeak in this car. Beth said her short list of cars for me were all nameplates that she hadn’t experienced any problems with. She said that’s the best you can do, and I agree: that’s about as honest as you can be.

The paperwork was done immediately. We negotiated a tiny bit from the price, which she didn’t want to do as it had just arrived, and she immediately suggested she could get me a super-good deal from the University of Michigan Credit Union, which she did. All the negotiating was done and handled within thirty minutes.
There’s a point where you say, Is the deal fair? Is the car good? It was just like I had bought a new car; that was the quality of the experience.

Of course, you’re not me, and of course the people at Dunning Toyota knew exactly who I am. On the other hand, the price was good, the mileage was good, the car was good, and it was all fair. There’s a point where you say, Is the deal fair? Is the car good? When I came to get the car, it was inside so it could be under lights to look at it; it was clean, it was filled with gas, and all the paperwork and title were ready. When the plate arrived, they put it on. It was just like I had bought a new car; that was the quality of the experience.

The people at the other dealership knew exactly who I was, too, and yet here was my experience there: The car wasn’t ready. When I asked them to see all the paperwork on the mechanics of the car, they were gone for ten minutes and came back and said, “Jeez, I guess this one slipped through the cracks, and nothing was ever done.” It’s beyond crazy, since the guy called me more than five times, set up the appointment, said he’d bring the car over from the other lot to the main dealership and have it ready for me, and if he’s not there, so-and-so will be there, it’s all handled. He did tell me there was a little miss in the engine because it had been steam cleaned, and he didn’t want me to see it until they’d serviced it, and then said it was all set. All set? It was a complete rattletrap.

I started by going in not really happy with the salesperson but giving him the benefit of the doubt. Then I had to endure his try to talk to me about all the hot options on this ten-year-old car, when I had told him clearly I just needed a car that was clean and running well. He wasn’t listening to me, the car was not ready, and then he gave me the non-Carfax thing that said the car was priced “below its value” and “sale priced” without giving me the information I really needed. It was easy to get up and walk out. He gave me no other options.
It was like they’d just swept it out and stuck it on the lot. I was not worth their while. The car was not worth their while.

It was such a bad experience from beginning to end. First, being harangued by this dealer at home, at work, and on my cell phone, although I told him I was traveling and busy. Then, having a car presented to me that hadn’t even gone through any checkpoints. It was like they’d just swept it out and stuck it on the lot. I was not worth their while, and the car was not worth their while. If they knew who I was, imagine your experience.

The truth is, people who buy used cars deserve just as much respect as people who buy new cars. As Skip LeFauve, the first head of Saturn, once said to me, “I would argue that people who are spending under $15,000 deserve even more help from a salesperson and more respect and courtesy, because they’re spending a greater proportion of their income.” Isn’t that an amazing thought?

And that’s how I was treated by Beth Bashert. It was worth her while; the car was worthy; and I was worth it because to her, as you know, if you treat somebody right, you have them for the rest of your life. I’ve sung her praises to people before I even bought a car from her, just from talking to her about the process. I’ll say it one more time, I love car dealers. Let me rephrase that: I love good car dealers.

pageElements.text: This all begs the question that’s burning in my mind. “Will my next car do the driving so I can have back all that time I waste on long freeway drives and bumper-to-bumper traffic?”
“This is all in the research stage,” BMW’s Werner Huber  told me with a sly smile. “Though technically we are very close to a car that can do that."

“This is all in the research stage,” BMW’s Werner Huber told me with a sly smile. “Though technically we are very close to a car that can do that.” He is head of Driver Assistance and Environmental Perception at BMW Group Research and Technology. But just because the technology exists doesn’t mean you can buy it. Sure, you'll have a choice of cars that can park themselves in the next couple of years. But a fully automated car is a long way off. And one reason for that is evident in Bosch’s demonstration of that self-parking car technology.

Before that demonstration car would park, the driver had to accept a liability waiver. And the app he used to manage the parking remotely requires that the driver touch an icon while the car parks. If he lifts his finger off the icon, the car stops. There is a good reason for this.

“The driver must always be in control of the car, even if the car is in an automatic mode,” explained Huber. Legally, the liability for anything the car does must be with the human. So, even though research prototype automated cars can technically do a lot of things on their own, we can’t let them. Allowing the car to drive means changing laws that vary by state and country and that have governed transportation for decades. No easy task. And not a task that is likely to happen in time for me to start shopping for a fully automatic car anytime soon.

Until the legal landscape is clear, explains Huber, car manufacturers will keep testing the limits of human control of the vehicle. Cars will increasingly correct mistakes, take over some of the driving chores, and intervene in case of emergency by braking or correcting the human's steering. Cars might be able to take over in some circumstances or at some speeds. But the driver will have to maintain ultimate decision making power.
And that is bad news for that nap I was hoping to take during my commute.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: When I called to confirm that I would be attending the Land Rover Driving School at the glamorous Biltmore Estate in Asheville, North Carolina, I was informed that I couldn’t come unless I brought along my eighty-six-year-old Aunt Mimi. After reading about my last driving adventure with Mimi on this website, everyone at Land Rover was eager to meet her.
One call to Mimi confirmed it. She answered without hesitation, “Just tell me the date, time and place. I’m all packed!”

Mimi informed me that she had not driven an off-road vehicle since the 1950s, when she and her husband, Alan, who was in the Air Force, were stationed in Newfoundland. She got around in the snowy conditions in a Triumph Mayflower, a small British four-seater, which was plenty sturdy but nothing compared to a Land Rover.
I thought, “Oh no! How is Mimi ever going to get behind the wheel of a Land Rover on a rough off-road course? She is going to freak!”

I was so wrong. Let me preface this by saying that I have been taking adventures with Land Rover for well over a decade in places as wild as the mountains of Argentina, the dunes of Mongolia’s Gobi Desert, and the canyons of southern Utah. Several years ago, I took the off-road course at the Biltmore. I remember being so scared that my instructor, Greg Nicklaus, told me to calm down and appreciate the Zen of the experience. By serendipity, Nicklaus was the same instructor that Mimi and I had on this trip.
We would be experiencing mangled roads with rocky, knee-deep puddles, mud, ice, tree stumps, steep hills, and unknown obstacles. Mimi’s response was, “I want to go fast!"

But Mimi was not at all frightened. After Nicklaus explained that we would be experiencing mangled roads with rocky, knee deep puddles, mud, ice, tree stumps, steep hills, and other unknown obstacles, Mimi’s response was, “I want to go fast!”

Nicklaus calmly informed her, “Slow and steady is the word here.” He gave us a user-friendly explanation of how to shuffle the wheel (let it slide between your hands) and the terrain response system (one simply turns a knob to suit the terrain: grass/gravel/snow, mud/ruts, sand and rock or auto). He also educated us on using hill descent control: you take your foot off the gas and the brake when descending a hill, and the vehicle takes over.

Mimi exclaimed as she was driving over our first rutted road, “This car practically drives itself!”  Greg reminded her to go easy on the gas, keep her foot off the brake, and center the wheel to prevent us from sashaying. Mimi’s reply, “These tires are like dancing shoes rather than hiking boots—this vehicle is so graceful!”
Our instructor educated us on using hill descent control: you take your foot off the gas and the brake when descending a hill, and the vehicle takes over.
After the hill, there was a series of bumpy ruts and puddles. “Hello baby,” said Mimi, “I’m in mud and there’s no road here!”
“Mimi you're a rock star!”  exclaimed Nicklaus.
She answered, “You mean because I'm going through rocks?”
Yes. In fact, at that point Mimi was driving on two wheels.
To describe what this course looked like, we got out of our car to watch the other students take the rocky path. Nicklaus lowered the suspension so that Mimi could get out easily. She was impressed.
“My friend has an SUV, but we need a ladder to get into it,” she quipped.

And there’s more, I explained as we got back into the Range Rover. “These seats can heat, cool, and massage. And look at all the beautiful wood inlays and soft leathers they use,” I bragged. Mimi cooed,  “This interior is as handsome as a piece of Elizabeth Taylor’s jewelry…it shines!”
As we approached the next butte, Nicklaus said, “We are going to drop down on a hillside to your left.”
Mimi uncharacteristically faltered for a second. “I can’t see what’s below me!”
Nicklaus noted calmly: “There’s nothing to it. Take your foot off the gas and the brake, and let the machine do its job.”

As Mimi slowly lowered the vehicle down into one and a half feet of mud, she smiled. “This is a lot different than driving on a racetrack in an Aston Martin. How fast does this car go on the autobahn?”
Nicklaus replied: "You’re bringing a tear to my eye. You’ve got it! You are in control of this vehicle.”
Mimi’s comeback? “If I had a Range Rover in Atlanta, I could maneuver through all of our traffic with the ease of a gazelle.”

About a week later, Mimi sent me this e-mail: "As I think back on the wonderful weekend in North Carolina, all I can really recall at my senior age is the thrill of driving the Range Rover. Wow!  It was the thrill of my lifetime. The car, although I must say it's much more than a car, was the smoothest feeling of travel I've ever experienced.  Sure, there were bumps and grinds …the logs crossed our paths, the mud holes were knee deep, the creeks crossed were uncharitable, the cliffs climbed were rocky and daring, I never once winced because this Rover was so luxurious and solid-feeling. I felt like I am in the arms of an Atlas or Arnold Schwarzenegger (in his youth, of course.)”

pageElements.text: And then there was the Biltmore. The 8,000-acre estate is the historic home of George W. Vanderbilt. Building started in 1889, in the style of a French Renaissance chateau, and it formally opened on Christmas Eve 1895. Besides taking part in the driving school, we were invited to a private candlelight tour of the estate. The mansion has more than four acres of floor space, including thirty-five bedrooms, forty-three bathrooms, sixty-five fireplaces, an indoor pool, and a bowling alley. Frederick Law Olmstead, who created Central Park in New York City and Elm Park in Worcester, Massachusetts, designed the Biltmore’s vast gardens.

pageElements.text: It's so fun to unwrap new things. No doubt, a huge part of the appeal of Detroit's auto show, officially known as the North American International Auto Show, is the fact that there will be unveilings of concepts and new production models.  But there's also the enjoyable feeling, when walking in to Cobo Center near Detroit's riverfront, of joining the crowd. It's a great thing to start your day by being a happy cog in the swiftly moving wheel of the global auto industry.

A bright spot in the slushy, gray-sky landscape of January in Michigan, the auto show media preview days mean hordes of reporters for everything from lowly blogs to the Wall Street Journal and the major networks; auto company executives, designers, and marketing people from the corners of the globe; and photographers and video crews everywhere you turn. It's an education in the European-cut men's suit, the languages of many nations, and the psychology of crowds. It's also a brilliantly colored Disneyland of sheetmetal. Over here: a phalanx of Smart Fortwo microcars, including the Jeremy Scott version with wings and, more to my taste, a Brabus special edition in orange and teal. Love it! Over there: more BMWs in one place than you have ever seen if your kid doesn't go to Stanford.

The techno music, the endlessly looping supersize videos, and the camera shutters are everywhere, and they never stop. Another person who never stops: Jean Jennings, who made the rounds today and shot a half-dozen videos in which she interviewed the brilliant designers of some of the most intriguing introductions of the year. We'll be posting these soon! Meanwhile, here's some of what I appreciated at the opening press day of the Detroit show.

The day started with the introduction of an aluminum-bodied, completely redesigned Ford F-150. It took place in the nearby Joe Louis Arena, where the Detroit Red Wings hockey team play. I had hoped the truck would be dropped from the sky or driven through a wall of ice, or something. Although the rollout was more straightforward, the new model is a definite game changer. As truck buyers expect, it can be configured in many ways, including five trim levels and four engine choices--one is a new 2.7-liter EcoBoost with auto start-stop, not the macho option but maybe the smart option. Fuel economy numbers aren't out yet, but that 700-pound weight saving from using aluminum ought to be a big help.

The 2015 Ford F-150 also gets a 360-degree rearview camera and a plethora of driver assist features, including "trailer hitch assist" and a remote-opening tailgate....does that mean the average person could dare to pull the boat down to the lake without two or three more mechanical friends in the car with her? The sound you hear is, not more techno music, but the echo of America's klutzes and women of smaller size (or lesser strength) applauding.

When I saw Ford's Atlas concept at last year's Detroit show, I was mesmerized by the sheer muscular beauty of it. The 2015 F-150 is the production version of that gorgeous specimen. Do you like big trucks? I do. This one will be on sale by the end of the year.

The Audi Allroad shooting brake concept was unveiled to universal acclaim by everybody around me, including our photographer, Susan Campbell, who said she had a serious car crush on the little wagon. Me, too, although it would qualify more as a shooting brake for hunting very short bunnies, based on its diminutive size. (It does seat four, though.) But besides being cute, the Allroad concept is a hybrid with intriguing advanced connectivity. The "e-tron" graphic on its side signifies that it has "e-tron quattro" technology: powerful yet fuel sipping, with a plug-in hybrid powertrain that will garner an estimated 123 mpg. It has a smartphone-style menu in its airplane-inspired instrument panel. Just one example: when it senses a hand approaching, the climate controls automatically open out.

At Kia, I was pleasantly confirmed in my belief I'd be impressed by the top-end K900, which made its debut at the Los Angeles Auto Show and so got less attention in Detroit. But I was less excited by the Stinger concept, which was unveiled here this afternoon. What is it about this bulbous yellow body that I didn't like? Can't put my finger on it, but I have to appreciate Kia's energy in bringing out an ambitious rear-wheel-drive concept car in Detroit. It is designed to use a version of the engine used in the Korean automaker's racing Optimas from the Pirelli World Challenge, a 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder. Korean muscle car? Sort of. Videographer Scott Allen couldn't stop looking at it.

Really, we barely touched the surface, and tomorrow will be another day in which I'm looking forward to getting a good look at the 2015 Honda Fit, rolled out this afternoon, as well as the Chrysler 200 and other cars I expect to love.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: It seems counterintuitive to shop for a $35,000 car on the basis of how it accommodates one's $50 handbag, but the fact is, a woman’s purse is her essential traveling companion.  Thanks to the automotive trend of cockpit styling, our purses are relegated to the passenger’s seat, the passenger’s lap, or, most often, the floor. Women would rather not have that coveted Coach bag, or even our thrift store find, sitting in winter sludge or kicked by our teenager’s combat boots.

And so my sister, Sandy, and I undertook a noble quest.  Armed with my compact utility bag and her fancier overstuffed purse (clues to who was the tomboy and who was the girly girl as kids), we set out to scour Detroit’s North American International Auto Show in search of the vehicles able to fit a woman and her nylon or leather sidekick comfortably.

Unfortunately, we found the pickings very slim. The perfect car must have dedicated space for the average purse to fit easily. That space has to be adjacent to the driver’s seat, yet not in the way of vehicle operation.
We didn't do a scientific test or get out the measuring tape, and we saw only a selection of cars. Your nominations for really good (or bad) candidates are welcome!

Luxury brands were most disappointing. From Audi to Volvo, they all claim to anticipate your every need but have little purse allowance in their wood-veneered center columns. Frustrated, we set our bags on cup holders or emergency brakes and watched hinged compartments gobble or trap them (I'm talking to you, Mazda CX-9).
We marveled at how even the Range Rover Sport, with separate armrests and a center divide as vast as the Grand Canyon, couldn’t spare a square inch for our wayward bags.

Still we persevered and, making our way around the show floor, we found a few rare vehicles worthy of honors in our highly subjective Golden Clutch Awards. It's important to point out that we didn't do a scientific test or get out the measuring tape, and we saw only a selection of cars and trucks. Your suggestions for really good (or really bad) Golden Clutch candidates would be very welcome!

And the Winner Is: Tesla Model S

You’ve probably heard about this revolutionary plug-in electric five-seat sedan that excels in visual design and mechanical innovation. But did you know it has the most exquisite spot for your purse? A panoramic sunroof sheds loads of light on a slightly futuristic interior. A generous ridged wood-grain storage tray splits the floor between driver’s and passenger’s sides, ideal for any size of bag. Why so roomy? Because a seventeen-inch touchscreen manages all the car’s controls, eliminating the need for a busy center stack. On top of this glorious bag space, Tesla says you can add a Premium Center Console as a “place to rest your phone,” but I already have a place to rest my phone: inside my purse. Now if only I had about $80,000 in that purse to pay for the Tesla.

And the Winner in the Back-to-Reality Category Is: Toyota Highlander

The Highlander SUV has a brilliantly conceived armrest with two garage-style doors that retract fully to reveal a deep compartment wide enough for a sizable purse. It can close completely or stay open for easy access without sacrificing a spot to rest your arm. Starting around $30,000, the Toyota's appealing standard options include voice controls and a rearview camera. Model choices allow for seven or eight passengers, and a Hybrid is available, meaning there is probably a Highlander to suit everyone and their daily baggage.

Close Seconds: Honda Odyssey and Toyota Sienna

Preconceived minivan notions aside, it is cool to slide into a captain’s chair and effortlessly drop your purse into the lovely large cavern between the center stack and the cup holders. Honda’s Odyssey, an unapologetic utilitarian with great visibility, comfort, and decent gas mileage, is ready to handle the road as well as the softball team. A superior hostess, the Odyssey not only keeps your purse handy, but some models even have an in-car cooler and vacuum. Such versatility will put you in the $35,000 range and higher.

The similarly priced Toyota Sienna was wonderfully accommodating of our bags, especially the molded plastic floor tray that safeguards one’s purse from the indignity of sitting directly on the carpet. The Sienna’s interior is a bit more stylized than the Odyssey's, with an asymmetrical dash swooping toward the driver. Add in terrific seat management, including an effortlessly folding third row, and you’ve got a vehicle that will get you and your personal tool kit through anything.

Runners Up, Way Up: GMC Sierra and Cadillac Escalade

We literally climbed up into these two GM behemoths and noticed they boast similar square armrests that house roomy compartments beneath padded hinged tops. The Sierra pickup, starting around $27,000, has a serviceable interior and will haul more than your jean hobo bag with a range of cab and bed configurations. At upward of $70,000, the Escalade (right) is expensive, thirsty, and massive but can transport your Fendi tote, a group of friends, and their golf clubs in ridiculous style.

Honorable Mention: Scion IQ and BMW Z4 sDrive 35is

The tiny two-door Scion IQ (right) was one of the least expensive cars we saw at the auto show, starting around $17,000. Surprisingly, our bags tucked nicely in a space behind the emergency brake.

On the opposite end of the spectrum, the racy BMW Z4 sDrive 35is convertible, which starts above $65,000, seemed built for speed as well as our purses. Not a practical choice for most of us, but with 335 horsepower, you can set your bag on the shelf behind the two Kansas leather seats and let your cares fly out the open top.

title: Minicars Bomb Latest Crash Test
subTitle: How worried should you be? What you need to know about new crash test scores.
promoTeaserSmall: How worried should you be? What you need to know about new crash test scores.
promoTeaser: How worried should you be? What you need to know about new crash test scores.
metaTitle: Minicars Bomb Latest Crash Test - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Minicars Bomb Latest Crash Test: How worried should you be about minicar safety? What you need to know about new crash test scores. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: You see them toddling down the street and think, “How cute!” Minicars like the Chevrolet Spark, the Fiat 500, and the Honda Fit are indeed adorable, plus fuel-efficient and affordable. But how safe are they out on the road next to semis and SUVs?

The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety has just released results of its most modern of crash tests, the “small overlap front” test. This test has only been in use since 2012. It’s intended to show what happens to a car when it hits another vehicle, or a solid object such as a telephone pole, not head on but in an offset crash. The testing crashes the car into a rigid barrier at 40 mph, with 25 percent of the car’s front end making contact.
Here are the results for all the minicars tested, and the detailed chart is below. Note: not one received the top Good rating overall. That's none.

Overall Acceptable

Chevrolet Spark

Overall Marginal

Mazda 2 (right), Kia Rio, Toyota Yaris, Ford Fiesta

Overall Poor

Mitsubishi Mirage, Nissan Versa sedan, Toyota Prius c (right), Hyundai Accent, Fiat 500, Honda Fit

The top-rated car, the Chevrolet Spark, was also named a 2014 Top Safety Pick. It was the only car in the group to earn that coveted moniker. IIHS commented that, in the Spark's crash, "the dummy's movement was fairly well controlled and its injury measures were low," suggesting that the structure in the lower part of the inside passenger compartment held up better than in the other minicars.

The bottom-rated cars were the Honda Fit (right) and the Fiat 500. The Fiat's driver's-side tore "tore open at the hinges," IIHS said, and both cars experienced "seriously compromised...driver space" after the crash. In both cars, the steering column was pushed back toward the driver, and the crash test dummy's head did not remain in contact with the driver's-side air bag after the impact.
As they have done historically, automakers will undoubtedly revise future models so they get better scores on the next round of tests.

The Good News Is...

There's a small silver lining in the test results: Every one of these cars got Good scores on at least some of the injury measures to the crash test dummy, which ameliorates the shock of the overall poor grades. The Spark was rated Good for all four: head and neck, chest and thigh, hip, and lower leg and foot. Even the lowest-ranked Honda Fit got Good scores for dummy upper body injury.

The frightening part is how badly they all did on the Structure rating. The Versa, Prius c, Accent, 500, and Fit all got the lowest score of Poor here, and the structure of every other car—including the Spark—was rated Marginal.

Reality Check

Keep this in mind: Minicars have not suddenly become less safe than they were before. The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration are continuing to raise the bar for what “safe” means. For that I say, Bravo! It’s the mission we are hoping they are on. IIHS even states that the reason it came out with the offset crash test was "to help drive further improvements in frontal crash protection." But despite that perspective, yes, minicars are still likely to be in more trouble in an accident. Almost every cars is safer today than ever before, but size does, in fact matter. The structure of these little cars is not holding up as well as we’d all like when faced with a difficult smashup. If you really want to dive into the testing and what it measures, check out this detailed explanation of all IIHS's frontal crash tests.

The good news for consumers is that the car companies take these test results very, very seriously. As they have done historically, automakers will undoubtedly revise future models so they get better scores on the next round of tests. (For example, IIHS says most vehicles were rated Poor or Marginal when it started running another crash test, the "moderate overlap frontal" crash. Today, the "vast majority" are rated Good.)

And that’s great for the people inside minicars—and the people inside bigger cars who don’t want to hurt them.

pageElements.text: The Lincoln Navigator goes EcoBoost: Is that a mixed message? It’s the luxury SUV that has been immortalized in songs by the likes of rap star Young Jeezy and R&B A-lister R Kelly. Has it come home from the party now that it has adopted a 3.5-liter EcoBoost V-6 instead of its old V-8? More to the point, has the recently rebranded Lincoln Motor Company done anything to offend the loyal fans of the luxury barge?

It doesn't look like it. It's a good thing that the 5.4-liter V-8 engine is gone; after all, it has been there since the Navigator was introduced in 1997. The twin-turbocharged EcoBoost V-6 offers an estimated 370 horsepower, up from the 310 that the big SUV had before, plus 430 pound-feet of torque, up from 365. Lincoln says it expects the new Navigator to have best-in-class towing capability when the final numbers are out. So, if you're looking at the utility aspect of the Lincoln Navigator, not to worry.

The 2015 Lincoln Navigator will be officially unveiled at the Chicago Auto Show on February 6 and will go on sale in the fall. Comparisons to the just-redone 2015 Cadillac Escalade, which has been much more effectively modernized and restyled, will be immediate. Holding the line on changes has helped Lincoln keep the cost steady: the big Caddy comes out in the spring, priced just over $71,000, whereas the Navigator is expected to be priced in the mid to upper $50,000s.

Aside from the engine news, the Lincoln has been given a cosmetic update, but not one that changes the basic character of the big luxury vehicle. First and foremost, for the Navigator fans out there, let’s talk about the optional Reserve package with its Ziricote wood trim—you know, the stuff you’d find on a yacht—and twenty-two inch polished aluminum wheels, plus, if you so desire, a set of chromed running boards.

Oh, and the leather. Acres of buttery premium Trevino leather. Color and materials design manager Barb Whalen describes the leather as “incredibly soft, but it has a rugged quality.” It’s absolutely everywhere, especially if you choose the Reserve option package: on all three rows of seats, on the center console, armrests, and shift knob, as well as covering the instrument panel and even the door to the glove box.
Another new touch on the 2015 model: illuminated “welcome mats” under both front doors that greet you when you unlock the Navigator.

On the outside, the Lincoln split-wing grille and revised hood profile make the Navigator match the rest of the Lincoln lineup, but anybody expecting a big difference in its appearance will be disappointed. A power tailgate and a full set of LED lights round out the exterior changes. You can get the 2015 Navigator, as before, in the already generous 207.4-inch wheelbase or the extended-wheelbase version, at 222.3 inches. The overall size and shape of the SUV have not changed.
The chief engineer, Elaine Bannon, says that's how Navigator buyers like it. “We knew what our customers wanted,” she said. “I’m proud that we were able to give our customers so much more.”

Is the 2015 Lincoln Navigator something you will personally own? Probably not, and it’s far from the ecological champion of the year. But a vehicle like this exists for the reason sequined gowns exist: because there is a time and a place for impractical, luxurious, over-the-top things. In the case of the Navigator, it’s not even impractical. After all, it can tow, it can carry, and it has all the passenger space you would need for whatever you’ve got in mind.
You, and seven of your closest sybarite friends.  In the immortal words of Young Jeezy (hey, I’ve got teenagers who own iPods):
“Let ‘em talk, let ‘em hate, watch that Lincoln Navigate”
