pageElements.text: I continue to not drive anything due to the big walking boot on my right ankle, which was broken at the Detroit Auto Show. Not that I stayed home. No sirree, you can't keep a good woman down! So I spent all of last week clumping from London to Crewe, England, and on through Paris, then back to London with Bentley Motors, purveyors of fine motorcars and now of fine furniture. Fancy that.

The trip began with a visit to the very private atelier of my millinery god, Philip Treacy, known to most Americans for the hats he made for the last royal wedding, thanks to People magazine's extensive coverage. It was a rare moment, brokered by our common friend Richard Charlesworth of Bentley.

It was on to Bentley’s historic headquarters in Crewe, where again I was welcome where few have been invited—the back rooms where veneers are mirror matched by hand, and where large southern German bull hides are scrupulously examined for the slightest flaws (unacceptable!) before a laser cuts pattern pieces dictated by a computer. Bulls are used because they don't have stretch marks.

On Wednesday, we took a high-speed train through the Chunnel to Paris, where we were whisked by chauffeured Bentley to a spectacular meal at the Prince de Galles hotel, from head chef Stéphanie Le Quellec. (Her husband is head chef at the Georges V, next door.)

The next day brought us (by Bentley) to the vast Maison et Objet, the Paris furniture show, to see the new line of Bentley designed and inspired furniture. Scott Allen, our brilliant JKC videographer, was there to record every word along the way. He is right now locked in his room (from the outside) editing several videos from our whirlwind trip abroad. Stay tuned.

It was so cold when we left for Europe that I couldn't imagine how to pack for the balmy 46° temps expected in Paris and London. It was just such a relief to not have to cover every millimeter of skin before I walked outside. Of course, we arrived home to the usual blizzard and more double-digit sub-zero temps.

Yesterday, I bought a figure-eight lace-up ankle brace so I could take the boot off and begin working out again at the gym and continue Pilates. It will be such a relief to do something other than lie on my back with my foot up in the air. Oh, wait! That is Pilates.

I’ve had all four dogs as constant company wherever I go, which is basically from couch to kitchen to bathroom, concentrating all the while not to trip over one or all of them and break my left ankle, too.

It's my birthday weekend ahead, and I'd really planned to be snowshoeing. Oh, well. I guess I'll be no shoeing. I continue to drive nothing (there is a Maserati Quattroporte parked outside my window that will leave long before my ankle brace comes off), and Jean's Driveway remains closed under a very deep layer of snow and ice, with ten more inches expected in the next two days.

But never fear. We have several more designer walkarounds from the Detroit Auto Show coming. We have our videos from our European adventure on the way. And before you know it, we will be on our way to the Westminster Kennel Club's big show at Madison Square Garden!
Love,
Jean

title: 3 Lists To Help You Survive Winter
promoTitle: 3 Lists To Help You Survive Winter
promoTeaserSmall: What to have in the car so you're ready for anything. Emergency kits: not just for winter anymore!
promoTeaser: What to have in the car so you're ready for anything. Emergency kits: not just for winter anymore!
metaTitle: 3 Lists To Help You Survive Winter - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 3 Lists To Help You Survive Winter. What to have in the car so you're ready for anything. Emergency kits: not just for winter anymore! Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: As a lifelong Northerner, I confess to a little perplexity over the complete standstill in Atlanta last week. But I was nevertheless sympathetic. There’s little that’s as frustrating (or scary) as being stuck in a traffic jam on untreated, ice-covered roads. So I’m not even going to make a single crack about pampered warm-climate drivers who have no clue about how to drive in the snow.

I am, however, going to make a crack about this: I heard a radio interview with a woman who vowed, after spending some thirty hours stuck in her car on the freeway, “I’ve decided I’m going to start keeping a little kit in the car with some snacks and drinks for emergencies.”
Okay, really? Who doesn’t have an emergency kit in the car? Is this really just a Snow Belt thing?

Maybe it’s because of many years spent driving kids places, but I always have emergency supplies in my car. And it's not just a winter thing (although we do have six more weeks of that, according to Punxsutawney Phil). I would go a step further and suggest that you keep an emergency box of supplies in your car year-round.

I would even suggest you store these supplies in various places around the car. What if your trunk freezes shut, or if you get into an accident that makes it impossible to open? Or what if you just don't feel like parking, getting out of the car, and fishing around in the trunk for a granola bar in pouring rain or -14 degree weather?
And don’t let anybody get into the car in weather below freezing without a warm coat, even if they are just carrying it!

For you:

    • Food that isn’t temperature sensitive: energy bars, dried fruit, beef jerky, hard candy like Brach’s or soft candy like Dots, small packets of nuts or raisins.
    • Drinks such as juice or flavored water in pouches or aseptic boxes.
    • At least one large metal or ceramic cup that could be used to melt snow for drinking water.
    • Layers of clothing for every person likely to be in the car. Gloves or mittens, socks, hats, plus changes of footwear and clothes. And don’t let anybody get into the car in weather below freezing without a warm coat!
    • Blankets
    • A first-aid kid: Band-Aids, your favorite over-the-counter pain reliever, antibacterial cleaning squares
    • If you take essential meds, carry a couple days’ supply with you, if you’re not comfortable storing it in the car
    • Paper towels and toilet paper. You don’t want to need to perform ablutions in a remote area, but if you ever have to, you’ll want to have the paper goods to do it cleanly
    • A cell phone charger that works in your car

For safety:

    • Shovel
    • Ice scraper and short-handled broom
    • Flashlight, with batteries stored separately so they don’t corrode or so the flashlight doesn’t get left on and wear them out
    • Candles and strike-anywhere kitchen matches

For your car:

    • Jumper cables
    • Tow rope or chain
    • Windshield washer fluid
    • Cat litter (to put under the wheels in case you get stuck)
    • Emergency reflectors or flares
    • For the truly prepared: a distress (“Help!”) flag and a whistle
it’s good to have what you might need in an emergency. Bridges go out, storms happen, and delays come out of nowhere.

Remember, this list is not just for winter; it’s good to have what you need in your car any time of the year, whether you're going on a long drive or just running errands around town. Bridges go out, storms happen, and delays come out of nowhere. In case you’re ever stuck anywhere for whatever reason, you’ll be glad you have something more than an old gas receipt and an empty fast-food coffee cup on board with you.
Digital Vision/Thinkstock

pageElements.text: The Westminster Dog Show is taking place next week, and Bob the Reluctant Show Dog will be one of the 2,716 dogs who will participate.

Bob has competed at Westminster once before, in 2011. He was not yet three, which was very young for a Chesapeake Bay retriever. He was not quite mature, but he was always spectacular-looking with great proportions. Because there were twenty-seven Chesapeakes competing, the judge separated the dogs and the bitches and looked at each group as it went around the ring separately. Then she had all of them come out together and go around the ring. Then she pulled ten dogs as her finalists. The first six she called were bitches, which immediately made us think that she favored the smaller, more delicate girl dogs. Then she picked the top three Chesapeakes in the country. She then went down the long line of dogs, stopped at Bob, and picked him as her tenth. I’m getting a little choked up just writing this. At the time, though, I burst into tears and cried so hard that I got interviewed.
None of the girls won, and Bob didn’t win. The number-one Chesapeake in the country won.

We think Bob has a decent chance this year because he is at the perfect age (five) and in peak condition, and he loves his handler, Kelly Leonard. It’s a magic bond, and he really enjoys the show ring. Don’t ask me how or why, but he loves it.

We skipped Westminster in 2012, and we missed out on 2013 last year because the entry was late. I was dumbfounded when my husband told me he sent it U.S. Postal Service Next Day and it didn’t arrive in time. (When it absolutely has to get there, you have to use FedEx.) Secretly, I was glad, because it was so hard going to Westminster that first time. You had to stay there all day with your dog, it was super hot, and you couldn’t sit down because there was no room for chairs, so we were leaning around a lot.
Want to meet Bob at Westminster? He'll be at Pier 94, Section A, Row 20 at the Chelsea Piers all day Tuesday (February 11).

This year, it’s completely different. Instead of jamming 2,716 dogs into a cramped under-construction space at Madison Square Garden, they have moved all of the breed competitions to the Chelsea Piers. If you win your breed, you enter the group competition. The group competitions will then happen at Madison Square Garden on Monday and Tuesday. These are what you see on television. When Tuesday’s group competition is finished, they go directly into Best in Show with the winners from all the groups.

This is a bench show, one of very few in the country. That means that the dogs are grouped together by breed in one area, and they have to stay there all day. So you can come in and out as a visitor and count on the fact that if you’re looking for Chesapeakes, you’ll find twenty of them all benched together with, of course, Bob being the most beautiful one of all. We call that being kennel blind.

If you want to come to Westminster and meet Bob in person and get his autograph or get your picture taken with him, he will be in Pier 94, Section A, Row 20. He’ll be hanging out in his cage except for bathroom breaks and on Tuesday, when he and the other nineteen Chesapeakes that are registered for the show will compete in Ring 8 at 12:30 p.m.

We’re going to leave from Ann Arbor on Sunday in a Mercedes-Benz Sprinter van. It’s quite a posse: Tim, handler Kelly, videographer Scott, Bob, and me. That’s right, we’re going there to work, with just a break to see Bob compete and let me weep a little bit. Just kidding. I’ll only be weeping if he wins. Actually, I might be fainting if he wins.

We want to make a little video that brings to you some of the excitement of having a dog in the show. Going to dog shows isn’t really magic. They frequently take place in sporting arenas and hotel conference rooms, where it’s all pretty cut and dried and there’s not a lot of ambiance unless you like the smell of dog pee. But Madison Square Garden was absolutely without a doubt as magic to us two years ago as it looks on television.

pageElements.text:
If you have ever printed directions from Google Maps, you are going to thank today’s complete update of Google Maps for saving you from the dorky Luddite’s fate. In fact, if you’ve ever planned a trip online, you’re going to love this complete revamp of this powerful online planning tool. Google did a refresh of the mobile version of Google Maps early in 2013, but today, if you use it from a Web browser, you will find it cleaner, prettier, more organized, better informed, and more integrated with your phone. Some fifteen percent of heavy users of the service have been getting access to some of the new tools for a few weeks. But, if you aren’t one of those, you should check it out before you go anywhere. 
Here’s why.
As of today, if you use Google Maps from a Web browser, you will find it cleaner, prettier, more organized, better informed, and more integrated with your phone.

Plane? Train? Drive?

Thinking of heading to the Big Apple for the weekend? But what’s the best way to go? Is it too expensive to fly? Would it be more onerous to drive? Now when you ask Google Maps for directions, it will weigh all these options for you. If a flight is available to your destination, it will do a quick calculation—based on actual flights—and include the time and cost of that option in your directions. Deciding on a mode of transportation no longer requires a visit to Kayak or Travelocity (although you still might want to hit your favorite travel site to book the flight). The decision, at least, is now a matter of a quick glance. Love it.

Get What You Need

Once you get to New York, you’ll want to have some fun. Search for a museum from Google Maps, and the map display will grok what you are thinking. Suddenly the most interesting tourist destinations are more visible than the bazillions of other scraps of information on that busy map. Search for Italian restaurants, and now those are more focused. Google Maps doesn’t eliminate the other information; it just brings to the fore what it knows you want to know.

Plans Already Included

Did you book a hotel or make a restaurant reservation online? How about a flight? Those will show up in your map, too, while you are searching for fun things to do. So you can eyeball how far the museum is from your hotel and how hard it will be to get to that restaurant from where you plan to be.

Transit Help

Not sure how to get from the hotel to your lunch meeting? Ask Google Maps for directions. It will display various driving options and, where public transit is an option, the subway. Choose the bus icon, and click “List all times and options.” It will show you a grid of your options so you can see how far you’ll have to walk (so you can pack the right shoes!), what train to take, and when you need to leave to get where you’re going on time.

What’s Going On?

Thinking about hitting a blues club? Taking in a play? Want to make sure there’s a ballet worth seeing while you’re there? Check out a venue from Google Maps, and click “Upcoming Events” to see what acts will be playing there in the coming weeks. No more opening six browser windows just to plan a simple evening out.
Google Earth is now integrated into maps. (No, it wasn’t before. They were completely separate.) So when you zoom in, you get a real feel for where you are going.

Better Visuals

It used to be a bit of a pain to get to street view from Google Maps. Not anymore. Bring up a museum, restaurant, or nightclub, and you’ll get a panel that shows you everything you might want to know about that destination. Not just how to get to it but the street view of it and user uploaded images of the place. Some venues even have an interior map so you can do a virtual tour from your browser. (These look awesome.) And Google Earth is now integrated into maps. (No, it wasn’t before. They were completely separate.) So when you zoom in, you get a real feel for where you are going.

Real-Time Traffic

Since Google bought Waze—the app that uses the army of smartphones traveling on the roads to track slow traffic, accidents, and other road events in real time—Waze data is being fed right into your Google Maps directions. (This has been working in the mobile apps for a while.) So, if you ask it to plot a route from where you are to where you want to go, it will show you construction sites, closed exit ramps, accidents, and other events that will have an impact on your journey. Click on these—represented as smashed cars, working guys, or exclamation point icons—to find out what’s going on. The directions panel will even let you choose if you want to look at real-time traffic or traffic that’s typical at a particular time of day. From your smartphone, the app might simply route you quietly around nasty events. So don’t be too surprised if it takes you a different way to smooth your commute.

Share Your Plans

Planning to take a trip with a special someone? Don’t waste your alone time talking about routes and timing. Click “My Custom Maps” to create a map you can customize and share—with just your paramour or everyone in your travel plans. This is a super powerful tool and I can’t possibly explain it all here. So, after clicking “My Custom Maps,” and “Create,” select the gear icon in the top right hand corner. Then go to "Take a Tour" to take a walk-through introduction to creating a map.

Map to Go

Did you spend your lunch break planning your mini break? And how did you plan to take that plan on the road? No worries. Just click "Save" from the directions panel, and all your research and routes will be saved to your smart phone. (As long as you sign in from your phone with the same Google e-mail address you use for Google Maps online.)
Maybe the last time you traveled, you showed up with a manila folder full of printouts from the Web. But it’s time to let go of the Nineties. Here’s why: It’s so much easier now.

title: 3 Electric Motorcycles
subTitle: The cheaper and more charming way to try an EV. Meet three West Coast makers of some good ones.

promoTeaser: The cheaper and more charming way to try an EV. Meet three West Coast makers of some good ones.
metaDescription: 5 Electric Motorcycles

contributors.bio: I'm the auto and motorcycle critic for the Orange County Register. Previously, I  was a staff writer at the Los Angeles Times for fourteen years, writing about motorcycles, cars, green living, and anything else that caught my fancy. Originally from Ann Arbor, Michigan, I currently live in Los Angeles with my ten-year-old son.

pageElements.text: Three years since entering the market, electric cars remain a novelty. Even if most people haven’t driven one, they’ve at least heard of the Tesla Model S, Chevrolet Volt, and Nissan Leaf.

The same can’t be said for their two-wheeled counterparts Zero, Brammo and Mission. Six years since the first production electric motorcycles started rolling onto the market, they continue to be an obscurity.

But women are a natural market for e-bikes. Lacking a hand-operated clutch and foot-actuated gearshift, in most cases, they don’t require the usual coordination of limbs to manage control, leaving a vehicle that’s as easy to ride as a scooter. Just twist the grip and go for emissions-free riding that costs mere pennies per day to operate.
For all those reasons plus the intangible one, fun, you ought to have a look at products from these West Coast companies that are powering 2014’s electric motorcycle lineup.

Zero Motorcycles

Zero Motorcycles first whispered its way onto the market in 2008 with a groundbreaking all-electric dirt bike. Since then, the Santa Cruz startup has added an S sport bike and a DS model that can be ridden both on-and off-road, as well as an all-new supersport model for 2014 called the SR, which can accelerate as fast as a Ferrari. Its 0-to-60-mph acceleration time is a lickety-split 3.3 seconds on its way to a 102-mph top speed.

New for 2014, a Z-Force Power Tank accessory can extend the range of its S and DS models to as much as 171 miles of city riding or eighty-eight miles on the highway. Recharging takes six to ten hours, depending on the size of the battery pack, and is done with a regular 110-volt wall outlet and charge cord that is built into the bike. The starting price is $12,995 for the S or a steep $16,995 for the SR, but operating costs are one penny per mile, versus fifteen cents for most cars.

Brammo

The Brammo company, based in Ashland, Oregon, makes the prettiest and fastest production electric motorcycle currently on the market. With a style that mimics Ducati’s bestselling Monster, the Empulse is a stylish commuter that can travel up to 128 miles per charge in city driving and about 80 miles per charge in combined city and highway riding. A top speed of 110 mph comes courtesy of an electric motor and 9.3-kilowatt-hour lithium-ion battery pack, which is showcased like the V-twin engine of a Harley-Davidson.

The only electric motorcycle to use a gearbox, the Empulse operates as a six-speed, similar to a clutched and gas-powered motorcycle.  In place of the gas tank is a carbon fiber shell that houses the same J1772 Level 2 charging port used on electric cars such as the Nissan Leaf and the Chevrolet Volt. Recharging takes about three hours with a Level 2 charger, or eight hours with a regular wall outlet. Pricing starts at $16,995.  Fuel economy is an astounding 438 mpg electric equivalent.

Mission Motorcycles

True to its name, Mission Motorcycles is on a quest much like Tesla’s. It seeks to combat the notion that electric vehicles are merely for tree-hugging do-gooders. It does this by offering a stylish, high-end electric sport bike that comes close to matching the performance of its gas-powered counterparts. The first bike from the San Francisco startup is limited to a forty-vehicle production run and is expected to hit the market in the summer. For $74,000, the Mission RS is a track-tested sport bike that boasts a top speed of 150 mph and a 0-to-60-mph acceleration time of just three seconds. A $30,000-plus R model will be available later in the year, with an estimated range of up to 140 miles per charge and a recharge time that’s as little as thirty minutes, using a Level 3 fast charger

pageElements.text: The Insight is a long-serving hybrid by Honda, and it provides everything we have come to expect from Honda’s green cars. The Insight shares its hybrid technology with the popular Civic Hybrid and gets similar gas mileage with 41 mpg in the city and 44 mpg on the highway. Unfortunately, at 98 hp it has 12 horses less than the Civic to get it across town. To help with economy, select the EcoAssist feature, which moderates throttle, transmission, and air conditioning for maximum efficiency.  The interior design takes its cues from several other Honda sedans, creating an appealing amalgam of ergonomic controls. There are also plenty of hiding spots and storage space for whatever you need to stash. One of the Insight’s biggest attractions is its price, with a base near $20,000. The low sticker isn’t without drawbacks, however, and the Insight can be a rough ride on bumpy roads with increasingly unpleasant cabin noise at high speeds. Honda didn’t skimp on safety, though, and the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety rated the Insight as a Top Safety Pick. With rear seats down, the cargo space, already respectable for a small car, almost doubles. The Insight’s value may be enough to make up for some minor deficiencies, and it is a good choice if you’re looking for a hybrid that doesn't break the bank.

title: 2014 Honda Odyssey
subTitle: Refreshed rolling HQ.

pageElements.text:
Type: Seven- or eight-passenger, front-wheel-drive minivan
Price range: $29,855-$45,480 (including destination charge)
Trim levels: LX, EX, EX-L, Touring, Touring Elite
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 248 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/28 mpg highway
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick Plus; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 star overall rating
Our favorite standard feature Flat-folding Magic Seat
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera, daytime running lights
Notable options on this model: Lane departure warning; Honda Vac (on Touring Elite model only)
You might also be considering: Chrysler Town & Country ($30,490), Nissan Quest ($27,415) (all prices include destination charges)

The Honda Odyssey does everything a family’s rolling HQ should. It can carry up to eight people, depending on seat configuration, tows up to 3,500 pounds, and boasts almost 40 cubic feet of storage behind the already generous third row. There’s plenty of room for storage up front, too, with a large removable center console that can fit even a sizeable purse and several water bottles. For trips to Ikea or cross-country moves, take advantage of Honda’s Magic Seat design and marvel as you fold the rear seats seamlessly into the floor to maximize cargo space. The Odyssey runs a V-6 engine with a six-speed automatic transmission, and it uses Honda technology that allows some cylinders to shut off when not in use, helping it achieve a class-high 19 mpg city and 28 mpg highway. 2014 brings a refresh of both the exterior and interior. Outside, the front end takes a bit of dive toward a bolder front grille, and sculpted aluminum fenders lead to chrome trimmed fog log lights. Inside, the center stack has been updated and accommodates tech features like a touchscreen for media and a USB interface.

Perhaps the biggest stroke of brilliance is the new HondaVac on the Touring Elite model which makes cleaning up an anytime anywhere possibility. True the price is high, starting just below $30,000 and reaching up to $45,000 fully loaded, but the safety and reliability of the Odyssey may make up for that. In the driving dynamics and styling departments the Odyssey makes some strides but can’t completely escape its van pedigree. Still, why should it try when this Honda ticks so many of those useful minivan boxes?

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: The top of the Nissan stand was one of the coolest places to be at the 2014 North American International Auto Show. To the left, the sweetest car ever, the IDx (right), shown first at last fall's Tokyo Motor Show. Small, reminiscent of the beloved Datsun 510, but modern in every way. I was not the first person to say, Build it and I'll buy one. To its right, the polarizing Nissan Sport Sedan Concept, widely touted as the next Maxima. When I say polarizing, I mean that one prestigious car magazine called it the best concept at the show and another called it a monstrosity. I rather liked that as well, especially its "floating" roof.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/237DqwitQns?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

The Sport Sedan Concept is the continuation of Nissan's philosophy of applying sports-car looks and performance to the sedan category. It's a little something for the Maxima fans among you to look forward to.
Congratulations, Shiro Nakamura, who never seems fazed by the critics. Always thoughtful, he is one of my favorites to spend time with.
